description: A member of the Microsoft System Center suite of management solutions, System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager increases IT productivity and efficiency by reducing manual tasks and letting you focus on high-value projects, maximize hardware and software investments, and empower end-user productivity by providing the right software at the right time. Configuration Manager helps you deliver more effective IT services by enabling secure and scalable software deployment, compliance settings management, and comprehensive asset management of servers, desktops, laptops, and mobile devices. In addition, Configuration Manager can integrate with Windows Server Update Services (WSUS), Network Access Protection (NAP), Certificate Services, Exchange Server and Exchange Online, Group Policy, the DNS Server role, Windows Automated Installation Kit (Windows AIK) and the User State Migration Tool (USMT), Windows Deployment Services (WDS), and Remote Desktop and Remote Assistance.
name: System Center 2012 Configuration Manager - 70-243
subtitle: SCCM

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike take a tour of the System Center Configuration Manager console. They do a high level overview of the different nodes in the console. They also talk about how SCCM fits into an enterprise environment.

Log Trace Tool, be able to go in,

537
00:25:19.410 --> 00:25:20.500
open up a log.

538
00:25:20.500 --> 00:25:23.270
And take a look at,
there's tools like the Swiss Army Knife.

539
00:25:23.270 --> 00:25:27.430
Vlog readers, I actually use it for
non-SECM logs,

540
00:25:27.430 --> 00:25:29.500
I use it outside for a bunch of stuff.

541
00:25:29.500 --> 00:25:31.780
It's so powerful that we can use it for
almost anything.

542
00:25:31.780 --> 00:25:33.790
It's been around for some time.

543
00:25:33.790 --> 00:25:34.810
It's part of the toolkit so

544
00:25:34.810 --> 00:25:37.670
it's definitely something that we're
gonna wanna just spend a little time on.

545
00:25:37.670 --> 00:25:40.010
We're also gonna take
you in at some point and

546
00:25:40.010 --> 00:25:42.700
we're gonna show you what's
going on with SQL Server.

547
00:25:42.700 --> 00:25:47.240
And as I scroll over and
just move up here real quickly.

548
00:25:47.240 --> 00:25:49.620
And I'll zoom in so we can see.

549
00:25:49.620 --> 00:25:53.870
You can see that I am in the SQL Server
management studio, we are using,

550
00:25:53.870 --> 00:25:56.095
as you can see there, SQL Server 2012.

551
00:25:56.095 --> 00:26:00.585
And I've just taken a quick view of
the databases that are in there.

552
00:26:00.585 --> 00:26:04.055
We do have some Operations Manager
databases, Report Server databases,

553
00:26:04.055 --> 00:26:04.885
Orchestrator.

554
00:26:04.885 --> 00:26:08.025
As I said, we're using multiple
products from the System Center Suite.

555
00:26:08.025 --> 00:26:10.415
But we're here to talk about and
focus on SCCM.

556
00:26:10.415 --> 00:26:14.975
You can see I've highlighted
the CM_ database, the last three

557
00:26:14.975 --> 00:26:19.910
alphanumeric characters, in this case PLB,
are gonna be the site code for

558
00:26:19.910 --> 00:26:23.550
System Center Config Manager,
whatever the database underscore

559
00:26:23.550 --> 00:26:26.560
end of that sentence or end of that
statement is is always your site code.

560
00:26:26.560 --> 00:26:28.280
So in this case, our site code is PLB.

561
00:26:28.280 --> 00:26:32.010
The site code is a three digit
alpha numeric identifier

562
00:26:32.010 --> 00:26:34.100
unique to the site installation.

563
00:26:34.100 --> 00:26:35.920
Has to be specified
when we do the install.

564
00:26:35.920 --> 00:26:39.370
We'll look at that in a future
episode when do the install demo.

565
00:26:39.370 --> 00:26:42.450
And once you set that up,
good news is it's there forever.

566
00:26:42.450 --> 00:26:44.160
Bad news is it's there forever.

567
00:26:44.160 --> 00:26:44.830
>> Can't change it.

568
00:26:44.830 --> 00:26:47.383
>> Only way to change that is to
blow it out and start from scratch.

569
00:26:47.383 --> 00:26:50.371
Remember, blowing it out and
starting from scratch is not so simple.

570
00:26:50.371 --> 00:26:53.030
Because we integrate into
the active directory.

571
00:26:53.030 --> 00:26:55.770
And so it's just not a matter of just
blowing out what we've done with

572
00:26:55.770 --> 00:26:56.700
System Center.

573
00:26:56.700 --> 00:26:57.400
We have to go out and

574
00:26:57.400 --> 00:27:01.200
remove the System Center Config container
in order to be able to do that.

575
00:27:01.200 --> 00:27:03.690
What I'm gonna quickly show you
by just way of wrapping up here.

576
00:27:03.690 --> 00:27:05.890
I'm gonna move to our
other machine real quick.

577
00:27:05.890 --> 00:27:08.039
We've got a domain controller
we set up as well.

578
00:27:09.270 --> 00:27:10.520
So I'm just going to zoom in for

579
00:27:10.520 --> 00:27:14.444
us on the Active Directory User and
Computer manager.

580
00:27:14.444 --> 00:27:15.685
I have that opened up here.

581
00:27:15.685 --> 00:27:19.750
As you can see, we've got that set
up our practicelabs.com domain.

582
00:27:19.750 --> 00:27:22.260
I've set up the advanced features view.

583
00:27:22.260 --> 00:27:24.870
So I've gone to the view menu
chosen advanced features so

584
00:27:24.870 --> 00:27:27.780
we can see all of the system
containers in here.

585
00:27:27.780 --> 00:27:30.590
And as I scroll down you'll
see I have a system container.

586
00:27:30.590 --> 00:27:33.540
And I have [COUGH]
System Management right there.

587
00:27:34.790 --> 00:27:37.650
And as I move over inside
the System Management container,

588
00:27:37.650 --> 00:27:40.460
you'll see that I have some
information that's been set up and

589
00:27:40.460 --> 00:27:43.030
configured in there,
including a reference to my site code.

590
00:27:43.030 --> 00:27:47.170
When I talk about having to get rid of not
just on installing Config Manager, but

591
00:27:47.170 --> 00:27:49.750
potentially coming in here and
dealing with this.

592
00:27:49.750 --> 00:27:52.280
Having to reset the site codes
a little complicating cuz it involves

593
00:27:52.280 --> 00:27:53.210
several things.

594
00:27:53.210 --> 00:27:56.050
So we're gonna talk about how to set this
container up because it's not created

595
00:27:56.050 --> 00:27:56.630
by default.

596
00:27:56.630 --> 00:27:59.250
As a matter of fact it's
part of the installation for

597
00:27:59.250 --> 00:28:00.750
System Center Confiq Manager.

598
00:28:00.750 --> 00:28:03.400
We'll do this in our future
walk through in the demo.

599
00:28:03.400 --> 00:28:05.990
We're gonna have to go in and
actually use ADSI Edit.

600
00:28:05.990 --> 00:28:09.020
Which is the actual directory
service editing tool.

601
00:28:09.020 --> 00:28:12.430
We need farce level admin rights,
enterprise admin rights to use that.

602
00:28:12.430 --> 00:28:16.230
We're going to use ADSI edit to create
the System Management container that I

603
00:28:16.230 --> 00:28:17.120
just showed you.

604
00:28:17.120 --> 00:28:18.880
We have to manually create that for

605
00:28:18.880 --> 00:28:21.910
System Center Config Management to be
able to write these items in there.

606
00:28:21.910 --> 00:28:23.280
Create them during the install.

607
00:28:23.280 --> 00:28:24.390
We're going to show you how to do that.

608
00:28:24.390 --> 00:28:27.150
Make sure that's part of our checklist for
installing.

609
00:28:27.150 --> 00:28:29.370
We'll talk through all
those things as we go.

610
00:28:29.370 --> 00:28:30.540
>> Okay, all right.

611
00:28:30.540 --> 00:28:32.820
Well, Adam I tell you what,
that's a lot of great information.

612
00:28:32.820 --> 00:28:35.820
I don't know about you guys and
gals out there, I'm getting excited.

613
00:28:35.820 --> 00:28:38.390
Looking at that console you
just see the potential.

614
00:28:38.390 --> 00:28:40.560
A lot of the things that we
already do on our network,

615
00:28:40.560 --> 00:28:44.120
maybe we're running deployment services or
WSUS, and things like that.

616
00:28:44.120 --> 00:28:46.470
We can see where we can
start tying that in and

617
00:28:46.470 --> 00:28:49.090
getting it under one
interface is fantastic.

618
00:28:49.090 --> 00:28:51.670
Instead of having so
many different consoles to go through.

619
00:28:51.670 --> 00:28:52.780
And then, of course, it's got so

620
00:28:52.780 --> 00:28:56.200
many more capabilities that I
can't wait to for you to show us.

621
00:28:56.200 --> 00:28:57.960
So, again excited.

622
00:28:57.960 --> 00:28:58.890
Hope you guys are too.

623
00:28:58.890 --> 00:29:00.450
That's gonna do it for
this particular episode.

624
00:29:00.450 --> 00:29:01.440
Hope you enjoyed it.

625
00:29:01.440 --> 00:29:04.160
Remember if you wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live

626
00:29:04.160 --> 00:29:07.980
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

627
00:29:07.980 --> 00:29:09.940
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

628
00:29:09.940 --> 00:29:10.560
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

629
00:29:10.560 --> 00:29:12.278
>> And we'll see you next time.

630
00:29:12.278 --> 00:29:17.610
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss the architecture of a SCCM deployment. They look at primary sites and secondary sites, and describe their purpose and functionality. They also look at the SCCM roles that are installed on the servers in the deployment.
episodes.title: Architecture Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.751 --> 00:00:16.140
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.140 --> 00:00:17.390
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:21.350
Today, we're doing our System Center
Configuration Manager 2012 R2.

5
00:00:21.350 --> 00:00:24.640
And in this episode,
we're gonna take a look at, and

6
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:27.890
kind of do an overview of
the architecture involved when

7
00:00:27.890 --> 00:00:30.170
we're running
System Center Configuration Manager.

8
00:00:30.170 --> 00:00:35.510
It can be from a very simple one or
two server solution to something

9
00:00:35.510 --> 00:00:40.030
very complex that stretches across
multiple sites, geographic boundaries.

10
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:42.250
It has multiple servers involved with it.

11
00:00:42.250 --> 00:00:43.600
It can be pretty complex.

12
00:00:43.600 --> 00:00:46.800
So here to help us make sense
of all that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

13
00:00:46.800 --> 00:00:47.800
How's it going Adam?

14
00:00:47.800 --> 00:00:48.430
>> Good, good.
So

15
00:00:48.430 --> 00:00:50.750
the theme is making me
incredibly simple complex.

16
00:00:50.750 --> 00:00:51.940
That's what we're gonna go with.

17
00:00:51.940 --> 00:00:53.310
>> Microsoft is good at that.

18
00:00:53.310 --> 00:00:54.150
>> They are.

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:55.600
We shouldn't say those things though.

20
00:00:55.600 --> 00:00:56.310
That's not nice.

21
00:00:56.310 --> 00:00:58.690
So we are gonna try to make
the incredibly complex simple.

22
00:00:58.690 --> 00:01:00.282
I was only kidding around about
making the simple complex.

23
00:01:00.282 --> 00:01:04.852
It brings up an interesting point for us
which is that when we start talking about

24
00:01:04.852 --> 00:01:08.620
this technology, we can easily
get lost in the details, right?

25
00:01:08.620 --> 00:01:12.840
And we can easily get so
consumed with the nitty gritty or

26
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:16.542
the off in the corner what I
call purple squirrels right.

27
00:01:16.542 --> 00:01:20.410
Chasing those things that don't really
either exist or are not very important to

28
00:01:20.410 --> 00:01:23.550
us that we can spend a lot of time
focusing on things that may or

29
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:25.120
may not be super critical.

30
00:01:25.120 --> 00:01:28.240
So what we're gonna try to do is stay
focused on things that are gonna be

31
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:29.320
important for us.

32
00:01:29.320 --> 00:01:32.390
We're gonna take a look at some things
that will help us to understand that,

33
00:01:32.390 --> 00:01:36.460
take a look at some diagrams, talk about
some lists of various configuration items,

34
00:01:36.460 --> 00:01:37.770
features, solutions.

35
00:01:37.770 --> 00:01:38.920
Whatever it may be.

36
00:01:38.920 --> 00:01:40.430
And along the way,

37
00:01:40.430 --> 00:01:43.410
we'll try to make sure we point out things
that are gonna be critical for you.

38
00:01:43.410 --> 00:01:46.740
Not only to better understand this
product, but also to really understand

39
00:01:46.740 --> 00:01:51.110
the proper way to get it set up, to get it
deployed, to be successful, if you will.

40
00:01:51.110 --> 00:01:53.629
Because there's a right way and
wrong way to do almost everything.

41
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:57.755
More often than not while we look for
guidance and

42
00:01:57.755 --> 00:02:01.780
wanna try to figure out the best path
forward and the path of least resistance.

43
00:02:01.780 --> 00:02:03.980
I'm trying to use every
contrite acronym and

44
00:02:03.980 --> 00:02:08.710
thought process and
saying that I can come up with here.

45
00:02:08.710 --> 00:02:11.440
When we do think about these things,
what we wanna think about is the fact that

46
00:02:11.440 --> 00:02:14.770
while there's a lot of guidance out there,
and a lot of it is very good by the way

47
00:02:14.770 --> 00:02:17.890
about things that you can do, you should
do, you may or you may not wanna do.

48
00:02:17.890 --> 00:02:20.970
What we often miss when
we read that guidance and

49
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:25.550
when we look for those best practices is,
how does that translate to me?

50
00:02:25.550 --> 00:02:27.495
Right, how does that
translate to my world?

51
00:02:27.495 --> 00:02:29.875
How does that in my world make sense?

52
00:02:29.875 --> 00:02:34.295
Am I the person who has that small,
medium, or large infrastructure?

53
00:02:34.295 --> 00:02:37.095
Do I have to do what so and so says?

54
00:02:37.095 --> 00:02:38.945
Can I get away with doing
something different?

55
00:02:38.945 --> 00:02:40.500
It's hard to know.

56
00:02:40.500 --> 00:02:43.910
It's hard to know,
ultimately because we may not, ourselves,

57
00:02:43.910 --> 00:02:46.200
really have a good understanding
of what needs to be accomplished.

58
00:02:46.200 --> 00:02:46.800
Let's be honest.

59
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:52.240
If we did, you will need to spend as much
time going through in painstaking detail,

60
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:55.520
some of the things you do to figure out
how to get things working the right way.

61
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:57.490
Cuz you'd make better decisions up front.

62
00:02:57.490 --> 00:03:00.640
But because you're not always comfortable
with the kind of things that have to be

63
00:03:00.640 --> 00:03:05.090
decided on or don't realize that the
things that you're deciding on up front

64
00:03:05.090 --> 00:03:07.720
will then impact your
ability to do things later.

65
00:03:07.720 --> 00:03:10.520
We talked in our last episode
about choosing a site code and

66
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:13.730
the fact that if you choose poorly,
you have to effectively step back and

67
00:03:13.730 --> 00:03:15.830
redo the installation from scratch.

68
00:03:15.830 --> 00:03:17.620
Because that site code can't be changed.

69
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:20.990
You may or may not know that about SCCM,
and you may not realize that.

70
00:03:20.990 --> 00:03:23.860
But during the install,
you're gonna have to know that.

71
00:03:23.860 --> 00:03:26.630
You're gonna have to decide
where you're gonna put SCCM,

72
00:03:26.630 --> 00:03:29.160
how you're gonna set it up,
how it's gonna be architected.

73
00:03:29.160 --> 00:03:33.230
For instance, one of the things
that has changed recently

74
00:03:33.230 --> 00:03:36.016
from 2012 to 2012 SP1 to now 2012 R-2.

75
00:03:36.016 --> 00:03:37.235
S-P-1 post.

76
00:03:37.235 --> 00:03:41.870
Now S-P-1 2012 R-2 effectively is.

77
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:45.580
When 2012 first came out,
when you set up a primary site,

78
00:03:45.580 --> 00:03:48.960
we're gonna start talking about what
these terms mean as we get going here.

79
00:03:48.960 --> 00:03:53.270
But when you setup a primary site and
installed SCCM, you made that choice, and

80
00:03:53.270 --> 00:03:54.850
that was basically it.

81
00:03:54.850 --> 00:03:58.530
If you decided to set up a primary
site as a standalone option,

82
00:03:58.530 --> 00:03:59.740
effectively on its own.

83
00:03:59.740 --> 00:04:04.620
Without a [COUGH] central admin server
and/or a hierarchy associated with it,

84
00:04:04.620 --> 00:04:08.260
you had no option to go back and
add that to a hierarchy at that point.

85
00:04:08.260 --> 00:04:10.730
When 2012 first came out,
that was the way it was.

86
00:04:10.730 --> 00:04:15.160
It's very similar to what we saw in 2007
and the earlier versions of the product.

87
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:19.843
In 2012 post SP1 and 2012 R2, we now have
the option to start out as a stand alone

88
00:04:19.843 --> 00:04:23.780
but then build a hierarchy around that
standalone primary server as things

89
00:04:23.780 --> 00:04:28.340
develop and we change our mind and
perhaps grow the infrastructure over time.

90
00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:30.830
And so
we are changing the way things work,

91
00:04:30.830 --> 00:04:34.270
in some cases literally version
to version, release to release.

92
00:04:34.270 --> 00:04:35.420
And we have to keep up with that.

93
00:04:35.420 --> 00:04:38.900
We have to understand that,
as SECM admins, as architects,

94
00:04:38.900 --> 00:04:42.106
as professionals that are potentially
looking to use this product.

95
00:04:42.106 --> 00:04:45.110
Because if we're not familiar
with some of those subtleties and

96
00:04:45.110 --> 00:04:50.340
some of those things that potentially can
be very valuable if we understand them but

97
00:04:50.340 --> 00:04:51.950
can be very troubling if we don't.

98
00:04:51.950 --> 00:04:56.032
We may make bad decisions, and there is
such a thing as a bad decision right?

99
00:04:56.032 --> 00:04:57.038
We wanna be nice to people and say,

100
00:04:57.038 --> 00:04:58.931
oh it's okay you didn't make
a bad decision, we'll fix that.

101
00:04:58.931 --> 00:05:00.312
Wrong, right?

102
00:05:00.312 --> 00:05:02.020
>> [LAUGH].
>> You make a bad decision.

103
00:05:02.020 --> 00:05:03.260
We've go work to do.

104
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:04.100
It's a problem.

105
00:05:04.100 --> 00:05:06.040
You should figure it out up front.

106
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:11.110
And so the reality is being
successful with this product is 90%,

107
00:05:11.110 --> 00:05:15.610
as it is in most cases with
almost any IT solution, 90%.

108
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:19.440
Planning and doing due diligence and
exercising due care.

109
00:05:19.440 --> 00:05:23.630
We'll borrow a couple of terms
from our CISSP conversations.

110
00:05:23.630 --> 00:05:27.490
Mike's heard me say that so many times
over our time together doing the other

111
00:05:27.490 --> 00:05:30.340
discussions at CISSP,
he's probably sick of hearing those terms.

112
00:05:30.340 --> 00:05:33.030
But due care and due diligence,
very important thought processes for

113
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:35.550
an IT administrator, an IT architect,

114
00:05:35.550 --> 00:05:40.120
an IT professional looking to use SSCM or
any product, I don't care what it is.

115
00:05:40.120 --> 00:05:41.980
You're just opening an Internet Explorer.

116
00:05:41.980 --> 00:05:43.380
You're gonna go Google something.

117
00:05:43.380 --> 00:05:47.130
Prior planning, understanding what it is
you're looking to accomplish, making sure

118
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:51.620
you have it clear in your mind, knowing
what is going to be a good to know, right.

119
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:54.970
Having the things you need to have
clear in your head is gonna always be

120
00:05:54.970 --> 00:05:56.510
a good way to be successful.

121
00:05:56.510 --> 00:05:59.790
And so planning is gonna be
the baseline for everything we do.

122
00:05:59.790 --> 00:06:05.540
Planning when it comes to SCCM, especially
in 2012 is going to be very important for

123
00:06:05.540 --> 00:06:08.320
us to make sure that we are focused on.

124
00:06:08.320 --> 00:06:10.950
I have to click in our live lab
environment every so often and

125
00:06:10.950 --> 00:06:13.560
make sure that the lab stays active and
it knows we're paying attention to it.

126
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:14.390
It gets a little lonely.

127
00:06:14.390 --> 00:06:15.980
Wanna make sure we're
paying attention to it.

128
00:06:15.980 --> 00:06:17.190
Make sure it knows we're here.

129
00:06:17.190 --> 00:06:18.420
It's okay.
Nice lap computer,

130
00:06:18.420 --> 00:06:20.400
nice lap computer, right?

131
00:06:20.400 --> 00:06:21.756
You're not alone.

132
00:06:21.756 --> 00:06:24.360
So we wanna make sure
that we understand that

133
00:06:24.360 --> 00:06:26.570
planning is gonna be one of
the critical keys to success.

134
00:06:26.570 --> 00:06:29.030
So let's begin our
journey towards planning,

135

towards understanding better what this

00:17:32.930 --> 00:17:36.460
Never have to bother ourselves with either
the thing at the top of the pyramid up

362
00:17:36.460 --> 00:17:40.250
there, the central admin site, and/or the
lower left hand corner, the child item,

363
00:17:40.250 --> 00:17:42.040
which is the secondary site.

364
00:17:42.040 --> 00:17:44.420
But let's, since we're already down,
let's talk about the Secondary Site,

365
00:17:44.420 --> 00:17:46.290
then we'll make our way back
up to the primary site.

366
00:17:46.290 --> 00:17:51.051
So the secondary site, what that's gonna
allow us to do is effectively allow us to

367
00:17:51.051 --> 00:17:53.430
be able to achieve two things.

368
00:17:53.430 --> 00:17:57.180
Bandwidth management in low bandwidth
situations for remote sites.

369
00:17:57.180 --> 00:18:00.670
We're gonna put a secondary site server
in, which is gonna have a management point

370
00:18:00.670 --> 00:18:04.290
associated with it, perhaps a distribution
point role associated with it.

371
00:18:04.290 --> 00:18:08.290
That's gonna allow us to effectively
control what clients are doing at

372
00:18:08.290 --> 00:18:12.227
that site, so they can talk to the
secondary site server to get instructions.

373
00:18:12.227 --> 00:18:16.030
In a, effectively,
a local fashion across the LAN.

374
00:18:16.030 --> 00:18:19.310
As opposed to having to go across the WAM
connection, which is probably slow and

375
00:18:19.310 --> 00:18:21.960
unreliable back up to the Primary Site.

376
00:18:21.960 --> 00:18:25.060
So the primary reason to deploy
a Secondary Site in the architecture is

377
00:18:25.060 --> 00:18:27.180
because of bandwidth considerations.

378
00:18:27.180 --> 00:18:31.700
Because if we do that we can then control
distribution of packages and applications.

379
00:18:31.700 --> 00:18:34.680
We can control distribution
of policy updates.

380
00:18:34.680 --> 00:18:36.199
We can control hardware inventory,

381
00:18:36.199 --> 00:18:38.164
software inventory information and
all that.

382
00:18:38.164 --> 00:18:42.819
Because all we're doing is effectively
asking the Secondary Site server to talk

383
00:18:42.819 --> 00:18:44.467
to the Primary Site server.

384
00:18:44.467 --> 00:18:48.392
And as a result of that connection and
that communication being controlled and

385
00:18:48.392 --> 00:18:51.360
being optimized,
we have a one to one communication.

386
00:18:51.360 --> 00:18:55.290
Instead of several hundred clients sitting
down there trying to communicate back up

387
00:18:55.290 --> 00:18:58.220
to the primary server over a slow and
unreliable connection.

388
00:18:58.220 --> 00:19:00.550
So that's gonna be the key there.

389
00:19:00.550 --> 00:19:02.469
So we wanna make sure
that we're aware of that.

390
00:19:02.469 --> 00:19:05.990
We also want to take note of the fact that
the Secondary Site has its own data base.

391
00:19:05.990 --> 00:19:08.770
And that's kinda interesting
as well because in 12 R2,

392
00:19:08.770 --> 00:19:13.520
SCCM 12 R2, we now see that the Secondary
Site has its own data base locally.

393
00:19:13.520 --> 00:19:16.600
Again, so it could store information,
manage certain things.

394
00:19:16.600 --> 00:19:18.100
Whereas, in prior versions,

395
00:19:18.100 --> 00:19:22.035
the Secondary Site most likely did not
necessarily have its own data base.

396
00:19:22.035 --> 00:19:24.070
So that is, again, something to consider.

397
00:19:24.070 --> 00:19:27.480
Our Secondary sites are going to be
in an parent-child relationship,

398
00:19:27.480 --> 00:19:29.640
they can only be related
to a Primary Site.

399
00:19:29.640 --> 00:19:31.360
They cannot exist on their own and

400
00:19:31.360 --> 00:19:33.910
they cannot exist unless there is
a Primary Site to link them to.

401
00:19:33.910 --> 00:19:36.070
So we wanna make sure
we are aware of that.

402
00:19:36.070 --> 00:19:39.670
We set that up during the installation
when we run the installation media and

403
00:19:39.670 --> 00:19:41.210
choose what option we want.

404
00:19:41.210 --> 00:19:42.970
We'll have an option for a Primary Site.

405
00:19:42.970 --> 00:19:44.470
We do that install first.

406
00:19:44.470 --> 00:19:47.260
The only way we can do a Secondary Site
in the install media is

407
00:19:47.260 --> 00:19:49.310
if there's already
a Primary Site available.

408
00:19:49.310 --> 00:19:50.580
We can reference that site code,

409
00:19:50.580 --> 00:19:54.150
and then we know we can then
see that Primary Site is there.

410
00:19:54.150 --> 00:19:55.639
So we wanna make sure we're aware of that.

411
00:19:56.690 --> 00:20:00.850
We can SQL Server Express and/or
a SQL Database to store the configuration

412
00:20:00.850 --> 00:20:01.610
information.

413
00:20:01.610 --> 00:20:04.510
So that SQL Database sitting down
there could be a SQL Express,

414
00:20:04.510 --> 00:20:08.550
or your local version of SQL installed
there that's gonna be available to us.

415
00:20:08.550 --> 00:20:12.430
We replicate our collective client data
back up across that two way arrow,

416
00:20:12.430 --> 00:20:14.630
that bidirectional arrow that
Mike's represented there for

417
00:20:14.630 --> 00:20:19.000
us to drive communication, again,
between the Secondary Site server and

418
00:20:19.000 --> 00:20:20.710
the Primary Site server.

419
00:20:20.710 --> 00:20:24.356
So the clients that are local to
that Secondary Site that are gonna

420
00:20:24.356 --> 00:20:28.462
be in that V land or in that site
boundary, or whatever it may be, are gonna

421
00:20:28.462 --> 00:20:33.420
be communicating with the Primary Site
server through the secondary site server.

422
00:20:33.420 --> 00:20:36.580
They're not gonna be communicating
directly up, so just be aware of that.

423
00:20:36.580 --> 00:20:38.140
We do not support client assignments,

424
00:20:38.140 --> 00:20:41.520
as clients are assigned
directly to the Primary Site.

425
00:20:41.520 --> 00:20:44.370
But the Secondary Site is
going to effectively proxy and

426
00:20:44.370 --> 00:20:47.310
manage on behalf of the primary site
because of the bandwidth issues.

427
00:20:47.310 --> 00:20:49.210
So we do just wanna be aware of that.

428
00:20:49.210 --> 00:20:51.557
We can house the majority
of our site server roles,

429
00:20:51.557 --> 00:20:55.305
and we'll talk about what these roles are
in our conversation as we continue here.

430
00:20:55.305 --> 00:20:58.420
But can host the majority of those
roles at the secondary site server

431
00:20:58.420 --> 00:20:58.930
if we need to.

432
00:20:58.930 --> 00:21:00.990
So it's a very flexible option for
us, right?

433
00:21:00.990 --> 00:21:03.890
As we talked about, the Primary Site
is going to be the kind of

434
00:21:03.890 --> 00:21:05.450
the focal point of all that information.

435
00:21:05.450 --> 00:21:06.980
We're going to manage clients there.

436
00:21:06.980 --> 00:21:08.670
We have the SQL data base there.

437
00:21:09.870 --> 00:21:11.080
You'll notice the Primary Site,

438
00:21:11.080 --> 00:21:15.010
if we scroll up just a little towards
the central admin site, has a parent-child

439
00:21:15.010 --> 00:21:19.010
relationship going on with this thing at
the top called the Central Admin Site.

440
00:21:19.010 --> 00:21:21.915
So a Primary Site is
usually gonna be the parent

441
00:21:21.915 --> 00:21:23.965
in the sense that it's gonna
be the primary server.

442
00:21:23.965 --> 00:21:27.745
It may have one or more secondary
sites' children associated with it, but

443
00:21:27.745 --> 00:21:32.315
it can also be, the primary site can be,
a child of a central admin site.

444
00:21:32.315 --> 00:21:35.385
So, effectively,
it can be both a parent and a child.

445
00:21:35.385 --> 00:21:40.045
Whereas a Secondary Site can only be a
child and can be connected to a Secondary

446
00:21:40.045 --> 00:21:43.635
site can be connected to a central
admin site through a Primary Site.

447
00:21:43.635 --> 00:21:45.615
So there is that hierarchy relationship.

448
00:21:45.615 --> 00:21:49.260
You can think of it as the central admin
site being the parent, the primary site

449
00:21:49.260 --> 00:21:53.520
being the child of the central admin site,
and the parent to the secondary site.

450
00:21:53.520 --> 00:21:56.730
And the secondary site being
a child of the primary site, and

451
00:21:56.730 --> 00:21:59.420
a grandchild of the central admin site.

452
00:21:59.420 --> 00:22:01.270
In effect when we think
about the hierarchy.

453
00:22:01.270 --> 00:22:03.490
The central admin site
is kind of interesting.

454
00:22:03.490 --> 00:22:04.540
This is an all up server,

455
00:22:04.540 --> 00:22:07.580
you can see multiple primary sites
are linked to it in Mike's diagram.

456
00:22:07.580 --> 00:22:09.280
They're coming up from both sides.

457
00:22:09.280 --> 00:22:14.080
They are two bi-directional arrows going
up and linking up there as we can see.

458
00:22:14.080 --> 00:22:18.340
And what the Central Admin Site does,
effectively, is really provide two things,

459
00:22:18.340 --> 00:22:21.050
two capabilities,
administration and reporting.

460
00:22:21.050 --> 00:22:23.960
It's the all up site that
allows us to gather, as you can

461
00:22:23.960 --> 00:22:28.490
see through the information flows across
the arrows, all of the client information,

462
00:22:28.490 --> 00:22:32.840
all the configuration information,
all the inventory information, etc.

463
00:22:32.840 --> 00:22:37.000
All that is gathered from all of the sites
and rolled up into, what we call the CAS,

464
00:22:37.000 --> 00:22:38.290
or the Central Admin Site.

465
00:22:38.290 --> 00:22:42.200
We have to to be careful of using acronyms
because CAS is also the acronym for

466
00:22:42.200 --> 00:22:44.920
the Client Access Server in Exchange.

467
00:22:44.920 --> 00:22:47.620
So we have to be careful with that
because that's our front end server.

468
00:22:47.620 --> 00:22:48.310
In Exchange,

469
00:22:48.310 --> 00:22:52.210
we have to obviously be aware of the fact
that the acronym is primarily used there.

470
00:22:52.210 --> 00:22:54.310
But depending on the topology
we have deployed and

471
00:22:54.310 --> 00:22:57.295
the technology we use, we may actually
see it used in multiple places.

472
00:22:57.295 --> 00:23:02.380
So, the Central Admin Site here is
gonna gather up all that information.

473
00:23:02.380 --> 00:23:06.070
Notice it has its own SQL Server database,
again, up at the top there.

474
00:23:06.070 --> 00:23:10.230
That database is gonna be used to store
that information that's coming up so

475
00:23:10.230 --> 00:23:13.070
we can report against it and
do those kinda things.

476
00:23:13.070 --> 00:23:15.220
We don't process any client data here.

477
00:23:15.220 --> 00:23:18.900
We don't support any clients being
assigned to the central admin site.

478
00:23:18.900 --> 00:23:23.020
It is strictly an all-up central
vision of our hierarchy.

479
00:23:23.020 --> 00:23:24.880
That is really all that we do here.

480
00:23:24.880 --> 00:23:28.720
We have a limited number of site roles
that can exist in the Central Admin Site.

481
00:23:28.720 --> 00:23:32.600
It is really designed for administration
all-up and reporting primarily.

482
00:23:32.600 --> 00:23:35.650
These are the key things that
really we see going on there.

483
00:23:35.650 --> 00:23:38.180
I know that we have created some bulleted
lists that kind of summarize all

00:23:38.180 --> 00:23:39.510
the points I just made.

00:23:39.510 --> 00:23:42.520
So maybe we'll just be able to, and we
are gonna throw those up real quick, but

we want the, not the site roles,
but actually,

487
00:23:46.455 --> 00:23:51.240
yeah the central admins site is and to use

00:23:51.240 --> 00:23:53.305
So if we can go through those and

the key bullet points that we'll Summarize

00:24:02.400 --> 00:24:05.220
what the key functionality is by role and

00:24:05.220 --> 00:24:07.153
So, the central admin site as you can see,

00:24:07.153 --> 00:24:09.893
required to use if we're gonna
have a multi site hierarchy,

00:24:09.893 --> 00:24:12.960
have to have a central avenue
to the site in order to do that.

00:24:12.960 --> 00:24:17.450
If we're gonna be using it we're focusing

00:24:17.450 --> 00:24:18.460
as you can see.

00:24:18.460 --> 00:24:20.950
Has to have a SQL database
associated with it.

00:24:20.950 --> 00:24:25.310
No client data being processed,
no client assignments being a home there.

00:24:25.310 --> 00:24:29.500
Clients are not gonna have a site code,
in other words, that points to a central

00:24:29.500 --> 00:24:33.180
admin site, or rather, that site code
points to a primary site server.

00:24:33.180 --> 00:24:34.510
So I just wanna make

And it has a limited number of site roles,

If we scroll down, I think we have the,

00:24:41.020 --> 00:24:45.330
So to use config manager, at least one

we can be in a child relationship

We talked about that.

We cannot be a child to

We saw the two primary sites

They connect up to the central admin site,

00:25:12.198 --> 00:25:16.470
But, key to understand that the primary

Remember with the primary site,

Remember SQL Server Express and or

By the way that SQL Server database,

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike demonstrate the installation process for SCCM 2012 R2. They configure a server with all of the prerequisites for installing SCCM 2012 R2, including installing IIS, the Windows ADK, and extending the schema. Then they complete the SCCM 2012 R2 installation wizard.
episodes.title: Installing SCCM 2012R2

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike cover post-installation tasks. They talk about ways to verify the SCCM 2012 R2 installation succeeded, and everything is working properly. They verify the proper directories were created, check log files, and open the SCCM console. They also use powershell to verify installation results.

00:25:15.287 --> 00:25:18.371
save it, run it whenever you want, very
quickly and easily get these lists without

536
00:25:18.371 --> 00:25:21.039
having to open up the console,
go through the GUI and that kinda thing.

537
00:25:21.039 --> 00:25:23.993
>> Absolutely, so, lots of different
ways for us to check the validity of

538
00:25:23.993 --> 00:25:27.145
the install to make sure things are
working, to make sure that everything is

539
00:25:27.145 --> 00:25:30.294
there, and to then be able to through
a little power show into it, to sweeten

540
00:25:30.294 --> 00:25:33.289
the mix a little bit and then to be
able to then use that to our advantage.

541
00:25:33.289 --> 00:25:36.803
As Mike was saying, maybe automate
something maybe have a script that does

542
00:25:36.803 --> 00:25:38.830
that for us when we log on so
we can see that.

543
00:25:38.830 --> 00:25:40.039
Lots of different ways to use that.

544
00:25:40.039 --> 00:25:41.039
>> Fantastic.

545
00:25:41.039 --> 00:25:44.558
All right, Adam again another great
episode we got to look at what happens

546
00:25:44.558 --> 00:25:48.630
after the installation where those log
files reside and how we can view those.

547
00:25:48.630 --> 00:25:50.660
And now we just verify
that everything's theirs.

548
00:25:50.660 --> 00:25:52.789
As you said, kick the tires, right?

549
00:25:52.789 --> 00:25:55.854
Make sure everything is good,
test out some of those features,

550
00:25:55.854 --> 00:25:57.690
make sure everything's ready to go.

551
00:25:57.690 --> 00:25:59.570
All right, well we appreciate that Adam.

552
00:25:59.570 --> 00:26:00.330
We had a great episode.

553
00:26:00.330 --> 00:26:01.997
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

554
00:26:01.997 --> 00:26:05.664
Remember, if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

555
00:26:05.664 --> 00:26:08.498
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

556
00:26:08.498 --> 00:26:10.206
Signing off for this one,
I'm Mike Rodrick.

557
00:26:10.206 --> 00:26:11.123
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

558
00:26:11.123 --> 00:26:12.581
>> And we'll see you next time.

559
00:26:12.581 --> 00:26:18.330
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike demonstrate creating a secondary site in SCCM 2012 R2. They walk through the wizard to add a secondary site to the existing SCCM infrastructure created in a previous episode. They also look at configuring the communications between the two sites.
episodes.title: Create a Secondary Site
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.125 --> 00:00:10.125
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.315 --> 00:00:16.192
Hello and welcome to another
fantastic episode here at ITPro TV

3
00:00:16.192 --> 00:00:17.560
>> Mm, switching it up, that's awesome.

4
00:00:17.560 --> 00:00:18.700
>> I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

And here with me of course is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

14

How's it going Adam?

15
00:00:45.730 --> 00:00:50.600
>> It is going well, I am happy and I am
excited, cuz we're gonna learn how to, or

16
00:00:50.600 --> 00:00:54.370

site as Mike was just saying.

17

We've gone through the process
both from a talking perspective,

18
00:00:57.680 --> 00:01:00.300
tell you what you need to do,
make sure you're aware of the dos and

00:01:00.300 --> 00:01:04.050

in depth discussion, step by step,
to show you how to set up a primary site.

21

What we're gonna do now
a little bit shorter,

00:01:09.370 --> 00:01:11.220
not gonna take as much
time to do this one.

We've preloaded all the prereqs and

done all that stuff that we walked through

25
00:01:17.795 --> 00:01:20.035
But in this one we're gonna go ahead and
just show you,

26
00:01:20.035 --> 00:01:22.815
picking up from the point of, hey,
we've already installed the prereqs.

27
00:01:22.815 --> 00:01:26.244
We've got the site server that's
gonna become the secondary site,

28
00:01:26.244 --> 00:01:28.739
already set up in other words,
built ready to go.

29
00:01:28.739 --> 00:01:32.442
Got IS installed and
configured, got bits in there,

30
00:01:32.442 --> 00:01:35.242
got our Windows authentication set up,

31
00:01:35.242 --> 00:01:40.610
got our HTTP An non HTTP Authentication
configured for the .NET framework.

32
00:01:40.610 --> 00:01:42.840
So all that's been done cuz we
already showed you how to do that.

33
00:01:42.840 --> 00:01:45.920
So we'll assume you can already
understand that that stuff will happen.

34
00:01:45.920 --> 00:01:48.580
And what we're gonna do is move in and
go to the console.

35
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:50.020
We'll do that in just a second.

36
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:51.890
And we're gonna pick up from
that point and say, hey,

37
00:01:51.890 --> 00:01:55.180
if we want to install a secondary site,
what do we actually do?

38
00:01:55.180 --> 00:01:58.060
And it's good to walk through how to
do this because, again, you may never

39
00:01:58.060 --> 00:02:02.160
actually have the opportunity in the real
world to set up a secondary site.

40
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:06.130
A, you may not need one, and B,
it may already be done for you.

41
00:02:06.130 --> 00:02:09.350
And so we really want to do is take
advantage of the opportunities

42
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:13.630
we have in our episodes with you, to show
you how all these things are gonna work.

43
00:02:13.630 --> 00:02:17.180
So that way, if you ever have a chance to
do them you'll feel confident, number one.

44
00:02:17.180 --> 00:02:19.017
And number two if you don't,
you've seen them,

45
00:02:19.017 --> 00:02:21.730
you've been able to talk through them,
see them and interact with them,

46
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:23.866
and you have a better
understanding of what's going on.

47
00:02:23.866 --> 00:02:27.258
It's also gonna help you with the skills
required in this area to prepare for

48
00:02:27.258 --> 00:02:30.279
the exam that you're studying cuz
you are going to have to know how to

49
00:02:30.279 --> 00:02:31.396
set up a secondary site.

50
00:02:31.396 --> 00:02:34.669
There may be questions about that, and
you're gonna wanna be able to walk through

51
00:02:34.669 --> 00:02:36.880
that process and
get it straight in your mind.

52
00:02:36.880 --> 00:02:38.397
So what we're gonna do is
switch over to my machine and

53
00:02:38.397 --> 00:02:39.520
we're going to do a quick demo for you.

54
00:02:39.520 --> 00:02:42.990
And we're going to show you how to walk
through and set up a secondary site.

55
00:02:42.990 --> 00:02:44.060
So we're in the console.

56
00:02:44.060 --> 00:02:45.620
I'm going to narrate for you as we go.

57
00:02:45.620 --> 00:02:46.450
We're in the console.

58
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:49.270
So what I've done,
I've opened up on my primary server.

59
00:02:49.270 --> 00:02:52.760
I've opened up my secondary, or
excuse me on my primary server opened up

60
00:02:52.760 --> 00:02:56.930
my config manager console and
I've got the sites area highlighted.

61
00:02:56.930 --> 00:03:00.110
And what we're going to do is, I'm going
to zoom in for you in just a second,

62
00:03:00.110 --> 00:03:03.590
we're gonna go into the administration
workspace, just setting it up for you, so

63
00:03:03.590 --> 00:03:04.556
you know where we are.

64
00:03:04.556 --> 00:03:08.267
We're in the administration workspace, and
then what we're gonna do from there is

65
00:03:08.267 --> 00:03:11.150
we're gonna go into the site
configuration sites area.

66
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:15.120
And then we're gonna go ahead,
highlight our existing site, and

67
00:03:15.120 --> 00:03:16.030
thank you very much.

68
00:03:16.030 --> 00:03:18.090
And we're now gonna go ahead and

69
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:21.460
we are going to get ready
to set up a secondary site.

70
00:03:21.460 --> 00:03:23.440
So let me show you what
that's gonna look like.

71
00:03:23.440 --> 00:03:25.172
Just to set the stage, here.

72
00:03:25.172 --> 00:03:26.250
I'm gonna zoom in so

00:03:26.250 --> 00:03:30.780

74
00:03:30.780 --> 00:03:34.440
And I am in, as I showed you or
told you, the Administration workspace.

75
00:03:34.440 --> 00:03:36.470
You'll see that highlighted
down on the bottom.

76
00:03:36.470 --> 00:03:40.640
I'm in the Site Configuration area
with the Sites item highlighted.

77
00:03:40.640 --> 00:03:42.610
And off to the right as we highlight that,

78
00:03:42.610 --> 00:03:45.590
we have our primary site
selected in the console.

79
00:03:45.590 --> 00:03:49.460
And up above you'll see that we
can create a secondary site.

80
00:03:49.460 --> 00:03:51.812
Straight up there at 12 o'clock,
approximately,

81
00:03:51.812 --> 00:03:55.250
if we kind of move it over to the center
there, it'll be roughly 12 o'clock.

82
00:03:55.250 --> 00:03:59.040
And we can see that on the ribbon to
the right of saved searches we have three

00:03:59.040 --> 00:04:02.835
icons that kinda have the asterisk
associated with them that look like new

00:04:02.835 --> 00:04:03.870
something.

85
00:04:03.870 --> 00:04:07.510
One says Add Site System Roles, we'll
be dealing with that in another demo.

86
00:04:07.510 --> 00:04:10.890
Create Site System Server, and then to

87
00:04:10.890 --> 00:04:13.220
And that's where we're gonna go and
what we're gonna do.

88
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:17.550
If you remember, the ability to be

89
00:04:17.550 --> 00:04:22.010
is predicated upon the idea of having
a primary site already installed.

90

And so we have to have a primary site set

91
00:04:25.980 --> 00:04:29.180
Now that we have that installed,
we have the option of going in and

00:04:29.180 --> 00:04:30.790

93
00:04:30.790 --> 00:04:33.240
So we're gonna go ahead,
we're gonna highlight that primary site.

00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:35.067
And we do already have it highlighted, but

00:04:35.067 --> 00:04:38.100

96
00:04:38.100 --> 00:04:41.369
And as we do that,
then we'll be able to go ahead and

97
00:04:41.369 --> 00:04:44.271
we will be able to set
up our secondary sites.

98
00:04:44.271 --> 00:04:48.030
So we're gonna do that, we're going to
click on our Create Secondary Site icon.

99
00:04:48.030 --> 00:04:49.820
Now, we can do it from the ribbon,
by the way, or

100
00:04:49.820 --> 00:04:54.070
we can right click on the primary
site that is selected in the window.

101
00:04:54.070 --> 00:04:57.400
And through the right click option off
our menu we have the same options.

102
00:04:57.400 --> 00:04:59.000
So there's a couple of ways to do this.

103
00:04:59.000 --> 00:05:02.060
And we can also do this from
PowerShell by the way as well.

104
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:05.180
So we have at least three ways to do this.

105
00:05:05.180 --> 00:05:09.145
Mike's actually offered to do a demo

106
00:05:09.145 --> 00:05:12.388
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's going to be doing that this

00:05:12.388 --> 00:05:15.816

108
00:05:15.816 --> 00:05:20.378
If you tune in you will see Mike doing
that on the government access channel

109
00:05:20.378 --> 00:05:21.810
right after C-SPAN.

110
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:22.620
>> There you go.
[LAUGH]

111
00:05:22.620 --> 00:05:23.862
>> So we're gonna go ahead and

00:05:23.862 --> 00:05:25.650
we are going to go through the wizard.

113
00:05:25.650 --> 00:05:27.530
I am not gonna zoom in on every screen.

I'll zoom in on the ones that are
important and show you what we gotta know,

00:05:30.400 --> 00:05:33.300
but some of the introductory screens
really nothing going on there.

116
00:05:33.300 --> 00:05:36.500
Not a lot of value in showing you

118

So on the first Before you begin screen

119
00:05:42.500 --> 00:05:44.480
We're then gonna go ahead and

121
00:05:49.380 --> 00:05:53.450
We got a couple of red circles with

00:05:53.450 --> 00:05:55.120
meaning we need some information.

123
00:05:55.120 --> 00:05:57.710
So let's go zoom in real quick,
let's take a look at what we need.

124
00:05:57.710 --> 00:05:59.480
We're gonna need a site code.

125
00:05:59.480 --> 00:06:01.750
Now the site code, if you remember,

126
00:06:01.750 --> 00:06:05.060
is gonna be the three digit
alphanumeric value that we've assigned.

127
00:06:05.060 --> 00:06:07.650
But it's gonna be the site code
we've assigned to the primary site.

128
00:06:07.650 --> 00:06:12.000
Because, remember, the secondary site is
gonna become a child of the primary site.

129
00:06:12.000 --> 00:06:13.120
Doesn't have its own site code,

130
00:06:13.120 --> 00:06:17.600
in other words, it will piggyback off the
primary site's, parent's site IE, right?

131
00:06:17.600 --> 00:06:21.100
Site code, so we have to know
what that is ahead of time or

132
00:06:21.100 --> 00:06:23.040
we're gonna wind up going
off into space somewhere.

133
00:06:23.040 --> 00:06:25.530
>> So this is really what's
associating it with the primary.

134
00:06:25.530 --> 00:06:28.905
If you had more than one primary site,
this is where you're telling it you're

135
00:06:28.905 --> 00:06:31.600
gonna be a child of this
particular primary site.

136
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:35.430
>> Correct, so if we had, and Mike raises
an excellent point because in a multi site

137
00:06:35.430 --> 00:06:39.390
hierarchy, right, with a central admin
server, we've seen based on the diagrams

138
00:06:39.390 --> 00:06:42.780
that we looked at that we could indeed
have more than one primary site.

139
00:06:42.780 --> 00:06:45.880
And if we do, we obviously are going to
have unique site codes for every site.

140
00:06:45.880 --> 00:06:50.330
So the child site has to be told
effectively which site to associate with.

141
00:06:50.330 --> 00:06:52.780
And if we don't know which
site we're associating with,

142
00:06:52.780 --> 00:06:56.050
we could in theory wind up
associating with the wrong one.

143
00:06:56.050 --> 00:06:59.010
We also have to provide a site server
name, you'll see that as well.

144
00:06:59.010 --> 00:07:00.552
That's gonna work with the site code.

145
00:07:00.552 --> 00:07:04.130
The two have to match up in order to make
sure that we have the right site code and

146
00:07:04.130 --> 00:07:07.310
the right server in the site that
represents the site code as the primary

147
00:07:07.310 --> 00:07:08.270
site server.

148
00:07:08.270 --> 00:07:09.780
And then we have to have the site name.

149
00:07:09.780 --> 00:07:13.240
Remember the site name is
the name of the secondary site,

150
00:07:13.240 --> 00:07:15.690
not the name of the primary site.

151
00:07:15.690 --> 00:07:20.560
But this is gonna be the name of
the secondary site that we wanna create.

152
00:07:20.560 --> 00:07:21.690
We can call it anything we want.

153
00:07:21.690 --> 00:07:23.580
We're gonna call it Secondary Site.

154
00:07:23.580 --> 00:07:25.080
Remember I like simplicity,

155
00:07:25.080 --> 00:07:27.600
I like straightforwardness
in our naming conventions.

156
00:07:27.600 --> 00:07:31.830
I talked to you about the best practice
I try to implement with my customers.

157
00:07:31.830 --> 00:07:35.870
When we do site code naming,
we do the first letter of the site name,

158
00:07:35.870 --> 00:07:39.930
the domain name rather, and
then 01, 02, 03 to iterate.

159
00:07:39.930 --> 00:07:42.380
So we're gonna follow that
thought process as well.

160
00:07:42.380 --> 00:07:44.638
S for secondary site, 01.

161
00:07:44.638 --> 00:07:47.950
So S01 will be our site code for
our secondary site.

162
00:07:47.950 --> 00:07:50.390
You know, 01 for the first secondary site.

163
00:07:50.390 --> 00:07:51.980
So that's what we're gonna do here.

164
00:07:51.980 --> 00:07:53.420
And then we have our install folders.

165
00:07:53.420 --> 00:07:56.101
You can see we're gonna leave that at the
default, we're not gonna bother with that.

166
00:07:56.101 --> 00:07:58.818
So let's go and let's just get
that programmed in real quick.

167
00:07:58.818 --> 00:08:02.676
So we're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna do S01.

168
00:08:02.676 --> 00:08:04.831
So let me type that in.

169
00:08:04.831 --> 00:08:08.938
Or let me get in there and type that in.

170
00:08:08.938 --> 00:08:14.553
And then.

171
00:08:14.553 --> 00:08:17.910
Hold on just one second there.

172
00:08:17.910 --> 00:08:18.860
I clicked on the wrong.

173
00:08:18.860 --> 00:08:19.365
There we go.

174
00:08:19.365 --> 00:08:21.050
[LAUGH] I clicked on the wrong button.

175
00:08:21.050 --> 00:08:23.930
Wound up not only getting out of
that screen, but actually wound up

176
00:08:25.290 --> 00:08:28.870
going to a little bit of a different place
on the server that we don't need to be.

177
00:08:28.870 --> 00:08:32.740
So we're gonna put our site code in F01,
we're gonna go ahead in type in our

178
00:08:32.740 --> 00:08:36.540
site server name, so
that's gonna be our PLABSYS03.

179
00:08:38.240 --> 00:08:41.570
I happen to have bad habit of
talking to myself when I type

180
00:08:41.570 --> 00:08:45.670
because I don't know how to type, so it
takes my mind off the fact that I'm always

181
00:08:45.670 --> 00:08:47.830
one click away from making mistakes.

182
00:08:47.830 --> 00:08:51.000
So why you hear me talking
to myself while I'm typing,

183
00:08:51.000 --> 00:08:54.130
that's because of I didn't do that then
you would see nothing on the screen.

184
00:08:54.130 --> 00:08:58.770
Now we can also browse, we can find
a site survey by using the browse option.

185
00:08:58.770 --> 00:09:01.830
We're not going to do that but
we could go out in browser we need it too.

186
00:09:01.830 --> 00:09:04.690
So just want to make sure we're
aware of that is well and

187
00:09:04.690 --> 00:09:07.390
that we know that if we do you
need to browse want to go out and

188
00:09:07.390 --> 00:09:09.300
use that the pick list is in effect,
right?

189
00:09:09.300 --> 00:09:11.240
We can always go out and
find a server that way.

190
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:16.160
And then we're gonna name our sites, we're
gonna do that, call that secondary site.

191
00:09:16.160 --> 00:09:17.050
So we'll put all that in.

192
00:09:17.050 --> 00:09:19.620
And then we're gonna do down below.

193
00:09:19.620 --> 00:09:21.120
We're gonna hit next.

194
00:09:21.120 --> 00:09:22.540
Give that just a second.

195
00:09:22.540 --> 00:09:25.120
Moves to our installation
source files screen.

196
00:09:25.120 --> 00:09:29.170
On the installation source files, we have
the default set to copy installation

197
00:09:29.170 --> 00:09:33.010
source files for the parent sites or
over the network, meaning we're going to

But, Mike brings up an excellent point,

00:16:41.970 --> 00:16:44.490

00:16:44.490 --> 00:16:48.310

00:16:50.870 --> 00:16:54.380

00:16:54.380 --> 00:17:00.890
Because we may have multiple domain

00:17:00.890 --> 00:17:05.080

00:17:13.850 --> 00:17:17.820

00:17:17.820 --> 00:17:22.760

00:17:29.770 --> 00:17:30.950

00:17:30.950 --> 00:17:34.960

00:17:37.230 --> 00:17:39.260

We can still push certificates across

00:17:43.120 --> 00:17:45.730

00:17:45.730 --> 00:17:47.500

00:30:05.920 --> 00:30:07.500
But the idea would have been the same.

652
00:30:07.500 --> 00:30:10.330
I was just going to show you that we
effectively have a set of connectors

00:30:10.330 --> 00:30:12.620
roughly looking the same
that we can interact with.

654

And we can go in and we can take
a look at the child database and

00:30:15.940 --> 00:30:17.320
just take a look at the properties.

656
00:30:17.320 --> 00:30:19.320
We can take a look at
the sender tab in there and

657

just see what's going on
with the replication.

658
00:30:20.770 --> 00:30:24.070
So we can always circle back to that

659
00:30:24.070 --> 00:30:25.060
But the idea is the same.

660

We just wanted to be able to show you now

661
00:30:28.210 --> 00:30:30.570
how these communication pathways
are going to be created and

662
00:30:30.570 --> 00:30:31.930
ultimately what they're gonna look like.

663
00:30:31.930 --> 00:30:32.960
>> Very good.

664
00:30:32.960 --> 00:30:35.830
All right, well Adam again another
great look, love these labs,

665
00:30:35.830 --> 00:30:37.060
love these demonstrations.

666
00:30:37.060 --> 00:30:42.220
Got to see how to set up that secondary
site, associated with that primary site.

667
00:30:42.220 --> 00:30:44.780
Got to see the things going on in

668
00:30:44.780 --> 00:30:48.290
It's still in the process of
building that secondary site up but

669
00:30:48.290 --> 00:30:50.500
we got to see everything
we really needed to see.

670
00:30:50.500 --> 00:30:51.450
Fantastic, appreciate that.

671
00:30:51.450 --> 00:30:53.540
>> Absolutely.
>> Hope you guys enjoyed this one.

672
00:30:53.540 --> 00:30:55.680
Remember, if you want to attend

00:30:55.680 --> 00:30:59.380

00:30:59.380 --> 00:31:00.986
Signing off for this one,

00:31:00.986 --> 00:31:01.799
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

676

>> And we'll see you next time.

677
00:31:03.485 --> 00:31:09.110

topics.title: Design and plan System Center Configuration Manager infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike demonstrate deploying an operating system image using SCCM. They capture an image of a Windows 8.1 client, prepare the image for deployment, and then deploy the image to a bare metal machine.
episodes.title: OS Deployment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.215 --> 00:00:15.911
Hello, and welcome to another fun and
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

00:23:09.204 --> 00:23:12.676

00:23:12.676 --> 00:23:18.390

00:23:18.390 --> 00:23:23.690
And, like all unique objects, it has its

00:23:23.690 --> 00:23:25.382
It has the site code as
part of the package,

493
00:23:25.382 --> 00:23:26.843
the first three letters or numbers.

00:23:26.843 --> 00:23:31.671
PLB is the site code and
then it iterates from 0001, 0000,

00:23:31.671 --> 00:23:33.967
four 0s, and then the number.

496
00:23:33.967 --> 00:23:37.731
And so we potentially have a total
of five items there, right,

497
00:23:37.731 --> 00:23:41.010
which will give us up to
99,999 unique entries.

00:23:41.010 --> 00:23:43.634

00:23:43.634 --> 00:23:46.849

>> That's quite a bit, but we have

00:23:46.849 --> 00:23:53.379

99,999 individual packages if we need to.

501
00:23:53.379 --> 00:23:55.424
And then Content Validation, and

502
00:23:55.424 --> 00:24:00.291
even with the aggressive patch management
cycle that Microsoft has for updates,

503
00:24:00.291 --> 00:24:02.879
I think we still should be okay-
>> Right [LAUGH].

504
00:24:02.879 --> 00:24:05.809
>> For that unless we have a really,
really big patch Tuesday,

505
00:24:05.809 --> 00:24:07.712

506
00:24:07.712 --> 00:24:11.083
Also content validation,
this allows us to be able to,

507
00:24:11.083 --> 00:24:15.850
as you see here, verify integrity of
packages on the distribution point.

508
00:24:15.850 --> 00:24:19.720
We do that again, our magic number,
once a week, every seven days.

509
00:24:19.720 --> 00:24:23.680
Now content validation and integrity
is all about making sure that packages

510
00:24:23.680 --> 00:24:26.500
themselves have not been
modified without our knowledge.

511
00:24:26.500 --> 00:24:30.450
We are digitally signing those packages,
hashing them so we understand that they

512
00:24:30.450 --> 00:24:33.220
are effectively in the state they
were in when they were deployed.

513
00:24:33.220 --> 00:24:35.150
We are comparing that and checking that.

514
00:24:35.150 --> 00:24:38.570
If that has changed in any way, then
we may have to take remediative action.

515
00:24:38.570 --> 00:24:42.240
So we check that once a week to ensure
the integrity of those packages.

516
00:24:42.240 --> 00:24:43.390
Very important.

517
00:24:43.390 --> 00:24:47.130
And then boundary groups, we've
talked about boundary groups already.

518
00:24:47.130 --> 00:24:50.600
You'll see our lab boundary group there
that we've been using and demoing with.

519
00:24:50.600 --> 00:24:53.500
Remember the boundary group is
simply the administrative container,

520
00:24:53.500 --> 00:24:56.800
like a distribution point group
would be for distribution points.

521
00:24:56.800 --> 00:24:59.340
It's the administrative container for
the boundaries we create.

522
00:24:59.340 --> 00:25:04.730
If you remember, we create boundaries
by using either IP V4 addresses,

523
00:25:04.730 --> 00:25:10.010
IP V4 subnets, IP V6 prefixes,
and or at the directory sites.

524
00:25:10.010 --> 00:25:12.700
We can use any or
all of those things to create boundaries.

525
00:25:12.700 --> 00:25:16.322
And those boundaries are then going
to associate systems with a site.

526
00:25:16.322 --> 00:25:19.614
And the site is going to have those
boundaries as part of its definition.

527
00:25:19.614 --> 00:25:22.800
And then the systems within those
boundaries are going to be able to use

528
00:25:22.800 --> 00:25:26.418
this particular distribution point, or
this group, if we have more than one,

529
00:25:26.418 --> 00:25:30.040
assuming we have multiple distribution
points in a distribution point group.

530
00:25:31.340 --> 00:25:33.930
So I just want to make sure
we're aware of all that.

531
00:25:33.930 --> 00:25:37.650
So that is how the distribution point
is set up and configured for us.

00:28:09.680 --> 00:28:10.910

00:28:52.176 --> 00:28:57.680

601
00:28:57.680 --> 00:29:00.810
Now, it's interesting because

602
00:29:00.810 --> 00:29:04.500
The User State Migration Tool is really
used in a very narrowly defined set of

603
00:29:04.500 --> 00:29:05.620

604
00:29:05.620 --> 00:29:10.320
It is used when you want to migrate your
user profile from one machine to another

605
00:29:10.320 --> 00:29:14.650
and you're not centrally storing
things like, files, and pictures, and

606
00:29:14.650 --> 00:29:16.080
stuff like that.

607
00:29:16.080 --> 00:29:21.360
So we are, if we're going to image
a machine, do an update to it, you take

608
00:29:21.360 --> 00:29:24.540
it from seven to eight, 8.1, something
like that, we could use that tool.

609
00:29:24.540 --> 00:29:28.440
It winds up being very valuable in a very,
very narrowly defined business case.

610
00:29:28.440 --> 00:29:30.980
It's a lot of work to be
able to move the profile.

611
00:29:30.980 --> 00:29:34.650
It's usually not worth the effort if you
have lots and lots and lots of users.

612
00:29:34.650 --> 00:29:38.410
Because what typically is done is we
use folder redirects and group policy

613
00:29:38.410 --> 00:29:42.310
to manage all that information up to
central stores in the network somewhere

614
00:29:42.310 --> 00:29:46.310
on a storage area network or out on
a file share or whatever that may be.

615
00:29:46.310 --> 00:29:48.580
As a result of that users
reconnect to their data and

616
00:29:48.580 --> 00:29:51.890
pull it back down when we
give them a new desktop.

617
00:29:51.890 --> 00:29:54.860
And if we're doing VDI,
we don't need that because with VDI

618
00:29:54.860 --> 00:29:57.830
our desktop is effectively
following us wherever we go.

619
00:29:57.830 --> 00:30:00.590
So the reality is, this really is probably
not technology you're going to spend a lot

00:30:00.590 --> 00:30:03.630

it's there as a package, because

00:30:03.630 --> 00:30:07.580

Can actually have an opt-in where

So we'll take a look at that, but

01:03:09.790 --> 01:03:11.050
We can actually pre populate and

01:03:15.530 --> 01:03:18.110
We could do a wake on land to

1303
01:03:18.110 --> 01:03:22.980
since it's required it must be installed

01:03:22.980 --> 01:03:24.390

01:03:24.390 --> 01:03:27.710
Remember awake on land is typically going

01:03:27.710 --> 01:03:28.530

01:03:28.530 --> 01:03:31.200
Right.
You putting your lid down on your

01:03:34.660 --> 01:03:37.820

01:03:37.820 --> 01:03:41.120

1311
01:03:41.120 --> 01:03:45.590
that may power cycle down and power cycle

01:03:45.590 --> 01:03:49.150
So, we can send awake on land,

1313
01:03:49.150 --> 01:03:52.230

01:03:52.230 --> 01:03:54.240
So, this is kinda what

01:03:54.240 --> 01:03:55.628

01:03:55.628 --> 01:03:59.462
So, we have some nice options would

01:04:04.711 --> 01:04:07.490
Then this is also a pretty cool one,
I like this a lot.

01:04:07.490 --> 01:04:11.220
A lot of my customers are,
I have customers all over the world, so

1321
01:04:11.220 --> 01:04:14.200
I have people that are going to be
working in different time zones.

1322
01:04:14.200 --> 01:04:18.280
And this is nice because we can schedule
this deployment and do it based on UTC so

1323

we could specify
Universal Time Coordination.

1324
01:04:21.030 --> 01:04:25.429
So when we say it's five o'clock somewhere

1325
01:04:25.429 --> 01:04:30.023
o'clock somewhere, and we could specify
that this deployment only happens based on

1326
01:04:30.023 --> 01:04:33.130
that time localized for
every time zone that we exist in.

1327
01:04:33.130 --> 01:04:36.380
Because which you don't want to do, is
say you wanted to deploy at five o'clock

1328
01:04:36.380 --> 01:04:39.817
eastern time and that would be three
o'clock in the morning somewhere else, and

1329
01:04:39.817 --> 01:04:42.490
it's two o'clock in

01:04:42.490 --> 01:04:45.120
Because then that screws with not

1331
01:04:45.120 --> 01:04:48.300

on those systems in real time, right?

1332
01:04:48.300 --> 01:04:49.930
So we can set that up, schedule it.

Notice we have a calendar option,

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike do a review on managing applications, and talk about some of the do's and don'ts of deploying packages and applications. Then they demonstrate setting up the application catalog. They also show how to make it available to users via the intranet and the internet.

00:09:14.332 --> 00:09:19.263

00:33:04.600 --> 00:33:07.590
You'll see that it's not allowing
me to go in there, right?

632
00:33:07.590 --> 00:33:08.930
So we're not allowed effectively,

633
00:33:08.930 --> 00:33:13.720
that web page block is coming from the lab
environment, but the idea is that we're

634
00:33:13.720 --> 00:33:16.950
not able to get to it because we
haven't allowed it to show up, right?

635
00:33:16.950 --> 00:33:20.000
And so just be aware of the fact
that without that policy we're gonna

636
00:33:20.000 --> 00:33:20.965
have an issue.

637
00:33:20.965 --> 00:33:23.705
We wouldn't be able to bring it up
if we had it actually loaded and

638
00:33:23.705 --> 00:33:24.535
available in real time.

639
00:33:24.535 --> 00:33:27.965
So I just wanted to show you that
obviously that's gonna become important,

640
00:33:27.965 --> 00:33:32.835
because if we don't actually have that
in there, we're gonna run into an issue.

641
00:33:32.835 --> 00:33:37.445
And so we do wanna obviously update that
and although we could do it manually, and

642
00:33:37.445 --> 00:33:39.255
let's just see if the agent's installed.

643
00:33:39.255 --> 00:33:41.130
If it's not,
we're gonna wait any longer on it.

644
00:33:41.130 --> 00:33:44.530
You guys get the general idea, but if the
agent's, there I'll just run the updated,

645
00:33:44.530 --> 00:33:47.758
hasn't installed yet, it can take up
to five to ten minutes to install.

646
00:33:47.758 --> 00:33:50.780
So, may not actually be able to get it
in there, but you get the general idea.

647
00:33:50.780 --> 00:33:52.000
We're blocking that.

648
00:33:52.000 --> 00:33:54.180
We'd have to go in and allow it and
IE in effect, right, and

649
00:33:54.180 --> 00:33:55.610
just be able to bring that up.

650
00:33:55.610 --> 00:33:59.510
But once we did that we would then be able
to bring up the application catalog site.

651
00:33:59.510 --> 00:34:02.820
We then would be able to effectively
download any software that may

652
00:34:02.820 --> 00:34:05.510
have been posted there from
a self-service perspective.

653
00:34:05.510 --> 00:34:08.110
So it would allow us to be
able to do that functionality.

654
00:34:08.110 --> 00:34:11.000
So configuring it was really just
a matter of setting up the roles, and

655
00:34:11.000 --> 00:34:13.870
then from there we would be able to do
the deployment the way we've done and

656
00:34:13.870 --> 00:34:15.910
set up the software, and push it out.

657
00:34:15.910 --> 00:34:17.560
Then, we'd be able to
use it if we wanted to.

658
00:34:17.560 --> 00:34:18.763
So it's obviously pretty cool.

659
00:34:18.763 --> 00:34:22.023
If you wanted to see the tail end of
that where it actually does show up,

660
00:34:22.023 --> 00:34:23.530
you could go out and take a look.

661
00:34:23.530 --> 00:34:26.730
If you look at the documentation
we told you to take a look at, or

662
00:34:26.730 --> 00:34:30.380
even just go out and look for a YouTube

663
00:34:30.380 --> 00:34:33.420
Microsoft actually has some really
cool videos on their MVA site.

664
00:34:33.420 --> 00:34:36.400
You guys talk about MVA,
the Microsoft Virtual Academy, at all?

665
00:34:36.400 --> 00:34:36.930
>> I don't think so.

666
00:34:36.930 --> 00:34:39.600
>> Okay, so let's just do this real quick,
just bring up the website, and

00:34:39.600 --> 00:34:43.220
we'll go out and we'll take a look,
and I'll show where to go.

668
00:34:43.220 --> 00:34:48.370
Go to MicrosoftVirtualAcademy.com,
all one word.

669
00:34:48.370 --> 00:34:50.490
And can we go to Mike's website,
Mike's website,

670
00:34:50.490 --> 00:34:52.110
can we go to Mike's machine real quick,
Titus?

671
00:34:52.110 --> 00:34:53.270
Thank you so much.

672
00:34:53.270 --> 00:34:55.730
So, MicrosoftVirtualAcademy.com.

00:34:55.730 --> 00:34:57.360
No, that's not the right one.

00:34:57.360 --> 00:34:59.450
Do a google for Microsoft Virtual Academy.

675
00:34:59.450 --> 00:35:01.415
That's somebody else that's
pretending to be Microsoft.

676
00:35:01.415 --> 00:35:04.430
>> [LAUGHS]
>> I think it might be mva.microsoft.com

677
00:35:04.430 --> 00:35:05.060
is what I'm thinking.

678
00:35:05.060 --> 00:35:08.048
But just do Microsoft Virtual Academy,
yeah, just bring that up and
