00:35:08.048 --> 00:35:08.660
get a listing.

680
00:35:08.660 --> 00:35:09.830
I think that should be
the right one right there.

681
00:35:09.830 --> 00:35:11.878
>> mva.microsoft-
>> mva.microsoft.com, right.

682
00:35:11.878 --> 00:35:13.730
So just click on that and bring it up.

683
00:35:13.730 --> 00:35:17.540
So if you guys have not seen the Microsoft
Virtual Academy before, this is where all

684
00:35:17.540 --> 00:35:23.330
the online, free e-learning and
training is offered from Microsoft.

685
00:35:23.330 --> 00:35:25.650
It's got a wealth of
really cool stuff on it.

686
00:35:25.650 --> 00:35:29.660
And it's broken up by category,
so you can do app-dev stuff,

687
00:35:29.660 --> 00:35:34.030
you can do system admin stuff,
there's all sorts of stuff in there.

688
00:35:34.030 --> 00:35:37.010
And if you go in and
you search by topic or by area.

689
00:35:37.010 --> 00:35:39.400
So you go to IT Pro,
instead of Developers,

690
00:35:39.400 --> 00:35:41.110
cuz right now I think you
have the Developers one.

691
00:35:41.110 --> 00:35:43.970
Select it, you bring up the IT Pro area.

692
00:35:43.970 --> 00:35:47.090
It's got category stuff
specific to IT Pros.

693
00:35:47.090 --> 00:35:49.780
And, excuse me, then you may be
able to do a search in there, so

694
00:35:49.780 --> 00:35:52.460
you could probably do a search by topic.

695
00:35:52.460 --> 00:35:53.430
So you could go in.

696
00:35:54.600 --> 00:35:58.350
You could do a search for
you know SCCM for instance, right?

697
00:35:58.350 --> 00:36:01.040
Find all the stuff that's
available on SCCM so

698
00:36:01.040 --> 00:36:02.380
we'd be able to take a look for that.

699
00:36:02.380 --> 00:36:04.090
It does have to load the catalog.

700
00:36:04.090 --> 00:36:06.906
It may take a minute to do that,
but the idea would be that yeah,

701
00:36:06.906 --> 00:36:08.623
then you can see results for courses.

702
00:36:08.623 --> 00:36:10.913
You can see this is a pretty
intuitive interface.

703
00:36:10.913 --> 00:36:14.250
You could go in and you could search for
whatever you want to see.

704
00:36:14.250 --> 00:36:18.971
And then these are self paced e-Learning
environments that have prerecorded

705
00:36:18.971 --> 00:36:20.040
content.

706
00:36:20.040 --> 00:36:22.592
It's not live, it's not interactive, but

707
00:36:22.592 --> 00:36:26.220
it does give you the opportunity
to learn some basic stuff.

708
00:36:26.220 --> 00:36:30.130
There maybe links to additional
resources available there.

709
00:36:30.130 --> 00:36:33.550
There's usually links to the hosted
hands-on labs through TechNet.

710
00:36:33.550 --> 00:36:36.320
So it's actually a really nice
little integrated environment

711
00:36:36.320 --> 00:36:40.540
to do some additional, hands-on follow
up in terms of skill gathering.

712
00:36:40.540 --> 00:36:42.950
So you could just follow up there as
well if you're not familiar with that.

713
00:36:42.950 --> 00:36:45.280
It would be an additional
cool resource for you.

714
00:36:45.280 --> 00:36:46.520
So just think about that.

715
00:36:46.520 --> 00:36:49.030
We did have a couple of graphics
we just wanted to end up with,

716
00:36:49.030 --> 00:36:50.550
with regards to device affinity.

717
00:36:50.550 --> 00:36:52.300
You've got that little one there.

718
00:36:52.300 --> 00:36:56.130
And so
let's just talk about device affinity and

719
00:36:56.130 --> 00:36:59.640
we'll just quickly review what simulated
deployments are and give you a list of

720
00:36:59.640 --> 00:37:02.950
some additional log files that you want
to be looking at as well from a trouble

721
00:37:02.950 --> 00:37:06.940
shooting perspective to wrap up this
particular episode and this conversation.

722
00:37:06.940 --> 00:37:09.160
So I mentioned device
affinity in the last episode.

723
00:37:09.160 --> 00:37:11.680
We talked about the idea
that device affinity

724
00:37:11.680 --> 00:37:16.020
allows users to be associated with
a device and say hey, this is my device,

725
00:37:16.020 --> 00:37:19.970
any software you deploy to me should be
deployed to this device on my behalf.

726
00:37:19.970 --> 00:37:21.050
That kind of thing.

727
00:37:21.050 --> 00:37:24.370
So the idea with device affinity
is that a user says yes,

728
00:37:24.370 --> 00:37:26.690
I use this particular set of devices.

729
00:37:26.690 --> 00:37:30.250
You could see we have a user kinda
pointing to three devices of various

730
00:37:30.250 --> 00:37:31.530
types up there.

731
00:37:31.530 --> 00:37:32.870
And then down below,

732
00:37:32.870 --> 00:37:36.408
we have another user that's kind of
off to the side that's not associated.

733
00:37:36.408 --> 00:37:37.320
That user looks so

734
00:37:37.320 --> 00:37:42.190
much sadder by comparison to the one
up above, not associated with a device.

735
00:37:42.190 --> 00:37:46.950
And as a result of that, we could see the
big red X that Mike has put on the screen,

736
00:37:46.950 --> 00:37:49.360
indicating no device affinity.

737
00:37:49.360 --> 00:37:52.455
And so, as a result of that,
when we do a deployment

738
00:37:52.455 --> 00:37:57.370
the arrows coming out of the site server
on the right kind of indicate software or

739
00:37:57.370 --> 00:37:59.870
application packages being deployed.

740
00:37:59.870 --> 00:38:03.190
We don't deploy to the one with the X
because there's no affinity, the user has

741
00:38:03.190 --> 00:38:07.420
not said, I work and/or I play here so
you should put my software there.

742
00:38:07.420 --> 00:38:11.320
So device affinity is all about making
sure that users associate with devices.

743
00:38:11.320 --> 00:38:15.510
And then if we do user-based deployments
as opposed to computer-based deployments,

744
00:38:15.510 --> 00:38:20.150
we don't deploy software to devices that
users have not created an affinity for.

745
00:38:20.150 --> 00:38:21.252
So, that's kind of how that works.

746
00:38:21.252 --> 00:38:24.560
So just interesting to review that, and
maybe give you a little graphic on that to

747
00:38:24.560 --> 00:38:26.000
make sure you're
comfortable with that idea.

748
00:38:27.260 --> 00:38:30.780
We also, I want to remind you about
deploying applications over all,

749
00:38:30.780 --> 00:38:32.383
just the thought process with that.

750
00:38:32.383 --> 00:38:34.025
I don't know if we can
zoom in just a little bit,

751
00:38:34.025 --> 00:38:35.740
maybe make that just slightly bigger.

752
00:38:35.740 --> 00:38:38.880
But the idea we have there is we have

753
00:38:38.880 --> 00:38:43.150
a user down at the bottom there on
an end point looking at information or

754
00:38:43.150 --> 00:38:47.400
just waiting for information to
come down and/or go back and forth.

755
00:38:47.400 --> 00:38:52.310
Remember the computer agent will actually
update the management point every so

756
00:38:52.310 --> 00:38:56.270
often by checking in and
saying hey every 60 minutes by default.

757
00:38:56.270 --> 00:38:57.510
Is there a policy update?

758
00:38:57.510 --> 00:39:01.180
If there is, can I please receive the
output of that and see what's going on?

759
00:39:01.180 --> 00:39:04.870
Management point is a central point
of communication for the endpoint,

760
00:39:04.870 --> 00:39:06.468
the managed endpoint, the client agent.

761
00:39:06.468 --> 00:39:10.280
The management point checks with
the primary site server, says hey,

762
00:39:10.280 --> 00:39:11.440
is there any update?

763
00:39:11.440 --> 00:39:13.920
Primary site server may say,
yes, there is.

764
00:39:13.920 --> 00:39:18.100
There is a package or an application
waiting at one more distribution points

765
00:39:18.100 --> 00:39:21.930
please notify the endpoint that it
should go ahead and download that.

766
00:39:21.930 --> 00:39:25.130
So then the endpoint goes out in
the arrow on the right, goes and

767
00:39:25.130 --> 00:39:26.770
finds the distribution point.

768
00:39:26.770 --> 00:39:29.690
And, then, actually,
will stream down that application,

769
00:39:29.690 --> 00:39:32.450
or whatever package is waiting there,
and will bring it down.

770
00:39:33.480 --> 00:39:37.110
So this is how an application or
package deployment is gonna take place.

771
00:39:37.110 --> 00:39:40.530
So, just wanted to give you
a graphic to remind you of that.

772
00:39:40.530 --> 00:39:45.240
We, actually, did this in our last
discussion in the other episode, but

773
00:39:45.240 --> 00:39:48.980
this just brings to life for us
graphically what we did by way of review.

774
00:39:48.980 --> 00:39:51.490
We also talked about what
a simulated deployment is.

775
00:39:51.490 --> 00:39:53.456
I went through and
talked to you about that and

776
00:39:53.456 --> 00:39:55.129
just talked about the what if nature.

777
00:39:55.129 --> 00:39:56.845
We demoed it from the perspective of hey,

778
00:39:56.845 --> 00:39:58.961
can you do it after you've
done a real deployment?

779
00:39:58.961 --> 00:40:00.587
The answer is of course no.

780
00:40:00.587 --> 00:40:04.856
We talked about that and I showed you that
we got an error as a result of that but

781
00:40:04.856 --> 00:40:08.727
I did remind you that you would want
to do these prior to actually doing

782
00:40:08.727 --> 00:40:13.560
the deployment so that way we could test
the water and see what would happen.

783
00:40:13.560 --> 00:40:16.960
We just summarized the points here for
the simulated deployment.

784
00:40:16.960 --> 00:40:21.550
It allows us to test evaluation of, as you
can see, requirements in the application

785
00:40:21.550 --> 00:40:24.428
deployment type without having
to distribute the files.

786
00:40:24.428 --> 00:40:27.630
Meaning you wanna check the logic of
the rules of the deployment without

787
00:40:27.630 --> 00:40:29.170
actually doing the deployment.

788
00:40:29.170 --> 00:40:33.820
We just put the information up there that
helps you to kinda work through logically

789
00:40:33.820 --> 00:40:36.010
and make sure you understand the do's and
don'ts there.

790
00:40:36.010 --> 00:40:38.960
Good for you to have a sense of that
in case you're ever asked about it.

791
00:40:38.960 --> 00:40:42.910
Then I think we're gonna finalize and
finalize our conversation today in this

792
00:40:42.910 --> 00:40:49.430
episode with just a referencing nod to
the logs both on the server side and

793
00:40:49.430 --> 00:40:54.200
on the client side that are appropriate
and important for application deployment.

794
00:40:54.200 --> 00:40:56.700
We wanna make sure we know that there are,
as you can see,

795
00:40:56.700 --> 00:41:00.390
a fairly large number of log files
that we may wanna take notice of and

796
00:41:00.390 --> 00:41:03.400
be aware of,
there are 73 log files overall.

797
00:41:03.400 --> 00:41:06.270
If you remember we talked about
that in one of our prior episodes.

798
00:41:06.270 --> 00:41:10.360
But of that super set, we can see
that there are probably a good 12 at

799
00:41:11.680 --> 00:41:15.500
a minimum, maybe even 14 or so,
that are gonna be important for

800
00:41:15.500 --> 00:41:19.280
us to take notice of both on
the server side and on the client side.

801
00:41:19.280 --> 00:41:22.300
We would have individual
client logs by client

802
00:41:22.300 --> 00:41:24.830
that we may need to look at from
a troubleshooting perspective.

803
00:41:24.830 --> 00:41:27.500
And then we have a group of server logs

804
00:41:27.500 --> 00:41:31.345
that are going to be common to all clients
that are managed across those servers.

805
00:41:31.345 --> 00:41:33.535
We wanna make sure we're
familiar with both of those.

806
00:41:33.535 --> 00:41:36.875
Again, if you're preparing for the exam,
it's always a good idea to have a sense of

807
00:41:36.875 --> 00:41:39.775
the log files that are appropriate for
certain activities.

808
00:41:39.775 --> 00:41:42.265
You may get asked about them, you may not.

809
00:41:42.265 --> 00:41:43.795
Hard to say, you never know.

810
00:41:43.795 --> 00:41:46.635
But it's always good to know because
if you are asked about them,

811
00:41:46.635 --> 00:41:49.235
it'll be helpful to know we do
have log files in both locations.

812
00:41:50.380 --> 00:41:51.100
Very good, Adam.

813
00:41:51.100 --> 00:41:52.502
Again, another great episode.

814
00:41:52.502 --> 00:41:57.382
They're a good hands on look and we did a
little review on managing applications and

815
00:41:57.382 --> 00:42:01.840
talked about some do's and don'ts of
deploying packages and applications.

816
00:42:01.840 --> 00:42:06.010
We also got to look at setting
up the application catalog and

817
00:42:06.010 --> 00:42:09.820
how we can make those available
via the network, we'll say.

818
00:42:09.820 --> 00:42:13.300
Whether you're inside and
using HTTP and or HTTPS or

819
00:42:13.300 --> 00:42:17.010
on the outside in the internet
where we can only use HTTPS but

820
00:42:17.010 --> 00:42:19.650
making it available to the user
where the they can choose.

821
00:42:19.650 --> 00:42:22.630
Instead of us scheduling that install,
telling them when they're gonna get it,

822
00:42:22.630 --> 00:42:24.590
what they're gonna get,
we can set up a catalog.

823
00:42:24.590 --> 00:42:27.590
Let them pick and see what they want and
when they wanna get it.

824
00:42:27.590 --> 00:42:29.070
So really good stuff there.

825
00:42:29.070 --> 00:42:31.160
I hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

826
00:42:31.160 --> 00:42:33.650
Remember, if you attend one
of Adam's classes live,

827
00:42:33.650 --> 00:42:36.540
shoot us an email here
at seeadam@itpro.tv.

828
00:42:36.540 --> 00:42:39.470
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

829
00:42:39.470 --> 00:42:42.060
>> I'm an application package,
waiting deployment.

830
00:42:42.060 --> 00:42:43.139
>> We'll see you next time.

831
00:42:43.139 --> 00:42:48.730

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about integrating WSUS and the patch management functionality into SCCM 2012 R2. They configure WSUS and the SCCM environment to support deploying updates. Then they configure update synchronization with Microsoft.
episodes.title: Software Updates

environment, cuz that's

So we have options here,

We'll leave the defaults in place,

Because if we don't,

00:25:38.660 --> 00:25:39.356

00:25:39.356 --> 00:25:41.494
>> Which is one of those things that,

00:25:41.494 --> 00:25:43.262

00:25:43.262 --> 00:25:46.740
So I'm just gonna put check mark

00:25:46.740 --> 00:25:51.560
And then, show you that our magic

00:25:51.560 --> 00:25:53.240
So you'll see, enables synchronization.

00:25:53.240 --> 00:25:56.180
And then, the default simple

519
00:25:56.180 --> 00:25:58.130
But, of course, we can customize that.

520
00:25:58.130 --> 00:26:02.180
Now, keep in mind, cuz there's kind of
a debate that goes on a lot of the times

521
00:26:02.180 --> 00:26:05.930
when I do this with customers or I talk
about this in classes with students.

522
00:26:05.930 --> 00:26:09.390
Everybody says, well,
shouldn't we actually be more aggressive?

523
00:26:09.390 --> 00:26:11.460
Shouldn't we be checking for
updates every day?

524
00:26:11.460 --> 00:26:12.110
Right?

525
00:26:12.110 --> 00:26:17.180
But the reality is that, while in prior
years, before Microsoft really went to,

526
00:26:17.180 --> 00:26:21.420
almost without exception, for the most
part to a fixed schedule for updates,

527
00:26:21.420 --> 00:26:24.345
we commonly and
lovingly refer to that as Patch Tuesday.

528
00:26:24.345 --> 00:26:24.850
Right?

529
00:26:24.850 --> 00:26:27.160
So if you are aware,
and hopefully you are,

530
00:26:27.160 --> 00:26:30.520
of the fact that Microsoft's committed
to a once-monthly release schedule for

531
00:26:30.520 --> 00:26:34.750
patches, as most vendors have unless
there's a catastrophic issue, we

532
00:26:34.750 --> 00:26:38.500
call an out of band or out of cycle patch
that's released because of an emergency.

533
00:26:38.500 --> 00:26:40.830
And if that's the case, then, yeah,
you're gonna probably have to go out and

534
00:26:40.830 --> 00:26:43.875
manually sync in order to figure
out that that patch is out there,

535
00:26:43.875 --> 00:26:48.250
cuz it may come out, and it may be some
time outside that seven day cycle.

536
00:26:48.250 --> 00:26:51.930
But the reality is, normally,
unless things go horribly, horribly wrong

537
00:26:51.930 --> 00:26:55.820
somewhere, and while that happens,
it doesn't happen very often at all.

538
00:26:55.820 --> 00:27:00.000
You can probably count on less than one
hand the number of times that may happen

539
00:27:00.000 --> 00:27:01.210
over the course of a year.

540
00:27:01.210 --> 00:27:02.740
And I'm not kidding when I
say something like this.

541
00:27:02.740 --> 00:27:03.890
I'm being very serious.

542
00:27:03.890 --> 00:27:05.870
Right?
The majority of patches that Microsoft

543
00:27:05.870 --> 00:27:08.610
puts out are put out on
that once a month cycle.

544
00:27:08.610 --> 00:27:12.050
There may be 30 or 40 of them that
come out across a given cycle

545
00:27:12.050 --> 00:27:14.085
because of all the different
products that are patching.

546
00:27:14.085 --> 00:27:16.770
But the reality is,
if we know that we're patching,

547
00:27:16.770 --> 00:27:19.500
or be able to download new
patches once every thirty days,

548
00:27:19.500 --> 00:27:23.390
approximately, then checking every week
just to catch up on something that may

549
00:27:23.390 --> 00:27:25.990
have come up out of cycle
makes a lot of sense.

550
00:27:25.990 --> 00:27:29.690
Checking every day doesn't, because we're
just generating a lot of traffic that

551
00:27:29.690 --> 00:27:33.950
really probably 99% of the time gonna
come back negative and say, well,

552
00:27:33.950 --> 00:27:35.090
there's nothing new.

553
00:27:35.090 --> 00:27:36.990
So, we don't need to be that aggressive.

554
00:27:36.990 --> 00:27:37.845
Just want to point that out.

555
00:27:37.845 --> 00:27:40.720
Cuz a lot of people think,
oh I got to go out there, got

556
00:27:40.720 --> 00:27:44.270
to really make sure I'm checking everyday
to make sure I get the security things and

557
00:27:44.270 --> 00:27:45.321
make sure I have them all.

558
00:27:45.321 --> 00:27:47.940
And the reality is once
every seven days is fine.

559
00:27:47.940 --> 00:27:50.830
I actually tell customers to probably
of that out to every 14 days.

560
00:27:50.830 --> 00:27:54.980
And the reality is as long as you're
paying attention to out of patch or

561
00:27:54.980 --> 00:27:58.220
out of cycle patches that do come out,
and if you have to,

562
00:27:58.220 --> 00:28:01.150
you go out and manually sync to grab them,
you don't have to worry about that.

563
00:28:01.150 --> 00:28:04.070
Push that boundary out a little bit and
you're perfectly fine as well.

564
00:28:04.070 --> 00:28:04.830
So, that's up to you.

565
00:28:04.830 --> 00:28:05.660
Just keep that mind.

566
00:28:05.660 --> 00:28:06.990
So, we're gonna zoom out here.

567
00:28:06.990 --> 00:28:08.570
Gonna go back.

568
00:28:08.570 --> 00:28:10.370
Gonna leave that at every seven days.

00:28:11.390 --> 00:28:16.210
And we are going to go ahead and hit Next.

00:28:16.210 --> 00:28:17.360
There we go.

571
00:28:17.360 --> 00:28:19.330
And then,
what we're gonna do is the following.

00:28:19.330 --> 00:28:22.280
We have our supersedence rules page here.

00:28:22.280 --> 00:28:24.330
Let's just zoom in so you can see that.

574
00:28:28.447 --> 00:28:32.717
And what supersedence does, and I'll
kind of scroll over so you can see this,

575
00:28:32.717 --> 00:28:36.550
we configure a software update to
expire as soon as it has superseded.

576
00:28:36.550 --> 00:28:38.500
Or in other words,
another update has come out that says,

577
00:28:38.500 --> 00:28:40.980
hey, now I'm the update
that takes care of this.

578
00:28:40.980 --> 00:28:42.210
You're no longer needed.

579
00:28:42.210 --> 00:28:43.340
Right?
Get out of here.

580
00:28:43.340 --> 00:28:45.140
Right?
We don't want you here anymore.

581
00:28:45.140 --> 00:28:49.280
So, what we're doing is configuring
this idea that supersedents

582
00:28:49.280 --> 00:28:53.735
should be allowed to automatically expire
updates when new updates are pushed

583
00:28:53.735 --> 00:28:55.500
up by Microsoft that replace old ones.

584
00:28:55.500 --> 00:28:57.560
In effect, and this makes a lot of sense.

585
00:28:57.560 --> 00:28:58.160
Right?

586
00:28:58.160 --> 00:29:01.760
So, as a result of that,
you'll see here we have some options.

587
00:29:01.760 --> 00:29:04.450
Immediately expire
a superseded software update.

588
00:29:04.450 --> 00:29:08.580
Do not expire a superseded software update
until the software update is superseded

589
00:29:08.580 --> 00:29:11.910
for a specified period of time,
whatever that is.

590
00:29:13.100 --> 00:29:16.070
Period of time is in so
many months by the way, just to note that.

591
00:29:16.070 --> 00:29:17.440
Not days, but months.

592
00:29:17.440 --> 00:29:18.380
One of those things.

593
00:29:18.380 --> 00:29:21.510
So you go ahead and you put three
over there thinking,okay, three days.

594
00:29:21.510 --> 00:29:23.680
And, no, it's really 90 days, right?

595
00:29:23.680 --> 00:29:24.890
So just be aware of that.

596
00:29:24.890 --> 00:29:28.550
So what we have to decide
is how long we wanna wait.

597
00:29:28.550 --> 00:29:33.440
Now, you'll notice the default behavior
here is that we will not expire

598
00:29:33.440 --> 00:29:38.080
the superseded software update
immediately, but rather wait three months.

599
00:29:38.080 --> 00:29:39.120
Now, the reason for

600
00:29:39.120 --> 00:29:42.720
this is what can happen sometimes
is that patches are put out,

601
00:29:43.780 --> 00:29:47.390
they run their normal life, then Microsoft
puts out another patch or any vendor.

602
00:29:47.390 --> 00:29:50.120
Microsoft or any vendor puts out
another patch, and says, okay,

603
00:29:50.120 --> 00:29:52.020
we're superseding that patch.

604
00:29:52.020 --> 00:29:54.990
But the problem is, number one,
you may have that patch

605
00:29:54.990 --> 00:29:58.700
already deployed across part of your
infrastructure, but not all of it.

606
00:29:58.700 --> 00:30:03.190
You may also have that patch
deployed to most, if not all,

607
00:30:03.190 --> 00:30:07.300
the infrastructure but be looking
to bring some new machines online.

608
00:30:07.300 --> 00:30:09.350
It may be in your built in images, so

609
00:30:09.350 --> 00:30:11.370
you may already have the patch
in different places and

610
00:30:11.370 --> 00:30:15.040
have to work through the logic of whether
you are gonna continue using it or not.

611
00:30:15.040 --> 00:30:18.760
And so, we don't supersede the patch
right away to give you a window to

612
00:30:18.760 --> 00:30:22.850
be able to continue applying that patch if
necessary from a remediation standpoint

613
00:30:22.850 --> 00:30:27.080
to make sure that you get to a point
where your base line is now going to,

614
00:30:27.080 --> 00:30:31.530
not only reflect the fact that you're
gonna get rid of this patch, but

615
00:30:31.530 --> 00:30:34.640
that you have the chance to update it so
you can integrate the new patches.

616
00:30:34.640 --> 00:30:37.530
So, this is much about bandwidth,
I keep saying bandwidth,

617
00:30:37.530 --> 00:30:40.350
as much about baseline management
as it is about anything else.

618
00:30:40.350 --> 00:30:45.225
So we wanna keep in mind that superseding
patches right away can lead to disruption.

619
00:30:45.225 --> 00:30:48.165
Because what'll happen is that patch is
no longer available for you to deploy.

620
00:30:48.165 --> 00:30:50.810
And there may be systems that
actually still need that patch.

621
00:30:50.810 --> 00:30:51.345
>> Right.

622
00:30:51.345 --> 00:30:52.865
>> So that's why we want
to give ourselves a window.

623
00:30:52.865 --> 00:30:55.075
But that's gonna be up to you to decide,
obviously, right?

624
00:30:55.075 --> 00:30:57.455
It's gonna be a question of
how you choose to manage this.

625
00:30:57.455 --> 00:30:59.115
We'll leave the defaults in place.

626
00:31:00.305 --> 00:31:06.120
And we will decide if in the real
world we do this how long,

627
00:31:06.120 --> 00:31:08.460
based on months,
we want to be able to give a window.

628
00:31:08.460 --> 00:31:11.220
Or we can decide to immediately
expire a software update.

00:31:11.220 --> 00:31:13.878

expire, just cuz in our world,

00:31:13.878 --> 00:31:15.990
not really gonna matter

00:31:15.990 --> 00:31:19.600
It just makes for
a better set of choices for

us just in terms of

So, what we're gonna do now,

I'm not gonna bother with, or

I'm not gonna bother with going in and

But critical updates,

We have our options here.

We choose which one or ones we want.

In most cases you would

But, of course, then, you understand we're

00:31:51.567 --> 00:31:54.292

And we're just going to do security

00:31:58.653 --> 00:32:02.169

because obviously if we do a whole

00:32:02.169 --> 00:32:05.749

00:32:13.650 --> 00:32:17.070
So we're gonna streamline, just for

But in the real world here, we would

00:32:24.810 --> 00:32:27.820

And obviously Microsoft.

There's another one of those

00:50:37.525 --> 00:50:39.235
Now, compliance is kind of interesting.

1020
00:50:39.235 --> 00:50:43.600
And we'll give the picture a moment
just to kinda sit on the screen, and

1021
00:50:43.600 --> 00:50:45.690

1022
00:50:45.690 --> 00:50:48.210
before we talk about what's
actually happening there.

1023
00:50:48.210 --> 00:50:52.220
The idea with compliance and the idea with
patch management in general is twofold.

1024
00:50:52.220 --> 00:50:55.790
We need to build the catalog so that we
understand what updates are available.

1025
00:50:55.790 --> 00:50:59.677
But, then we have to decide what updates
are gonna necessarily be applied in our

1026
00:50:59.677 --> 00:51:04.029
environment, and what effectively is gonna
become part of our baseline going forward,

1027
00:51:04.029 --> 00:51:07.799
and which updates are just not important
at the time for whatever reason, and

1028
00:51:07.799 --> 00:51:09.446
we're not going to worry about.

1029
00:51:09.446 --> 00:51:13.234
And the ones that are important that
we want to apply, and ultimately

1030
00:51:13.234 --> 00:51:17.169
make part of a standard baseline for
our machines, have to be managed.

1031
00:51:17.169 --> 00:51:18.973
So, we have to think about testing them,

1032
00:51:18.973 --> 00:51:21.430
which always test an update
before we ever deploy it.

1033
00:51:21.430 --> 00:51:23.690
Never a good idea to put a patch out for
any reason,

1034
00:51:23.690 --> 00:51:26.680
under any circumstances,
unless we know what it's gonna do.

1035
00:51:26.680 --> 00:51:30.210
Not because we don't trust the vendor.

1036
00:51:30.210 --> 00:51:32.840
Because we should,
all kidding aside, right?

1037
00:51:32.840 --> 00:51:34.245
Hopefully, more often than not,

1038
00:51:34.245 --> 00:51:37.680
they do good work and we know that that
stuff will do what it's supposed to do.

1039
00:51:37.680 --> 00:51:40.010
But we don't know how it's gonna
operate in our environment.

1040
00:51:40.010 --> 00:51:44.350
It's not so much that the vendor itself,
or the vendor themselves, may or

1041
00:51:44.350 --> 00:51:45.610
may not be trustworthy.

1042
00:51:45.610 --> 00:51:49.750
The problem is that we may not know
how that patch is gonna behave,

1043
00:51:49.750 --> 00:51:52.530
because we have different
operating environments,

1044
00:51:52.530 --> 00:51:56.740
different system configurations,
different hardware, different software.

1045
00:51:56.740 --> 00:51:59.310
And we can't know just
off the top of our head,

1046
00:51:59.310 --> 00:52:03.200
without doing a little patch management,
QA testing, whether or

1047
00:52:03.200 --> 00:52:07.140
not that patch is gonna break anything,
and if so, what does it break, right?

1048
00:52:07.140 --> 00:52:09.410
So we need to think about that and
be aware of that.

1049
00:52:09.410 --> 00:52:13.517
So as a result, what's gonna happen
is we're going to test those patches,

1050
00:52:13.517 --> 00:52:16.620
figure out which ones, and
identify which ones we need.

1051
00:52:16.620 --> 00:52:17.550
Test those.

1052
00:52:17.550 --> 00:52:19.130
We're then going to say,
okay those look good.

1053
00:52:19.130 --> 00:52:21.570
Looks like we obviously
have a good match here.

1054
00:52:21.570 --> 00:52:23.470
Nothing breaks,
at least on the surface anyway.

1055
00:52:23.470 --> 00:52:24.535
It seems like everything is okay.

1056
00:52:24.535 --> 00:52:27.780
And then based on that,
we're going to set those patches up, and

1057
00:52:27.780 --> 00:52:29.410
get ready to identify them and

1058
00:52:29.410 --> 00:52:32.720
deploy them, because we have to
actually now decide to push those out.

1059
00:52:32.720 --> 00:52:36.632
But, before we can do any of that, what we
have to do is, or rather, as we do that,

1060
00:52:36.632 --> 00:52:37.270
I should say.

1061
00:52:37.270 --> 00:52:41.750
What we then have to do is figure out
which machines out there, which endpoints,

1062
00:52:41.750 --> 00:52:45.220
servers, desktops, etc.,
need which patches because

1063
00:52:45.220 --> 00:52:49.220
a new machine that's just been brought up,
may require a lot of patches.

1064
00:52:49.220 --> 00:52:51.030
Whereas a machine that's been
operating for a long time, and

1065
00:52:51.030 --> 00:52:54.255
has been getting patches,
may already have a lot of those, right?

1066
00:52:54.255 --> 00:52:55.180
>> Mm-hm.

1067
00:52:55.180 --> 00:52:56.920
>> Now, we, we may get smart.

1068
00:52:56.920 --> 00:53:00.899
We may say, well, what if we integrate
some of those patches into our baseline

1069
00:53:00.899 --> 00:53:02.665
image for our operating systems?

1070
00:53:02.665 --> 00:53:04.944
That way, as we deploy those new machines,

1071
00:53:04.944 --> 00:53:09.748
we don't have to worry about regressively
patching 20, 30, 40, 50 patches, and

1072
00:53:09.748 --> 00:53:14.026
back filling the machine because that
can present a security liability, right?

1073
00:53:14.026 --> 00:53:16.025
Because we bring up an unpatched machine.

1074
00:53:16.025 --> 00:53:18.765
And it may take several hours for
a mediator to cross the network.

1075
00:53:18.765 --> 00:53:21.045
So, I wanna make sure that we're aware
of that and we're thinking about that.

1076
00:53:21.045 --> 00:53:22.610
We have options in other words.

1077
00:53:22.610 --> 00:53:23.555
And we can look at,

1078
00:53:23.555 --> 00:53:27.100
and we will indeed talk about when
we do operating system deployment,

1079
00:53:27.100 --> 00:53:29.970
what that thought process would be if we
want to integrate some of those patches.

1080
00:53:29.970 --> 00:53:31.532
How can we do an update to the baseline?

1081
00:53:31.532 --> 00:53:33.271
We're not gonna really deal with that now,
but

1082
00:53:33.271 --> 00:53:34.806
just want to throw that out there for you.

00:53:34.806 --> 00:53:39.470
So, the idea would be now, when we
think about scanning for compliance,

1084
00:53:39.470 --> 00:53:43.250
is ultimately how are we going
to approach understanding?

1085
00:53:43.250 --> 00:53:47.350
Or approach, from our perspective,
figuring out

1086
00:53:47.350 --> 00:53:50.340
what it is that already exists out there
on the majority of our systems, and

1087
00:53:50.340 --> 00:53:51.980
where the gaps and
the deltas are gonna be.

1088
00:53:51.980 --> 00:53:56.060
And this is what this process that we're
diagramming here for you represents,

1089
00:53:56.060 --> 00:53:59.070
this idea of scanning the systems for
compliance, to see whether or

1090
00:53:59.070 --> 00:54:01.470
not they own these patches and
they're installed.

1091
00:54:01.470 --> 00:54:02.690
So, that's what we're gonna talk through.

00:54:02.690 --> 00:54:04.600
So, you'll see we have a laptop there.

00:54:04.600 --> 00:54:07.450
It says managed computer,
kind of in the middle, right there, and

1094
00:54:07.450 --> 00:54:10.153
we've got an arrow that's pointing
off to the WMI repository.

1095
00:54:10.153 --> 00:54:14.009
WMI repository is gonna
be on every machine.

1096
00:54:14.009 --> 00:54:17.545
The WMI repository allows us to
understand through the namespace,

1097
00:54:17.545 --> 00:54:21.820
what classes of objects, what attributes,
attribute classes we have.

1098
00:54:21.820 --> 00:54:23.970
And we've seen this when we did
an extension to the hardware

1099
00:54:23.970 --> 00:54:24.780
inventory, for instance.

1100
00:54:24.780 --> 00:54:28.560
We extended out and
looked at the WMI repository,

1101
00:54:28.560 --> 00:54:32.110
and actually created a couple of new

00:54:33.220 --> 00:54:35.980
And we actually can see in the real world,
every so

1103
00:54:35.980 --> 00:54:39.080
often, that there may be errors
associated with the WMI repository.

1104
00:54:39.080 --> 00:54:40.780
The namespace, right, for instance.

If we have a corrupt namespace,

we may try to install the client agent,
for instance, and

00:54:46.880 --> 00:54:49.850
have a problem because one of the failures
that can occur when we're installing

1108
00:54:49.850 --> 00:54:54.560

repository, the namespace is corrupt, or

1109
00:54:54.560 --> 00:54:59.450
unavailable for some reason we can not

00:54:59.450 --> 00:55:00.820
And so what can happen is,

00:55:00.820 --> 00:55:04.420
if we see that, it's actually a fairly

1112
00:55:04.420 --> 00:55:07.730
But you'll get an error code,
800 something or other,

1113
00:55:07.730 --> 00:55:08.990
I forget, what
>> [INAUDIBLE]

1114
00:55:08.990 --> 00:55:10.080
>> Something or other.

1115
00:55:10.080 --> 00:55:12.600
But whatever the error code is,
I forget the exact one, but

00:55:12.600 --> 00:55:15.500
you'll get one of two error codes
that normally will come up.

1117
00:55:15.500 --> 00:55:16.170
And you'll simply,

00:55:16.170 --> 00:55:18.880
the easiest way is to just go out and
Google for that error code.

1119
00:55:18.880 --> 00:55:23.130
But you'll basically, what you need to do

1120

You'll effectively create a new one and

1121
00:55:26.560 --> 00:55:28.679
And that will, more often than not,
fix the problem.

1122
00:55:28.679 --> 00:55:31.809
So, one of those things that can really
just happen in the real world, and

1123
00:55:31.809 --> 00:55:35.059
if you happen to come across that,
at least you'll know how to deal with it.

00:55:35.059 --> 00:55:37.372
But here we're checking for the WMI,

1125
00:55:37.372 --> 00:55:40.920
or with the WMI repository to

In addition, what we have to do is,

Those go down to the WSUS database, right?

Because we're talking to the WSUS server.

That's going down into

Remember, the management point is their

That is then going to affect where

Site server's talking
to the site database.

1141
00:56:19.450 --> 00:56:20.370
And, also, potentially,

1142
00:56:20.370 --> 00:56:23.240
is gonna be generating reports
on the status of the client.

1143
00:56:23.240 --> 00:56:26.170
So we've got a lot of communication
activity going on here,

1144
00:56:26.170 --> 00:56:27.540
lot of different things happening.

1145
00:56:29.090 --> 00:56:31.840
And so,
we wanna make sure we're aware of that.

1146
00:56:31.840 --> 00:56:39.610
The idea here is that we want to figure
out what is on that managed computer.

1147
00:56:39.610 --> 00:56:43.030
And then, based on what is currently
there versus what is being advertised or

1148
00:56:43.030 --> 00:56:48.900
available through the WSUS database
through the software update feature.

1149
00:56:48.900 --> 00:56:51.640
We then wanna figure out what
patches we are gonna need to apply.

1150
00:56:51.640 --> 00:56:54.660
So we're effectively looking to
see what our current baseline is.

1151
00:56:54.660 --> 00:56:58.240
Creating an effected delta,
a gap analysis in our mind.

1152
00:56:58.240 --> 00:57:01.300
And then, we can look at and then decide
which patches we're gonna need and

1153
00:57:01.300 --> 00:57:02.050
download those.

1154
00:57:02.050 --> 00:57:05.510
So this is what we're effectively gonna
be doing here, and trying to figure out.

1155
00:57:05.510 --> 00:57:09.015
So this is the process that we
are engaging in and looking at.

1156
00:57:09.015 --> 00:57:13.170
And so, we just wanna make sure
that we are thinking about that.

1157
00:57:13.170 --> 00:57:16.840
And taking a look and seeing what is
taking place is really helping us

1158
00:57:16.840 --> 00:57:20.870
to understand what patches
will be available, and

1159
00:57:20.870 --> 00:57:22.920
which ones may ultimately
wind up getting deployed.

1160
00:57:22.920 --> 00:57:26.180
So this is what scanning for
compliance is gonna look like.

1161
00:57:26.180 --> 00:57:28.440
We have different compliance states,
by the way.

1162
00:57:28.440 --> 00:57:29.180
We have a list of them.

1163
00:57:29.180 --> 00:57:30.480
We'll quickly show you what they are.

1164
00:57:30.480 --> 00:57:32.120
I believe if we scroll
down we should get those.

1165
00:57:32.120 --> 00:57:32.790
There we go.

1166
00:57:32.790 --> 00:57:37.680
So compliance states include required,
installed, not required, and unknown.

1167
00:57:37.680 --> 00:57:42.760
And the idea with compliance states is
when we look, if we have a required state,

1168
00:57:42.760 --> 00:57:46.040
that's a patch that is going
to have to be there, right?

1169
00:57:46.040 --> 00:57:47.580
So we need to install that.

1170
00:57:47.580 --> 00:57:49.400
If we installed, it's already there.

1171
00:57:49.400 --> 00:57:51.010
Not required, optional.

1172
00:57:51.010 --> 00:57:52.490
Unknown, we have no way of knowing.

1173
00:57:52.490 --> 00:57:54.935
So we haven't scanned or
just not sure what that is.

1174
00:57:54.935 --> 00:57:56.635
So we can look at those different states,
and

1175
00:57:56.635 --> 00:57:59.235
then as a result of understanding
the meaning of them,

1176
00:57:59.235 --> 00:58:03.905
really figure out exactly what is going
on, path by path, machine by machine.

1177
00:58:03.905 --> 00:58:07.845
We have a software update deployment
process, I think, if I'm not mistaken.

1178
00:58:07.845 --> 00:58:10.785
A graphic, and then we'll take a look
what the actual process looks like.

1179
00:58:10.785 --> 00:58:15.490
So what this graphic is gonna represent
for us is the ability to be able to go out

1180
00:58:15.490 --> 00:58:20.690
and to effectively show you how
we're gonna deploy software updates.

1181
00:58:20.690 --> 00:58:22.640
We're starting over with,
at the bottom there,

1182
00:58:22.640 --> 00:58:26.120
the administrative console,
the management point, distribution point.

1183
00:58:26.120 --> 00:58:28.230
We see all that functionality
on the site server.

1184
00:58:28.230 --> 00:58:32.900
So, the site server is going to,
you'll remember, be that local or

1185
00:58:32.900 --> 00:58:37.080
that focus point of information,
information management coordination.

1186
00:58:37.080 --> 00:58:38.590
All that's taking place there.

1187
00:58:38.590 --> 00:58:42.410
And what we see at the site server, up
above, from the console list, is that we

1188
00:58:42.410 --> 00:58:46.520
see that it's going up and talking to
the software update local source, or

1189
00:58:46.520 --> 00:58:50.470
the software update point, up at the top,
which is over to the left talking to

1190
00:58:50.470 --> 00:58:54.360
Microsoft Update pulling in all
those patches as we talked about.

1191
00:58:54.360 --> 00:58:56.390
Off to the right there, we have
a one way arrow that that goes up to

1192
00:58:56.390 --> 00:58:59.860
the site database to check on
the status and update information.

1193
00:58:59.860 --> 00:59:02.920
We have a manage computer
down on the left hand side.

1194
00:59:02.920 --> 00:59:07.170
And that computer's talking with the
management point, the distribution point,

1195
00:59:07.170 --> 00:59:10.720
talking with the administrative console,
or rather the administrative console is

1196
00:59:10.720 --> 00:59:13.500
talking to those other roles and
showing us what's going on.

1197
00:59:14.600 --> 00:59:17.410
And so, we'll download patches
from Microsoft Update.

1198
00:59:17.410 --> 00:59:18.940
We'll check the bin, if you will,

1199
00:59:18.940 --> 00:59:21.140
make sure that they
are available in the console.

1200
00:59:21.140 --> 00:59:24.460
And then, we will go ahead and
once we choose which packages we want to

1201
00:59:24.460 --> 00:59:29.230
deploy and create our deployment solution
to do that, we'll be able to go in and

1202
00:59:29.230 --> 00:59:33.870
then be able to start to see those
patches showing up in the console,

1203
00:59:33.870 --> 00:59:35.970
and then be able to start deploying them.

1204
00:59:35.970 --> 00:59:38.790
And so, this process is
actually fairly straightforward

1205
00:59:38.790 --> 00:59:40.390
once the patches are available.

1206
00:59:40.390 --> 00:59:42.770
And we simply say, hey,
I want these five patches.

1207
00:59:42.770 --> 00:59:46.640
Package them up and then deploy them as if
they were just a normal piece of software.

1208
00:59:46.640 --> 00:59:48.210
Because, effectively,
that's what we're doing.

1209
00:59:48.210 --> 00:59:51.640
We're deploying packages just using the
software deployment model, the way we did

1210
00:59:51.640 --> 00:59:55.970
with applications and packages as we
walked through and discussed all that.

1211
00:59:55.970 --> 00:59:59.510
So, deploying software updates to client
computers is fairly straightforward.

1212
00:59:59.510 --> 01:00:02.360
We have a list that will just walk us
through the high level steps here.

1213
01:00:02.360 --> 01:00:04.515
Provide the name and target collection.

1214
01:00:04.515 --> 01:00:09.370
So what are we gonna call
the deployment package?

1215
01:00:09.370 --> 01:00:11.630
Security update one or whatever.

1216
01:00:11.630 --> 01:00:12.860
What's our target collection?

1217
01:00:12.860 --> 01:00:15.550
All systems or
whatever we may want to call it.

1218
01:00:15.550 --> 01:00:18.540
Specify the type of deployment required or
available.

1219
01:00:18.540 --> 01:00:20.370
Required is obviously gonna be mandatory.

1220
01:00:20.370 --> 01:00:21.640
Available is optional.

1221
01:00:21.640 --> 01:00:23.860
Right?
So, we can choose to opt in on that.

1222
01:00:23.860 --> 01:00:25.210
Specify the schedule.

1223
01:00:25.210 --> 01:00:29.510
I want this available starting on
Tuesday afternoon at 5 PM or whatever.

1224
01:00:29.510 --> 01:00:31.990
Configure user notifications and
restart behavior.

1225
01:00:31.990 --> 01:00:34.540
Are we gonna tell users
we're doing patching?

1226
01:00:34.540 --> 01:00:36.160
Are we gonna tell them 20 minutes out?

1227
01:00:36.160 --> 01:00:38.390
Are we gonna tell them as we're doing it?

1228
01:00:38.390 --> 01:00:40.080
And then,
are we gonna automatically restart?

1229
01:00:40.080 --> 01:00:41.200
Are we gonna let them opt out?

1230
01:00:41.200 --> 01:00:42.820
If so, for how long.

1231
01:00:42.820 --> 01:00:45.730
We do have that opt-out
warning that comes up with

1232
01:00:45.730 --> 01:00:49.510
automatic updates when we do it through
the local client on the end point.

1233
01:00:49.510 --> 01:00:50.770
So we can do that.

1234
01:00:50.770 --> 01:00:52.130
Configure alert settings.

1235
01:00:52.130 --> 01:00:53.950
What kind of alerts may get generated.

1236
01:00:53.950 --> 01:00:57.480
Specify installation behavior based
on boundary group association and

1237
01:00:57.480 --> 01:00:58.520
content availability.

1238
01:00:58.520 --> 01:01:01.940
Remember, the need to
have boundary groups and

1239
01:01:01.940 --> 01:01:03.790
the use of boundary
groups is very important.

1240
01:01:03.790 --> 01:01:05.270
We've talked about them before.

1241
01:01:05.270 --> 01:01:08.080
The boundary group is really just
the administrative container for

1242
01:01:08.080 --> 01:01:09.000
the boundaries.

1243
01:01:09.000 --> 01:01:10.810
That just helps us to manage them.

1244
01:01:10.810 --> 01:01:12.580
But the boundaries themselves, remember,

1245
01:01:12.580 --> 01:01:17.890
based on either IPV4 address
range on subnet, on IPV6 prefix,

1246
01:01:17.890 --> 01:01:21.927
and or active directory site boundaries
are going to let us associate machines.

1247
01:01:21.927 --> 01:01:24.050
End points manage clients.

1248
01:01:24.050 --> 01:01:26.460
With one or more of those boundaries
set up, they're part of that group, and

1249
01:01:26.460 --> 01:01:28.010
associated with that site server.

1250
01:01:28.010 --> 01:01:30.659
And then, they can leverage this
functionality from within those

1251
01:01:30.659 --> 01:01:31.280
site servers.

1252
01:01:31.280 --> 01:01:33.890
So, want to make sure we know
that we have to associate them

1253
01:01:33.890 --> 01:01:35.915
with that boundary group in order
to be able to figure that out.

1254
01:01:35.915 --> 01:01:36.735
All right.

1255
01:01:36.735 --> 01:01:38.785
So, we've gone through, at that point,

1256
01:01:38.785 --> 01:01:41.725
all the stuff that we wanted to at
least set up and tee up ahead of time.

1257
01:01:41.725 --> 01:01:46.115
I'm gonna take a look here real quick, see
if we have our updates coming back down.

1258
01:01:46.115 --> 01:01:47.895
So give me just a second to do that.

1259
01:01:47.895 --> 01:01:49.030
So far, I haven't seen any.

1260
01:01:49.030 --> 01:01:51.519
I've snuck a peek once or
twice while we've been talking.

1261
01:01:52.560 --> 01:01:56.550
But, as I did say, this process can take a
fair amount of time depending on the speed

1262
01:01:56.550 --> 01:01:57.860
of the Internet connection.

1263
01:01:57.860 --> 01:01:59.920
And I'm not seeing any
updates showing up yet.

1264
01:01:59.920 --> 01:02:03.570
So what we're gonna do, I think,
is maybe wrap up this episode here.

1265
01:02:03.570 --> 01:02:04.210
We'll come back and

1266
01:02:04.210 --> 01:02:07.380
we'll do another one, just pick up
where the updates have come in.

1267
01:02:07.380 --> 01:02:09.870
That way, we're not stuck waiting and

1268
01:02:09.870 --> 01:02:12.830
talking to you about what I read
in the newspaper yesterday,

1269
01:02:12.830 --> 01:02:16.610
how exciting that was, and what I had for
breakfast this morning just to kill time.

1270
01:02:16.610 --> 01:02:18.920
But rather, we'll go, I mean,
we could do that, if you'd like.

1271
01:02:18.920 --> 01:02:19.495
>> [CROSSTALK] interesting.

1272
01:02:19.495 --> 01:02:21.586
>> Had a cool breakfast,
it actually was really neat.

1273
01:02:21.586 --> 01:02:23.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> But what I think would make more sense,

1274
01:02:23.320 --> 01:02:26.510
all kidding aside, is we'll go ahead and
we'll give you back a little bit of time,

1275
01:02:26.510 --> 01:02:27.090
let you go and

1276
01:02:27.090 --> 01:02:30.385
maybe do some stuff, get organized
>> Get a cup of coffee.

1277
01:02:30.385 --> 01:02:33.215
Do whatever you need to do to come
back and be fresh and focused.

1278
01:02:33.215 --> 01:02:36.475
As soon as we get these updates
synced up in the system here,

1279
01:02:36.475 --> 01:02:37.975
we'll be able to jump right back in.

1280
01:02:37.975 --> 01:02:39.875
We'll pick up the demo from that point.

1281
01:02:39.875 --> 01:02:40.985
We'll be able to, then, run through and

1282
01:02:40.985 --> 01:02:42.960
show you how to do
the deployment of the package.

1283
01:02:42.960 --> 01:02:45.550
And then we'll finish up
with this discussion.

1284
01:02:45.550 --> 01:02:46.640
>> Sounds like a plan, Adam.

1285
01:02:46.640 --> 01:02:47.860
Again, another great episode.

1286
01:02:47.860 --> 01:02:51.000
We got to look at at least the first
part of getting all this set up so

1287
01:02:51.000 --> 01:02:54.540
we can deploy those software updates
out to our clients and our enterprise.

1288
01:02:54.540 --> 01:02:56.770
And, as Adam told you,
there's more to come.

1289
01:02:56.770 --> 01:02:59.580
We've just gotta wait for everything
to kind of start synchronizing so

1290
01:02:59.580 --> 01:03:02.390
we can get in there and
actually perform those next steps.

1291
01:03:02.390 --> 01:03:03.460
So, we'll step away.

1292
01:03:03.460 --> 01:03:04.160
We'll take a break.

1293
01:03:04.160 --> 01:03:05.180
We'll wrap this one up.

1294
01:03:05.180 --> 01:03:08.090
Remember, if you guys wanna see
one of Adam's classes live,

1295
01:03:08.090 --> 01:03:11.535
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

1296
01:03:11.535 --> 01:03:13.645
Signing off for this one,
I'm Mike Roderick.

1297
01:03:13.645 --> 01:03:15.355
>> I'm patiently waiting for updates.

1298
01:03:15.355 --> 01:03:17.176
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

1299
01:03:17.176 --> 01:03:23.520
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike continue to look at integrating WSUS and SCCM 2012 R2. They go through the process of packaging an update for deployment. They also demonstrate how to create an automatic deployment rule.
episodes.title: Software Updates Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.921 --> 00:00:15.255
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.255 --> 00:00:16.505
I'm your host, Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:16.505 --> 00:00:20.680
Today we're doing our
SCCM 2012 R2 content.

5
00:00:20.680 --> 00:00:23.280
And specifically we're
looking at software updates.

6
00:00:23.280 --> 00:00:25.450
So this is a part two actually.

7
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:29.130
We've already got everything set up and
we were getting some updates synchronized

8
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:31.200
with Microsoft and
that takes a little bit of time.

9
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:34.480
So we took a little break and
now we're gonna dive right back into it.

10
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:36.210
And of course here with me is Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:37.040
How's it going, Adam?

12
00:00:37.040 --> 00:00:37.720
>> Good, good.

13
00:00:37.720 --> 00:00:39.270
So we broke the internet but

14
00:00:39.270 --> 00:00:41.890
we fixed it so
now we can get back to what we were doing.

15
00:00:41.890 --> 00:00:47.940
So I did mention at the ending of
our first episode in this series,

16
00:00:47.940 --> 00:00:50.890
the part one if you will, to make that
less complicated for those of you that

17
00:00:50.890 --> 00:00:56.170
are keeping track, that we had a bit
of a problem with the synchronization.

18
00:00:56.170 --> 00:00:56.700
I fixed it.

19
00:00:56.700 --> 00:00:58.840
We were just waiting on
everything to finish up.

20
00:00:58.840 --> 00:00:59.410
It has.

21
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:00.370
We have the catalog built.

22
00:01:00.370 --> 00:01:02.000
We'll jump back in there in a second.

23
00:01:02.000 --> 00:01:06.090
Just wanted to quickly give you a heads up
for the real world, that if this occurs,

24
00:01:06.090 --> 00:01:08.480
you'll at least have a sense of
how to deal with it there as well.

25
00:01:08.480 --> 00:01:12.290
So, we were demoing, and as we were
going through, I spent some time and

26
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:15.470
showed you that we were
using a proxy server.

27
00:01:15.470 --> 00:01:17.730
We don't normally do that
unless we have a reason to,

28
00:01:17.730 --> 00:01:20.640
meaning that we are using
proxies in the enterprise.

29
00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:24.599
And as a result of that, we have to
specify what that proxy will be and

30
00:01:24.599 --> 00:01:27.446
put in the address,
put in the connection port,

31
00:01:27.446 --> 00:01:30.796
if there is alternate port mapping for
it, and the name.

32
00:01:30.796 --> 00:01:33.400
And so we put all that in
on one of the two screens.

33
00:01:33.400 --> 00:01:38.970
When we went to verify the credentials,
partially my fault, partially the fault

34
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:43.890
of the organizational elements that
set up our lab environment for

35
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:48.900
us in the sense that I did not realize
that they had not done the proxy

36
00:01:48.900 --> 00:01:52.220
mapping and had it set up so that we
would be able to find it automatically.

37
00:01:52.220 --> 00:01:55.780
So I did not bother to verify it,
which again, was my fault.

38
00:01:55.780 --> 00:01:58.505
I should not have assumed that it would
be there automatically and it would work.

39
00:01:58.505 --> 00:02:02.012
So because I didn't verify the connection
we were not able to go out and

40
00:02:02.012 --> 00:02:04.430
connect automatically the first time.

41
00:02:04.430 --> 00:02:06.240
The sync failed, in other words.

42
00:02:06.240 --> 00:02:09.020
When we were sitting and talking with you,
keeping an eye on it here,

43
00:02:09.020 --> 00:02:12.200
as we looked at it we went back and
saw that nothing had happened.

44
00:02:12.200 --> 00:02:15.090
That's why we decided to take the break,
pause for a few minutes,

45
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:16.742
check on what was going
on behind the scenes.

46
00:02:16.742 --> 00:02:22.820
Went and looked at the status of the sync
manager, took a look at the logs,

47
00:02:22.820 --> 00:02:26.810
queried, found out that we did indeed have
a failure, went back, figured out why.

48
00:02:26.810 --> 00:02:30.540
We did not have the right credential and
port mapping in for the proxy.

49
00:02:30.540 --> 00:02:31.870
So it was simple enough to go back and

50
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:34.350
fix that once we diagnosed
what the problem was.

51
00:02:34.350 --> 00:02:37.810
But this can happen if you're not
configuring the proxy the right way.

52
00:02:37.810 --> 00:02:40.080
And so I just want to quickly
show you as we get started again,

53
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:42.600
we're gonna go back into my
machine here in a second,

54
00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:45.560
wanna show you just where I went and
what I did to see that.

55
00:02:45.560 --> 00:02:46.840
So that way if you ever have a problem,

56
00:02:46.840 --> 00:02:48.910
you'll at least have a sense
of what to do to fix it.

57
00:02:48.910 --> 00:02:52.450
And then we'll jump back in, cuz now
the catalog is built, we have our updates

58
00:02:52.450 --> 00:02:55.050
sitting here, and we'll be able to
pick back up where we left off.

59
00:02:55.050 --> 00:02:58.310
We'll choose an update,
we'll go ahead and we will highlight one,

60
00:02:58.310 --> 00:03:02.410
we'll talk about how to create a software
update group, and then we'll go in and

61
00:03:02.410 --> 00:03:04.440
we'll package it up and
get ready to deploy it.

62
00:03:04.440 --> 00:03:08.460
So if we can go to full screen on that,
so that we can see the entire console,

63
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:12.120
what I'm gonna do is just quickly take
you in to the monitoring workspace,

64
00:03:12.120 --> 00:03:14.130
we'll switch the focus here for
just a moment.

65
00:03:14.130 --> 00:03:15.680

00:38:41.660 --> 00:38:43.520

00:38:43.520 --> 00:38:48.166
Right, we've talked about the value

00:38:48.166 --> 00:38:51.838
boundaries that are used are going
to be set up, and remember,

785
00:38:51.838 --> 00:38:56.986
automatically generated and managed by the
active directory configuration process.

786
00:38:56.986 --> 00:39:01.956
That when we do an install and
add domains and name spaces in,

787
00:39:01.956 --> 00:39:08.694
will then populate those boundaries but
we have the topology site ITSG I believe.

788
00:39:08.694 --> 00:39:09.733
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> The Inter-Site Topology [CROSSTALK]

789
00:39:09.733 --> 00:39:10.810
Replication Site Generator,
whatever it's called.

00:39:10.810 --> 00:39:14.100
I think it's called ITSG if I

791
00:39:14.100 --> 00:39:18.750
But the automation process that
goes on under the hood between

792
00:39:18.750 --> 00:39:22.110
the domain controllers which
are talking to each other and

793
00:39:22.110 --> 00:39:23.870
trying to figure out who's where.

794
00:39:23.870 --> 00:39:29.840
And then ultimately the process of
setting all of those site connections up.

795
00:39:29.840 --> 00:39:32.825
Oh, it's
the Inter-Site Topology Generator, ISTG.

796
00:39:32.825 --> 00:39:35.400
Inter-Site Topology Generator
is what it's called.

797
00:39:36.510 --> 00:39:39.460
And so what happens is we
automatically monitor that.

798
00:39:39.460 --> 00:39:43.780
And then there's an automatic active
directory replication monitor, ReptoMon,

799
00:39:43.780 --> 00:39:45.710
that runs as well behind the scenes and

800
00:39:45.710 --> 00:39:49.240
is managing that whole process
to set up AV replication.

00:39:49.240 --> 00:39:51.212
Remember, we piggy back on top of that.

00:39:51.212 --> 00:39:55.480
We know when those site connectors are
going in and are using good bandwidth or

803
00:39:55.480 --> 00:40:00.090
are not using good bandwidth in the sense
that they're below a certain threshold.

804
00:40:00.090 --> 00:40:03.430
Now we can play with those settings,
we actually can modify them.

805
00:40:03.430 --> 00:40:08.443
So we can manually adjust what
a minimum bandwidth threshold is.

806
00:40:08.443 --> 00:40:11.850
By default, if we are below,

807
00:40:11.850 --> 00:40:16.410
I believe it is still 128k,
it used to be 128k.

808
00:40:16.410 --> 00:40:21.040
Maybe it'd be 64k now cuz we're optimized
a lot better today than we used to be.

809
00:40:21.040 --> 00:40:25.620
But I believe it's somewhere around 128k,
to maybe as low as 50k,

810
00:40:25.620 --> 00:40:28.710
that is the default on
the bandwidth on the connection.

811
00:40:28.710 --> 00:40:31.750
If we're at that level, or above,

812
00:40:31.750 --> 00:40:33.838
we are considered to have
good reliable bandwidth.

813
00:40:33.838 --> 00:40:37.850
If we are below that level, then the
system says, oh this is a bad connection,

814
00:40:37.850 --> 00:40:41.140
it is low speed and
then we mark the boundary as such.

815
00:40:41.140 --> 00:40:45.520
So we're playing off that whole process
on the AD side with the topology site

816
00:40:45.520 --> 00:40:49.220
generator and the measurement of
the connectivity on that link.

817
00:40:49.220 --> 00:40:52.560
Now, the measurement is done

00:40:52.560 --> 00:40:56.130
There's an algorithm it's used to run to
figure out exactly how much bandwidth we

819
00:40:56.130 --> 00:40:59.285

and what that looks like, and

820
00:40:59.285 --> 00:41:03.140
that's part of that replication monitor,
auto generation process that takes place.

00:41:03.140 --> 00:41:05.270
So we're not really involved in that but

00:41:05.270 --> 00:41:09.740
we can hard code the minimum threshold

Normally we set that to

512K but that's up to us based on

00:42:21.180 --> 00:42:25.040

a firewall, may involve several hops,

00:42:28.420 --> 00:42:30.590

00:42:30.590 --> 00:42:33.990
So we can control that behavior as well,
do not install software updates or

849

content source if it's not available.

00:42:38.030 --> 00:42:41.980

00:42:41.980 --> 00:42:43.200

00:42:57.150 --> 00:42:57.670

it's like having a dog, right?

1637
01:19:22.260 --> 01:19:24.062
All they wanna do is just please you, so

1638
01:19:24.062 --> 01:19:27.760
they will go out of their way to make
sure, but they then wanna tell you

1639
01:19:27.760 --> 01:19:31.380
what they did so that you're happy and you
give them props for doing the right thing.

1640
01:19:31.380 --> 01:19:33.140
So they did it.

1641
01:19:33.140 --> 01:19:35.456
Nice client, good client, good client.

1642
01:19:35.456 --> 01:19:36.700
Here's a treat.

1643
01:19:36.700 --> 01:19:38.189
And so they did it and
then they called me.

1644
01:19:39.210 --> 01:19:42.110
Not before they did it, which would
have actually been the right thing to do

1645
01:19:42.110 --> 01:19:43.504
because I could've stopped them.

1646
01:19:43.504 --> 01:19:46.124
They did it then they called
me afterwards, all excited,

1647
01:19:46.124 --> 01:19:47.838
you'll never guess what we just did.

1648
01:19:47.838 --> 01:19:48.587
We fixed a problem.

1649
01:19:48.587 --> 01:19:50.046
Let me tell you what we did.

1650
01:19:50.046 --> 01:19:52.560
And they proceed to tell me
they uninstalled the roll, and

1651
01:19:52.560 --> 01:19:53.545
then reinstalled it.

1652
01:19:53.545 --> 01:19:54.875
This is in production.

1653
01:19:54.875 --> 01:19:57.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now thankfully uninstalling

1654
01:19:57.070 --> 01:19:59.670
the software update roll is not the end
of the world because you don't really

1655
01:19:59.670 --> 01:20:02.485
affect anything in
production that's going on.

1656
01:20:02.485 --> 01:20:04.725
Other than the patch
management capabilities.

1657
01:20:04.725 --> 01:20:08.098
You're not uninstalling the server,
but you are blowing out the catalog.

1658
01:20:08.098 --> 01:20:08.955
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

1659
01:20:08.955 --> 01:20:10.155
>> So one of the problems is you

1660
01:20:10.155 --> 01:20:10.915
gotta rebuild that.

1661
01:20:10.915 --> 01:20:12.045
But it's not the end of the world.

1662
01:20:12.045 --> 01:20:13.575
It takes a little time.

1663
01:20:13.575 --> 01:20:15.235
It's not the worst thing you can do.

1664
01:20:15.235 --> 01:20:16.235
But they called me.

1665
01:20:17.390 --> 01:20:19.835
And they said hey so this is what
the problem was, this is what we did.

1666
01:20:19.835 --> 01:20:24.680
Cuz you've told us hey,
try to be a little bit forward thinking,

1667
01:20:24.680 --> 01:20:27.240
do a little diagnosis,
figure stuff out, work on your run.

1668
01:20:27.240 --> 01:20:29.000
If we can't figure it out call you.

1669

I said yeah but you're suppose to
ask before you do stuff, right.

1670
01:20:31.970 --> 01:20:36.610
I want you to be self sufficient,
that's good do that but ask first.

1671
01:20:36.610 --> 01:20:38.660
Would have saved you a lot of time and
trouble.

1672
01:20:38.660 --> 01:20:39.940
Luckily they didn't damage anything,

1673
01:20:39.940 --> 01:20:42.320
it just took a little bit of
time to rebuild everything.

1674
01:20:42.320 --> 01:20:45.911
But they uninstalled and sure enough, you
run the wizard again, all those settings

1675
01:20:45.911 --> 01:20:49.060
are available, but you could've fixed
the problem just by knowing where to go.

1676
01:20:49.060 --> 01:20:50.295
>> Right.
>> In the first place, right?

1677
01:20:50.295 --> 01:20:53.340
So, sometimes it's good to be out
on that limb and thinking about it.

1678
01:20:53.340 --> 01:20:56.130
Sometimes when you're sawing the limb
as you're looking back at the tree and

you're on the wrong side of it,
you may want to pause momentarily and

1681
01:21:03.270 --> 01:21:05.380
All right, so

Want to just wrap up a couple of

That we promised you about doing
automatic update deployment rules and

then we are going to wrap up this episode.

1686
01:21:17.025 --> 01:21:17.770
>> Mm-hm.

1687
01:21:17.770 --> 01:21:19.670
>> Because I have nothing left to say.

1688
01:21:19.670 --> 01:21:22.780
Which is not very common and
does not happen very often.

1689
01:21:22.780 --> 01:21:25.620
All right, so what is the process for
creating an automatic deployment rule?

1690
01:21:25.620 --> 01:21:26.940
You see we've documented this for you.

01:21:26.940 --> 01:21:29.830
Now we just ran through this in
the wizard, you saw me do this.

1692
01:21:29.830 --> 01:21:32.810
But as we always try to do when

1693
01:21:32.810 --> 01:21:35.420
Trying to summarize that and
give you some steps that you can rely on.

1694
01:21:35.420 --> 01:21:36.630
You can look at.

1695
01:21:36.630 --> 01:21:38.890
You can use as you're
studying as reference.

1696
01:21:38.890 --> 01:21:39.390
Right?
>> Right.

1697
01:21:39.390 --> 01:21:40.210
>> So that way it's always

1698
01:21:40.210 --> 01:21:41.290
a good thing to do that.

1699
01:21:41.290 --> 01:21:44.510
So you'll see here we have the steps
that we more or less followed and

1700
01:21:44.510 --> 01:21:45.910
the wizard laid out for you.

1701
01:21:45.910 --> 01:21:46.990
So you can take a look at them.

1702
01:21:46.990 --> 01:21:49.630
So you'll just want to make
sure you're aware of that.

1703
01:21:49.630 --> 01:21:51.900
And that you have a sense of what we did.

1704
01:21:51.900 --> 01:21:54.810
Let's go ahead and let's talk,
or let's rather not talk.

1705
01:21:54.810 --> 01:21:59.250
But let's move to the monitoring
deployment of software updates.

1706
01:21:59.250 --> 01:22:01.600
I think we have some status
messages we put up there as well,

1707
01:22:01.600 --> 01:22:02.350
if I remember correctly.

1708
01:22:02.350 --> 01:22:02.930
Right?

1709
01:22:02.930 --> 01:22:04.780
Deploy software,
you think going the other way.

1710
01:22:04.780 --> 01:22:05.500
There you go, yeah.

1711
01:22:05.500 --> 01:22:06.540
It's not up, it must be down.

1712
01:22:06.540 --> 01:22:07.389
>> It must be.
[LAUGH]

1713
01:22:07.389 --> 01:22:08.600
>> That's right, it must be down.

1714
01:22:09.810 --> 01:22:13.420
So when we are monitoring software update
deployments, and I showed you this,

1715
01:22:13.420 --> 01:22:15.110
we saw that it was already
green when it was there.

1716
01:22:15.110 --> 01:22:16.790
But we do have the monitoring workspace,

01:22:16.790 --> 01:22:19.600
that's what I showed you where the pie

1718
01:22:19.600 --> 01:22:21.320
Said oh, success.

1719

We have status messages and alerts which

1722
01:22:33.685 --> 01:22:35.530
We took a look at that so you saw that.

1723
01:22:35.530 --> 01:22:37.760
And we have alerts as well,
so these are valuable.

1724
01:22:37.760 --> 01:22:40.190
We do have some reports that
are specific to software updates,

1725
01:22:40.190 --> 01:22:42.750
thought we'd just give you
a preview of what those are.

1726
01:22:42.750 --> 01:22:44.090
There's a bunch of different ones there.

1727

We can do compliance,
deployment management,

1728
01:22:46.320 --> 01:22:50.060
deployment states, scanning and/or

1729

And then we have a couple of log files for

one of which came in handy for

1731
01:22:54.450 --> 01:22:55.960
>> Yes, it did.
>> Because I talked to you about that and

01:22:55.960 --> 01:22:57.460
we actually took a look at that.

But we do have WCM log as you can see and

1734
01:23:03.240 --> 01:23:06.690
We have the software update
point which is the WSUS server.

01:23:06.690 --> 01:23:11.770
We could see that, that's WSUSctrl.log,

And we have some things going on, but

Maybe there's a problem with

We could take a look at the five

ScanAgent.log, WUA update handler.log,
which is a Windows update agent handler,

1742
01:23:28.665 --> 01:23:32.430
Windows update, updates handler,
and/or updateStore.log.

1743
01:23:32.430 --> 01:23:36.530
So we just want to make sure
we're aware of that and

1744
01:23:36.530 --> 01:23:38.620
we have that in the back of our mind.

1745
01:23:38.620 --> 01:23:41.590
Remember, and I will remind you again,
just while we're finishing up on this

1746
01:23:41.590 --> 01:23:44.970
screen, that the reason we're throwing

1747
01:23:44.970 --> 01:23:45.590
you is twofold.

1748
01:23:45.590 --> 01:23:48.780
Number one, because you do obviously
wanna know that they exist and

1749
01:23:48.780 --> 01:23:49.410
they are valuable.

1750
01:23:49.410 --> 01:23:52.550
And in this case,
in the real troubleshooting scenario

1751
01:23:52.550 --> 01:23:56.720
that we went through, they actually proved
to be invaluable to solving the problem.

1752
01:23:56.720 --> 01:23:59.630
But in addition, in the real worlds
you need to know where these are if

1753
01:23:59.630 --> 01:24:02.990
you have an issue and you may be
asked about them at some point and so

1754
01:24:02.990 --> 01:24:05.740
you do have to have knowledge

1755
01:24:05.740 --> 01:24:08.430
>> Very good.
All right Adam, fantastic episode.

1756
01:24:08.430 --> 01:24:13.500
Great hands on look at, at the entire
process of doing our software updates and

1757
01:24:13.500 --> 01:24:15.140
even some troubleshooting.

1758
01:24:15.140 --> 01:24:18.800
I always say that sometimes when things go
wrong that's when you learn the most cuz

1759
01:24:18.800 --> 01:24:21.240
you really get to dive in there and
see what the heck is going on.

1760
01:24:21.240 --> 01:24:24.325
And the behind the scenes tour of

1761

we don't have to uninstall the rule
to get those settings back.

1762
01:24:27.800 --> 01:24:28.705
Always handy.

1763

Thanks for that Adam, we appreciate that.

1764

Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about using SCCM 2012 R2 to managing compliance. They look at creating and importing configuration items. Then they create and apply a configuration baseline. They also talk about the remediation process.
episodes.title: Managing Compliance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.379 --> 00:00:10.379
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.708 --> 00:00:15.401
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.401 --> 00:00:16.841
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.841 --> 00:00:22.262
Today we're doing our system center
configuration manager 2012 R2 content.

5
00:00:22.262 --> 00:00:26.329
In this episode we're gonna be looking
at Managing compliance when it comes to

6
00:00:26.329 --> 00:00:28.682
compliance settings compliance profiles.

7
00:00:28.682 --> 00:00:30.005
Wait did I get that right?

8
00:00:30.005 --> 00:00:32.222
Compliant settings and compliant policies.

9
00:00:32.222 --> 00:00:33.685
>> No you're right you're close enough.

10
00:00:33.685 --> 00:00:34.650
>> Very good right?

11
00:00:34.650 --> 00:00:37.080
>> That's good enough for
government work as we say so that'll work.

12
00:00:37.080 --> 00:00:39.900
>> That's why we have and that's why
we have the expert Adam Gordon here.

13
00:00:39.900 --> 00:00:40.710
How's it going Adam?

14
00:00:40.710 --> 00:00:41.365
>> It's going well.

15
00:00:41.365 --> 00:00:42.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what we're going to do,

16
00:00:42.740 --> 00:00:44.640
we're going to spend a little
bit of time talking.

17
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:47.110
I never know where to look, the red
lights just keep bouncing left right.

18
00:00:47.110 --> 00:00:52.300
And you know it's just crazy here, crazy I
say on Friday evening, so we're going to

19
00:00:52.300 --> 00:00:55.830
talk about compliance settings and how to
set up configuration items and baselines.

20
00:00:55.830 --> 00:00:59.290
And the idea behind compliance and
compliance management is not new.

21
00:00:59.290 --> 00:01:03.087
This is something that is actually
a thought process that exists and

22
00:01:03.087 --> 00:01:06.286
has existed for
sometime both outside of this product and

23
00:01:06.286 --> 00:01:10.233
in theory outside of any of the asset
management products that we use.

24
00:01:10.233 --> 00:01:14.294
Remember, although we hear to talk about
Microsoft system center config manager,

25
00:01:14.294 --> 00:01:17.953
this is not the only asset management
product in the world, there are many,

26
00:01:17.953 --> 00:01:21.328
many products from many vendors to
do basically the identical thing so

27
00:01:21.328 --> 00:01:22.990
we're talking about here.

28
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:27.510
We're not allowed to name them because
of the fact that you know if we do,

29
00:01:27.510 --> 00:01:31.530
well you know, your software may randomly
stop working and things would happen.

30
00:01:31.530 --> 00:01:32.581
>> ITProTV explodes.

31
00:01:32.581 --> 00:01:36.514
>> We don't want that to happen, but you
know things like HP openview, IBM Tivoli,

32
00:01:36.514 --> 00:01:39.930
there are many, many of these
products out there on the market.

33
00:01:39.930 --> 00:01:45.190
And so compliance generically is
the idea of being able to go in and

34
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:49.780
to establish a configuration baseline,
or some sort of a standard that we will

35
00:01:49.780 --> 00:01:53.390
manage against, manage to,
and manage from.

36
00:01:53.390 --> 00:01:56.420
Now that baseline is gonna be made
up of individual building blocks,

37
00:01:56.420 --> 00:01:59.555
these are called configuration items,
or, in the language, or

38
00:01:59.555 --> 00:02:03.830
the parlance, another cool word there you
can add to the vocabulary list for you.

39
00:02:03.830 --> 00:02:07.500
In the parlance or
language of change management,

40
00:02:07.500 --> 00:02:10.340
configuration management generically
in these frameworks we so

41
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:13.460
often talk about,
we call these configuration items or CIs.

42
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:19.990
And we put these CIs into a configuration
management database what's called a CMDB.

43
00:02:19.990 --> 00:02:23.690
We combine them together into what is
known as a configuration baseline.

44
00:02:23.690 --> 00:02:26.842
We call that a configuration baseline,
we don't have a cool acronym for that one,

45
00:02:26.842 --> 00:02:29.030
it's just called a configuration baseline.

46
00:02:29.030 --> 00:02:33.980
And as a result of that, we then can take
that baseline, and we can apply it, and

47
00:02:33.980 --> 00:02:37.010
we will show you how to do this
in the console in a few minutes.

48
00:02:37.010 --> 00:02:39.320
We can apply it, and
we can then use it, and

49
00:02:39.320 --> 00:02:41.710
we can measure all the systems against it.

50
00:02:41.710 --> 00:02:45.120
See whether those systems are indeed
going to be in compliance,

51
00:02:45.120 --> 00:02:47.090
in compliance means that
the baseline is applied,

52
00:02:47.090 --> 00:02:50.710
the settings are being managed
appropriately and the system is in effect

53
00:02:50.710 --> 00:02:54.810
configured the way the baseline says it
should be, or they are out of compliance.

54
00:02:54.810 --> 00:02:58.280
Out of compliance means that while
the settings are listed in the compliance

55
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:01.580
baseline, those settings are not applied,
and for some reason are not

56
00:03:01.580 --> 00:03:04.990
being managed here, and then we can
decide to do what's called remediate.

57
00:03:04.990 --> 00:03:09.930
Go back and change or effect a change in
that system by applying the baseline and

58
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:11.280
the changing the current configuration.

59
00:03:11.280 --> 00:03:13.430
So we're gonna talk
through how that works,

60
00:03:13.430 --> 00:03:16.330
and what the building blocks and
moving parts are with system center,

61
00:03:16.330 --> 00:03:19.535
in order to get that done and
then when we are finish as we always do.

62
00:03:19.535 --> 00:03:22.985
We'll come back out, we wrap up, we'll
show you the pretty picture that Mike has

63
00:03:22.985 --> 00:03:26.805
created for this along with some lists
of things that would just be helpful for

64
00:03:26.805 --> 00:03:31.385

and consolidate all that knowledge for us.

65

So, if we can go and
take a look at the console and

66

we'll take a look at what's going on there
and this is gonna be the really cool one.

67
00:03:39.460 --> 00:03:42.840
If we can go ahead and we can go are you
ready, do it with me, can we put Mike and

68
00:03:42.840 --> 00:03:45.540
me in the same picture at the same time
and keep the console there as well.

69
00:03:45.540 --> 00:03:46.700
>> I don't know if you can do that,
let's see.

70
00:03:46.700 --> 00:03:47.690
>> I don't know if you can do that.

71
00:03:47.690 --> 00:03:49.280
Do we have picture in picture in picture?

72
00:03:49.280 --> 00:03:52.690
I'd have to hold a mirror up we could do

73
00:03:52.690 --> 00:03:53.570
All right so just do me, but

74

what we're gonna do is we're gonna
go big jazz hand finish, fullscreen.

75
00:03:57.716 --> 00:04:00.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay there we go outstanding.

76

>> All right so we're gonna go ahead and

77

So let me just zoom in here real quick and

78
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:09.230
That's what we always do we want to start
out knowing what part of the console we're

79
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:11.240
gonna manage from, we're in assets and

80
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:15.500
compliance in that work space and
up here, we're in compliance settings.

00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:19.140
You could see it right there and

we're gonna go ahead and take a look at

We'll notice that we have no configuration

85

We're going to provide those,
