Hope everybody out there enjoyed this one.

532
00:28:19.050 --> 00:28:21.340
Remember, if you wanna sit in
one of Adam's classes live,

533
00:28:21.340 --> 00:28:25.460
shoot as an email here
at seeadam@itpro.tv.

534
00:28:25.460 --> 00:28:27.820
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

535
00:28:27.820 --> 00:28:30.210
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

536
00:28:30.210 --> 00:28:33.865
>> And we'll see you next time.

537
00:28:33.865 --> 00:28:35.350
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike demonstrate setting up site boundaries and boundary groups. They create a site boundary based on an Active Directory site, and then link that boundary to a boundary group. Then they list the different discovery methods for finding and adding SCCM clients.
episodes.title: Boundary Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.379 --> 00:00:15.061
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.061 --> 00:00:17.120
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:17.120 --> 00:00:21.650
Today we're doing our system center
configuration manager 2012 R2.

5
00:00:21.650 --> 00:00:25.570
And specifically in this one we're
gonna be looking at boundaries and

6
00:00:25.570 --> 00:00:26.520
boundary groups.

7
00:00:26.520 --> 00:00:29.610
And here to help us with that is
the one and only Mr. Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:29.610 --> 00:00:30.460
How's is going, Adam?

9
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:33.480
>> Good, good.
I'm feeling very fenced in this

10
00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:34.475
morning for some reason.

11
00:00:34.475 --> 00:00:37.181
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's see if we can clarify why that is

12
00:00:37.181 --> 00:00:38.260
the case as we go.

13
00:00:38.260 --> 00:00:41.690
So we're gonna talk about boundary
groups as Mike was alluding too.

14
00:00:41.690 --> 00:00:44.570
The idea with boundary groups,
we mentioned them in a prior episode as we

15
00:00:44.570 --> 00:00:46.290
talked about how to set
up a secondary site and

16
00:00:46.290 --> 00:00:48.730
why boundary groups are important and
what they are.

17
00:00:48.730 --> 00:00:51.110
We also need to be aware of them as
we set up our primary sites, but

18
00:00:51.110 --> 00:00:55.010
the reality is as we set up our primary
site, we don't really have a sense with

19
00:00:55.010 --> 00:00:58.260
that boundary is gonna be yet, because we
have to first install the primary site,

20
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:01.190
and then start figuring out
what our boundary is gonna be.

21
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:04.900
And then link that and set it up in our
hierarchy, if we're gonna indeed install

22
00:01:04.900 --> 00:01:08.330
a hierarchy for our secondary sites,
and leverage that for discovery.

23
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:11.180
So we're gonna back track a little bit,
talk through that logic.

24
00:01:11.180 --> 00:01:14.510
We're also demo that for you,
set up a boundary group or a boundary.

25
00:01:14.510 --> 00:01:16.547
And then a boundary group and
link it to the boundary group.

26
00:01:16.547 --> 00:01:20.580
But you saw me in the demonstration,
we did a setting up the secondary site.

27
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:22.500
Specify what a boundary group was,

28
00:01:22.500 --> 00:01:25.690
the lab boundary group we used
to set the secondary site up.

29
00:01:25.690 --> 00:01:29.150
That boundary group is
the administrative container in effect

30
00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:33.628
that lets us bring our boundaries in and
assign them and manage them.

31
00:01:33.628 --> 00:01:36.306
So we're gonna talk about what that
looks like, why that's the case, and

32
00:01:36.306 --> 00:01:37.379
how all that comes together.

33
00:01:37.379 --> 00:01:40.693
Mikes actually gonna help me
do that because Mikes been

34
00:01:40.693 --> 00:01:44.379
kind enough to volunteer to
explain using only his fingers.

35
00:01:44.379 --> 00:01:45.667
>> [LAUGH]
>> What a boundary and

36
00:01:45.667 --> 00:01:47.254
a boundary group are, okay, go.

37
00:01:47.254 --> 00:01:48.212
>> Here we go.
>> Okay.

38
00:01:48.212 --> 00:01:50.285
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you see the graphics,

39
00:01:50.285 --> 00:01:53.815
remember Mike's in charge of all graphics,
good, bad, or indifferent.

40
00:01:53.815 --> 00:01:55.212
It's Mr. Mike who's on the graphics.

41
00:01:55.212 --> 00:01:58.100
So great job of the finger usage there for
the boundaries.

42
00:01:58.100 --> 00:01:59.870
>> Thank you very much.

43
00:01:59.870 --> 00:02:03.590
>> I never could have done that, I just
start this and I, it get's confusing.

44
00:02:03.590 --> 00:02:04.580
>> It takes a lot of practice.

45
00:02:04.580 --> 00:02:06.132
>> Doesn't work, it does,
it takes a lot of practice.

46
00:02:06.132 --> 00:02:09.750
All right, so let's start by talking
not boundaries and boundary groups, but

47
00:02:09.750 --> 00:02:12.690
actually client assignment cuz the first
thing we have to understand with

48
00:02:12.690 --> 00:02:16.950
regards to boundaries and boundary groups
is actually how we assign a client and

49
00:02:16.950 --> 00:02:21.200
what the process of client assignment
is with regards to taking an endpoint.

50
00:02:21.200 --> 00:02:24.490
A client is a managed endpoint,
taking an endpoint and

51
00:02:24.490 --> 00:02:29.270
figuring out where we actually want to
have that endpoint be homed or assigned.

52
00:02:29.270 --> 00:02:31.210
And Mike and I were talking about
this right before we got started for

53
00:02:31.210 --> 00:02:32.210
this episode.

54
00:02:32.210 --> 00:02:34.060
Hey, what is that whole
client assignment thing?

55
00:02:34.060 --> 00:02:35.140
You were telling me, right?

56
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:38.340
That we can assign a client,
does that mean we assign it to one site?

57
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:39.960
Can we assign it to more than one site?

58
00:02:39.960 --> 00:02:41.490
What site do we assign it to?

59
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:45.430
These are all very important questions
that we have to really understand and

60
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:47.948
ultimately have straight in our
head as we get started with this.

61
00:02:47.948 --> 00:02:51.400
So I wanna spend just a minute kind of
clarifying for us before we get in and

62
00:02:51.400 --> 00:02:53.530
really start looking at how to do this.

63
00:02:53.530 --> 00:02:57.880
Client assignment implies that we're gonna
take an unmanaged endpoint, desktop,

64
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:01.860
a server, whatever that specific
Windows infrastructure may be,

65
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:04.610
and we're gonna then assign.

66
00:03:04.610 --> 00:03:07.940
Effectively, associate is assigning,
associate or

67
00:03:07.940 --> 00:03:13.300
assign that endpoint to a site
by specifying the site code.

68
00:03:13.300 --> 00:03:15.600
The primary server site code
is what we're gonna be doing.

69
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:17.120
Did you hear a go-cart?

70
00:03:17.120 --> 00:03:18.426
I thought I heard a go-cart.

71
00:03:18.426 --> 00:03:21.171
>> I think so.
>> [CROSSTALK] that I have going on.

72
00:03:21.171 --> 00:03:23.004
Code for why are we doing this, right?

73
00:03:23.004 --> 00:03:24.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, we just hear a noise going on

74
00:03:24.800 --> 00:03:28.405
sometimes and we talk about it as if it
was a go-cart just to keep you guys on

75
00:03:28.405 --> 00:03:29.755
your toes and confuse you.

76
00:03:29.755 --> 00:03:30.420
>> That's right.

77
00:03:30.420 --> 00:03:33.200
>> So when we're thinking
about client assignments

78
00:03:33.200 --> 00:03:36.320
we're thinking about the ability to be
able to take an unmanaged endpoint and

79
00:03:36.320 --> 00:03:38.150
effectively associate
it with a primary site.

80
00:03:38.150 --> 00:03:42.090
Remember the site code is the primary
site code that we are associating with.

81
00:03:42.090 --> 00:03:44.860
I was also mentioning to
Mike as we got started that

82
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:46.850
central admin sites don't
have their own site codes.

83
00:03:46.850 --> 00:03:49.330
Remember, they do not manage
in a multi-set hierarchy

84
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:50.282
the clients themselves.

85
00:03:50.282 --> 00:03:52.180
They are responsible for
administration and

86
00:03:52.180 --> 00:03:55.650
reporting, all up view in other
words of data in the hierarchy.

87
00:03:55.650 --> 00:03:58.540
Primary sites are where site codes
are created where we associate and

88
00:03:58.540 --> 00:04:00.750
manage clients through
client assignment and

89
00:04:00.750 --> 00:04:04.020
secondary sites are child
objects of the primary.

90
00:04:04.020 --> 00:04:08.590
Just like the primary site is indeed
a child object of a central admin site but

91
00:04:08.590 --> 00:04:12.530
the secondary site associators who saw
the demonstration in the prior episode

92
00:04:12.530 --> 00:04:14.050
with a primary site.

93
00:04:14.050 --> 00:04:18.140
We specified the primary site server
site code to create the assignment but

94
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:22.450
we did give the secondary site, if you
remember, it's own site code, right?

95
00:04:22.450 --> 00:04:27.500
But remember that secondary sites are not
capable of managing clients directly,

96
00:04:27.500 --> 00:04:30.650
but rather are gonna manage those
clients on behalf of the primary site.

97
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:32.080
Effectively they're gonna
group them together,

98
00:04:32.080 --> 00:04:34.170
they're gonna be responsible for them.

99
00:04:34.170 --> 00:04:38.210
And then we're going to be able to push
down a package to the distribution point

100
00:04:38.210 --> 00:04:40.790
or whatever from the primary
site distributed out or

101
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:42.360
put in that secondary site down there.

102
00:04:42.360 --> 00:04:46.460
Primarily, it's a bandwidth management
solution to offset lack of bandwidth or

103
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:49.480
lack of ability to bring multiple
clients across the divide and

104
00:04:49.480 --> 00:04:50.900
have them managed directly.

105
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:52.260
So we're just gonna be
thinking about that and

106
00:04:52.260 --> 00:04:55.170
we're gonna assign those
clients to our primary site.

107
00:04:55.170 --> 00:04:59.350
So we're going to go ahead and we are
going to, in the process of assignment,

108
00:04:59.350 --> 00:05:01.350
specify as we deploy the agent,

109
00:05:01.350 --> 00:05:04.610
the client agent, on what the site
code is we want to associate with.

110
00:05:04.610 --> 00:05:07.430
That site code will be the site
code of the primary site.

111
00:05:07.430 --> 00:05:11.340
Now Mike also referenced and
asked me in our conversation prior, hey,

112
00:05:11.340 --> 00:05:13.505
can we have more than one primary site?

113
00:05:13.505 --> 00:05:15.650
And if so is a sign and
effectively saying,

114
00:05:15.650 --> 00:05:17.921
which primary sites you
wanna be a member of?

115
00:05:17.921 --> 00:05:21.130
And I said that's absolutely correct,
because that's exactly what it is.

116
00:05:21.130 --> 00:05:23.878
It's a question of which primary
site we wanna associate with.

117
00:05:23.878 --> 00:05:27.870
In a multi-site hierarchy,
it's a question of which primary site

118
00:05:27.870 --> 00:05:31.400
the client will be assigned to and
that's the site code we specify.

119
00:05:31.400 --> 00:05:35.535
We can't specify multiple site codes,
and a client cannot be a member or

120
00:05:35.535 --> 00:05:39.300
be associated with,
more than one primary site at a time.

121
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:42.180
But as I mentioned to Mike,
you can reassign a client.

122
00:05:42.180 --> 00:05:46.046
So we can say hey,
you're gonna be a member of A01, right?

123
00:05:46.046 --> 00:05:48.129
Adam site primary site 01.

124
00:05:48.129 --> 00:05:51.462
But then I wanna move you to
Mike primary site, Mike 01.

125
00:05:51.462 --> 00:05:56.886
So I can actually reassign the client
form A01 to M01 simply buy reassigning or

126
00:05:56.886 --> 00:05:59.820
changing the site code on the client.

127
00:05:59.820 --> 00:06:01.840
Now, here's something interesting.

128
00:06:01.840 --> 00:06:03.915
As if everything I've said up
to now is not interesting.

129
00:06:03.915 --> 00:06:05.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> So here's something relevant

130
00:06:05.170 --> 00:06:06.010
and interesting.

131
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:08.220
So we can assign and
change site codes, obviously.

132
00:06:08.220 --> 00:06:09.730
There's several ways to do this.

133
00:06:09.730 --> 00:06:13.050
We can manually put in the site code,
so we can do that by programming it in.

134
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:14.620
Can we do that through PowerShell?

135
00:06:14.620 --> 00:06:16.050
>> Of course.
>> Of course we can,

136
00:06:16.050 --> 00:06:17.590
cuz we have more than 12 commandments so

137
00:06:17.590 --> 00:06:20.710
as a result we definitely
have the option to do that.

138
00:06:20.710 --> 00:06:21.760
>> 470.
>> 470 is bigger than 12, right?

139
00:06:21.760 --> 00:06:22.260
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

140
00:06:22.260 --> 00:06:23.742
>> So we can do that we'll

141
00:06:23.742 --> 00:06:27.640
go through PowerShell, we can do it
manually, we can actually script it and

142
00:06:27.640 --> 00:06:30.490
do it through a log-on script or through
group policy, There's a lot of different

143
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:32.560
ways to do that.
We'll be talking about client assignment

144
00:06:32.560 --> 00:06:36.130
and how it can actually get that up and
running in one of our future discussions,

145
00:06:36.130 --> 00:06:38.290
but the reality is we have
multiple options here.

146
00:06:38.290 --> 00:06:39.780
So, we just want to keep that in mind,

147
00:06:39.780 --> 00:06:42.634
be aware of that.
We also will, as I said, have the ability

148
00:06:42.634 --> 00:06:45.895
to be able to go in and to auto decide.
I didn't actually say this but

149
00:06:45.895 --> 00:06:47.765
I should have.
We can also auto discover the site

150
00:06:47.765 --> 00:06:51.135
assignment, using the active directory
integration for our site code.

151
00:06:51.135 --> 00:06:52.595
So we can actually do that as well.

152
00:06:52.595 --> 00:06:54.045
That's where boundaries come in because

153
00:06:54.045 --> 00:06:57.955
one of the key things we're gonna do with
boundaries is set up a subnet association,

154
00:06:57.955 --> 00:07:01.790
or an IP range association.
And by doing that, leveraging our active

155
00:07:01.790 --> 00:07:05.340
directory site topology, which is what
we're gonna talk about and do and

156
00:07:05.340 --> 00:07:08.450
using a discovery method known as
the active directory farce discovery

157
00:07:08.450 --> 00:07:12.080
method to effectively pull in those
IP ranges and site boundaries.

158
00:07:12.080 --> 00:07:16.690
As a result of that, any client that is
in an IP range associated with the site

159
00:07:16.690 --> 00:07:20.390
is automatically gonna be associated
with that site based on association

160
00:07:20.390 --> 00:07:23.900
of that site boundary with that
primary site and so as a result.

161
00:07:23.900 --> 00:07:27.500
We effectively now have an automated
process to discover site codes, and

162
00:07:27.500 --> 00:07:29.090
that's normally how we do it by the way.

163
00:07:29.090 --> 00:07:32.070
We normally simply automate the process
and have a client come up, and

164
00:07:32.070 --> 00:07:34.870
based on IP address and
boundary association,

165
00:07:34.870 --> 00:07:38.640
have that client auto discover its
site code assuming DNS is working and

166
00:07:38.640 --> 00:07:41.980
obviously all the bells and
whistles we associate with LDAP and

167
00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:44.180
all the things we need for
directory services are there.

168
00:07:44.180 --> 00:07:47.504
Assuming that all works, the theory
comes up and it should work just fine.

169
00:07:47.504 --> 00:07:49.746
But we also have the option of
manually overriding that and

170
00:07:49.746 --> 00:07:51.587
assigning site codes on
our own if we choose to.

171
00:07:51.587 --> 00:07:55.431
We did talk about client reassignment
as well We can move clients back and

172
00:07:55.431 --> 00:07:57.837
forth if necessary so
just keep that in mind.

173
00:07:57.837 --> 00:08:01.110
Now we do a site compatibility check
when we do client site assignments.

174
00:08:01.110 --> 00:08:04.580
We actually check whether or not the site
that we are signing the client to

175
00:08:04.580 --> 00:08:07.520
is capable of running that
client based on versioning.

176
00:08:07.520 --> 00:08:11.780
So its important to know that
if you have a 2007 client,

177
00:08:11.780 --> 00:08:16.500
an older client like say that's coming up
into 2012 R2 site that's not gonna work,

178
00:08:16.500 --> 00:08:18.920
cuz we don't support 2007 clients in 2012.

179
00:08:18.920 --> 00:08:21.920
So we do compatibility checks
to make sure that the client and

180
00:08:21.920 --> 00:08:24.890
the site are at the right version
level and will work together.

181
00:08:24.890 --> 00:08:29.055
We're also gonna make sure that the
Configuration Manager can check back and

182
00:08:29.055 --> 00:08:31.835
see what's going on in AD to
do automatic site assignments.

183
00:08:31.835 --> 00:08:34.345
It's gonna be part of the compatibility
check that we do as well.

184
00:08:34.345 --> 00:08:38.165
If we have Internet-based management of
clients, cuz we can manage clients locally

185
00:08:38.165 --> 00:08:41.633
inside the LAN, so
manage them through the cloud using 12 R2.

186
00:08:41.633 --> 00:08:45.955
If they're Internet-based,
we do no client compatibility check for

187
00:08:45.955 --> 00:08:49.165
site assignment,
manually we have to specify everything.

188
00:08:49.165 --> 00:08:53.330
So it's important for you to know from an
exam perspective, as well as in the real

189
00:08:53.330 --> 00:08:57.530
world, that if you're setting up Internet
based client management, everything must

190
00:08:57.530 --> 00:09:00.470
be configured manually, the site
assignment, the site code, all that.

191
00:09:00.470 --> 00:09:02.957
We don't do any compatibility checks,
we don't auto-discover.

192
00:09:02.957 --> 00:09:06.146
But if we are on the LAN locally within
the network and active directories

193
00:09:06.146 --> 00:09:09.701
available and all that's working, we
actually do the compatibility checks and

194
00:09:09.701 --> 00:09:11.593
auto discover and auto assign the client.

195
00:09:11.593 --> 00:09:14.200
So there's a little bit of a difference
there depending on how we want to

196
00:09:14.200 --> 00:09:15.305
approach that.

197
00:09:15.305 --> 00:09:17.945
Wanna give you just a standing kind of
working condition of what a boundary

198
00:09:17.945 --> 00:09:20.437
is before we go in and
actually start playing around with one.

199
00:09:20.437 --> 00:09:24.097
The formal definition of a boundary
is that it is a demarkation point.

200
00:09:24.097 --> 00:09:25.877
It's effectively a marker.

201
00:09:25.877 --> 00:09:28.957
It's some sort of an indicator
of things being on one side,

202
00:09:28.957 --> 00:09:32.307
being a member of a group, things being
on the other side being excluded or

203
00:09:32.307 --> 00:09:34.327
not being a member of the group
that we are creating.

204
00:09:34.327 --> 00:09:37.867
So the boundaries really nothing more than
this line that we create or the circle.

205
00:09:37.867 --> 00:09:39.317
You wanna do the graphic for
me again there?

206
00:09:39.317 --> 00:09:39.897
>> [CROSSTALK] Do that one more time?

207
00:09:39.897 --> 00:09:40.919
>> Yeah, can you do that for me?

208
00:09:40.919 --> 00:09:42.160
I'm not good at that.

209
00:09:42.160 --> 00:09:43.035
Thank you very much.

210
00:09:43.035 --> 00:09:44.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> You have to be a professional to be

211
00:09:44.860 --> 00:09:46.810
able to carry that off and do it well.

212
00:09:46.810 --> 00:09:49.360
Did you catch the facial expression
while Mike was doing that?

213
00:09:49.360 --> 00:09:51.470
He was so focused, so
just like he was in the zone.

214
00:09:51.470 --> 00:09:53.950
>> You gotta make sure that you get to
the bottom at the same time with both-

215
00:09:53.950 --> 00:09:54.655
>> He was in the boundary.

216
00:09:54.655 --> 00:09:55.932
I would say the zone, but
he was in the boundary exactly.

217
00:09:55.932 --> 00:09:58.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's exactly where he was.

218
00:09:58.120 --> 00:09:59.159
So the boundary, right?

219

Hey look, you gotta,

00:20:39.290 --> 00:20:42.580

through the auto topology or

448
00:20:43.690 --> 00:20:47.550

takes place behind the scenes.

449
00:20:47.550 --> 00:20:51.700
When we create name spaces and
we add domain controllers in, and

450
00:20:51.700 --> 00:20:55.320
we extend our Active Directory,
we're talking about the AD now.

451
00:20:55.320 --> 00:21:00.408
The Active Directory sites are built on or
based on the Active Directory name space.

452
00:21:00.408 --> 00:21:03.392
So we have to understand what
the domain tree and the forest are.

453
00:21:03.392 --> 00:21:05.665
And I'm not gonna go into
that whole conversation and

454
00:21:05.665 --> 00:21:07.850
do the two hour drill down
on what these things are.

455
00:21:07.850 --> 00:21:12.794
But the 30 second quick version is a
forest is the all up container that holds

456
00:21:12.794 --> 00:21:16.445
all the name spaces associated
below it through a tree and

457
00:21:16.445 --> 00:21:19.790
then a domain association in a hierarchy.

458
00:21:19.790 --> 00:21:24.780
The active directory sites and services
topology generation is built around

459
00:21:24.780 --> 00:21:28.892
the replication pathways that take place
to create the two way transit of trusts

460
00:21:28.892 --> 00:21:33.350
that link domains from child to parent in
the relationship up through the trees and

461
00:21:33.350 --> 00:21:35.570
from trees into the forest.

462
00:21:35.570 --> 00:21:37.980
These are the pathways that
allow communication and

463
00:21:37.980 --> 00:21:41.380
therefore proffer trust through
the domain name spaces to occur.

464
00:21:41.380 --> 00:21:46.100
So if you're in domain A and I wanna go
over to domain B, I have to have a trust

465
00:21:46.100 --> 00:21:49.880
relationship and a communication pathway
that links the two inside the forest.

466
00:21:49.880 --> 00:21:53.970
These pathways are auto-generated by
active directory when we set these name

467
00:21:53.970 --> 00:21:57.950
spaces up and we use the dcpromo wizard
and you go through and do all that.

468
00:21:57.950 --> 00:22:01.200
We can also manually create
additional ones as fall backs, or

469
00:22:01.200 --> 00:22:03.140
additional pathways for redundancy.

00:22:03.140 --> 00:22:05.930
That's a whole other conversation for

637
00:29:11.110 --> 00:29:14.410
Now the next thing we wanna talk about is
how to associate a management point with

638
00:29:14.410 --> 00:29:15.130
a boundary group.

639
00:29:15.130 --> 00:29:18.620
A management point is one of the site
server roles that are created

640
00:29:18.620 --> 00:29:19.690
upon creation of the site.

641
00:29:19.690 --> 00:29:22.460
The primary site has a management
point associated with it.

642
00:29:22.460 --> 00:29:24.220
The management point's gonna be critical,

643
00:29:24.220 --> 00:29:27.940
because the management point is where
a client goes to get information

644
00:29:27.940 --> 00:29:31.950
about any policy changes that may
occur with client agent settings.

645
00:29:31.950 --> 00:29:34.570
So reconfiguring or
changing the client agent

646
00:29:34.570 --> 00:29:36.900
settings are gonna be done
through the management point.

647
00:29:36.900 --> 00:29:41.060
Management point is also gonna be where a
client goes to update the primary site, or

648
00:29:41.060 --> 00:29:42.520
the site server on it's status.

649
00:29:42.520 --> 00:29:44.800
So it reports in through
the management point, so

650
00:29:44.800 --> 00:29:46.710
it's a central point of communication.

651
00:29:46.710 --> 00:29:49.450
It's really how the server reaches out and
manages the clients,

652
00:29:49.450 --> 00:29:52.760
how the clients reach out and effectively
talk to the primary site server, or

653
00:29:52.760 --> 00:29:54.930
the site server that
they are associated with.

654
00:29:54.930 --> 00:29:58.450
And so as a result of that, we're gonna
have to associate that management point,

655
00:29:58.450 --> 00:30:01.520
or management points,
meaning more than one, with a boundary.

656
00:30:01.520 --> 00:30:04.270
Cuz we have to effectively put
the management point into the boundary.

657
00:30:04.270 --> 00:30:06.480
So that way the clients know that
they can communicate with it.

658
00:30:06.480 --> 00:30:07.130
>> Gotcha.

659
00:30:07.130 --> 00:30:07.950
>> Very important.

660
00:30:07.950 --> 00:30:10.970
So it's not enough just to say,
hey, let me set up a boundary.

661
00:30:10.970 --> 00:30:11.870
Let me establish some.

662
00:30:11.870 --> 00:30:15.050
Let me set up a boundary group and
associate the boundaries with that,

663
00:30:15.050 --> 00:30:17.640
if we don't put a management point
into that boundary group, or

664
00:30:17.640 --> 00:30:21.480
effectively allow a management point to
be associated without those boundaries,

665
00:30:21.480 --> 00:30:25.410
then clients are not able to effectively
communicate with the system.

666
00:30:25.410 --> 00:30:28.750
And we're not able to push updates out or
delete anything that has to be done or

667
00:30:28.750 --> 00:30:29.950
the clients will not work.

668
00:30:29.950 --> 00:30:32.260
So this is a very critical
step in the process.

669
00:30:32.260 --> 00:30:34.360
Probably the most important
one as a matter of fact.

670

we're gonna take a look at how to do this.

00:38:23.720 --> 00:38:26.230

All the other discovery methods

We'll talk about why in an upcoming

But for now just understand that the only

867

00:39:44.280 --> 00:39:45.470

Hope everybody out there enjoyed

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike take a closer look at the discovery process. They look at heartbeat discovery, the four Active Directory discovery methods and network discovery. They demonstrate configuring options for Active Directory discovery.Then they look at log files associated with discovery.
episodes.title: Discovery Methods

00:10:35.140 --> 00:10:39.710

update the status in the site database

229
00:10:39.710 --> 00:10:41.980

00:11:29.260 --> 00:11:32.170

00:11:32.170 --> 00:11:35.650

is about updating the status flag on

250
00:11:35.650 --> 00:11:38.930

ensure we know that it's still active.

00:11:38.930 --> 00:11:41.370

00:11:43.290 --> 00:11:45.930

we do run this once a week.

00:11:45.930 --> 00:11:49.420

It's really more about the stress and

We know that Heartbeat Discoveries turn

00:32:49.670 --> 00:32:50.330

00:42:45.501 --> 00:42:47.329
We can also obviously parse log files and

917

do all sorts of stuff
with the CM trace tool.

918
00:42:49.332 --> 00:42:52.328
We talked about CM trace tool, if you
remember, looking at those log files.

919
00:42:52.328 --> 00:42:56.006
So we just wanna be aware of that and
make sure we're obviously thinking about

920

that as part of our general
conversation and thought process, okay?

921

Well, Adam, again another great episode

923

the next logical step as we setup

924

Thank you for that.

Great.
Loved it.

926

And remember if you wanna sit

929

Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

931

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike look at how collections are used in SCCM 2012 R2 to gather and manage similar resources. They create limiting collections and membership rules to filter the collection membership. They look at default roles used to manage permissions in SCCM, as well as creating custom roles.
episodes.title: Collections and Roles
episodes.transcript:

if you want to think of it this way,

they operate similarly.

A role is a predefined set of permissions

81

allow that user to carry out their job.

82

And straining the user's permissions or

So we're going to take a look at that

We'll talk about what security and

And remember planning is so

How that's going to affect our

Because out of the box we have a User
Account that basically is given full

That's fine as long as that User Account
is the only account that logs in and

94
00:04:15.675 --> 00:04:16.930
>> [LAUGH]
>> But chances are good if you

95

a member of the IT team,

96

you may actually have multiple

So now we have to worry about either

99
00:04:29.767 --> 00:04:31.200
nicely without being insulting.

100

>> I don't think you can.

101

>> A really bad idea.

102
00:04:32.512 --> 00:04:34.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we don't wanna do that,

because then what will happen is,
unfortunately, somebody will

105
00:04:40.610 --> 00:04:42.960
It's not often that people go ahead and

But what will happen is,

a way that's then gonna cause us to

110

not be able to use it properly at
least now without a mediation.

111

So what we're gonna instead is
delegate responsibility for

Well supportively we gonna talk

>> [SOUND] I am amazed.

I am going to have to stop and

I just don't know what to say.

You are absolutely right, more than 12.

If I remember correctly,

we do have a nice little screen capture-

>> [LAUGH] So we're going to go ahead and

I'm thinking security and

So we're in the assets and

In other words, as we setup and operate

demo and we'll just make sure

Wouldn't be a bad Idea for you to know

Would I spend a huge amount of time

Memorizing, we don't ever say memorize,

Do we wanna learn with

173
00:07:17.750 --> 00:07:19.590
It's not a bad idea to know they're there.

The reality is if you ever ask,

So we're not gonna spend

But we do want you te be aware

00:07:32.820 --> 00:07:36.850
So what we're gonna do is go ahead and I'm

00:07:36.850 --> 00:07:41.050

It's also at the upper

I'm gonna go ahead and

And let's just scroll down a little area,
a little bit there so we can see.

188
00:07:56.125 --> 00:07:58.145
We have to give our
user collection a name.

189
00:07:58.145 --> 00:08:01.857
Now, this is important, a sense that you
know we may only have two or three or

190
00:08:01.857 --> 00:08:02.844
four collections.

191
00:08:02.844 --> 00:08:04.818
But I have customers that
have hundreds of collections.

192
00:08:04.818 --> 00:08:05.445
>> Wow.

193
00:08:05.445 --> 00:08:10.093
>> Because they have very large
infrastructure, and they are managing it

194
00:08:10.093 --> 00:08:15.700
either with a geography focus, based on,
let's say, building and location.

195
00:08:15.700 --> 00:08:17.830
So some of my big healthcare clients,
for instance,

196
00:08:17.830 --> 00:08:21.770
are doing this based on the hospitals they
own, or clinics, or things like that.

197
00:08:21.770 --> 00:08:26.050
So you can create these collections and
have them do a variety of things.

198
00:08:26.050 --> 00:08:29.110
We're gonna talk about that in relation to
the rules that we use to be able to drive

199
00:08:29.110 --> 00:08:32.400
the collection creation,
because collections are just containers.

200
00:08:32.400 --> 00:08:36.690
The secret to collections are the rules
that we use to actually populate them.

201
00:08:36.690 --> 00:08:38.810
And there's four types of
rules that we can use.

202
00:08:38.810 --> 00:08:40.420
We can use what's called a direct rule,
and

203
00:08:40.420 --> 00:08:43.200
I'm gonna show you these in
the interface here in a second.

204
00:08:43.200 --> 00:08:46.030
But we can have what's called a direct
rule, a rule that effectively

205
00:08:46.030 --> 00:08:49.590
allows us to select, specifically,
highlight the exact users,

206
00:08:49.590 --> 00:08:52.540
or in the case of computers,
what computers we wanna put in.

207
00:08:52.540 --> 00:08:54.480
We can use what's called a query rule.

208
00:08:54.480 --> 00:08:58.950
A query rule is going to allow us to
effectively create a dynamic solution,

209
00:08:58.950 --> 00:09:01.900
run a query against whatever
the database we're gonna pull from.

210
00:09:01.900 --> 00:09:03.500
In this case, the active directory.

211
00:09:03.500 --> 00:09:05.570

00:36:34.780 --> 00:36:37.160

00:40:10.154 --> 00:40:15.048
So, what this is is the list of all
of the built in roles that exist

887
00:40:15.048 --> 00:40:16.780
inside of the system.

888
00:40:16.780 --> 00:40:18.030
The 15 that we talked about.

889
00:40:18.030 --> 00:40:21.600
Now it may be hard for you to sit
there and copy these all down and

890
00:40:21.600 --> 00:40:22.350
know what they are.

891
00:40:22.350 --> 00:40:25.430
I don't want you to stress over the fact
that you should remember all 15.

892
00:40:25.430 --> 00:40:26.420
What I want you to know for

893
00:40:26.420 --> 00:40:29.420
exam preparations is that we do
have them and it would be good for

894
00:40:29.420 --> 00:40:32.870
you to know what they are but if you don't
remember them, not the end of the world.

895
00:40:32.870 --> 00:40:34.090
But if you need to get them all down,

896
00:40:34.090 --> 00:40:37.470
you don't wanna spend five minutes with
the screen pause trying to copy them.

897
00:40:37.470 --> 00:40:40.230
Just go out and Google for them because
you remember you will find the stuff,

898
00:40:40.230 --> 00:40:42.400
it is out there on
the Microsoft website as well.

899
00:40:42.400 --> 00:40:45.120
It is in the documentation,
we are just trying to summarize and

900
00:40:45.120 --> 00:40:46.120
provide it for you.

901
00:40:46.120 --> 00:40:49.510
Make it a little easier for you to consume
but if it doesn't work for you that way,

902
00:40:49.510 --> 00:40:51.230
just go out and
get a list off the Internet.

903
00:40:51.230 --> 00:40:53.740
And just write them down and then remember
what they are and you'll be fine.

904
00:40:53.740 --> 00:40:55.170
Let's go back up to that beautiful table.

905
00:40:55.170 --> 00:40:58.400
We did create that split into two,
and we will be able to see that.

906
00:40:58.400 --> 00:41:00.320
All right, and you can see it now
just a little bit if you want.

907
00:41:00.320 --> 00:41:02.310
Yeah, that's good, just so we have that.

908
00:41:02.310 --> 00:41:04.940
So then what we have here is how
we monitor collections, right?

909
00:41:04.940 --> 00:41:07.970
We've talked about how to create them,
but we wanna keep an eye on them, right?

910
00:41:07.970 --> 00:41:12.490
And so if we're looking at the Component
Status for the creation or, excuse me, for

911
00:41:12.490 --> 00:41:16.035
the actual running and the manipulation
and management of the collection,

912
00:41:16.035 --> 00:41:20.730
SMS_COLLECTION-EVALUATOR is gonna
provide us status information related to

913
00:41:20.730 --> 00:41:22.270
what's going on in a collection.

914
00:41:22.270 --> 00:41:25.500
When we look for log information,
the Colleval, short for

915
00:41:25.500 --> 00:41:29.650
collection evaluation log, is where we're
gonna get detailed status information for

916
00:41:29.650 --> 00:41:31.110
the actual collections themselves.

917
00:41:31.110 --> 00:41:35.030
So, it's one of the logs we'd look for
in that group of 73 that we spoke about.

918
00:41:35.030 --> 00:41:37.070
Status message queries
will allow us to go in and

919
00:41:37.070 --> 00:41:40.430
look at status information
based on a query dynamically.

920
00:41:40.430 --> 00:41:43.030
We took a look at some of those
in one of our prior discussions.

921
00:41:43.030 --> 00:41:46.380
And then reports are going to allow us,
we haven't really looked at reports yet

922
00:41:46.380 --> 00:41:47.870
but we will,

923
00:41:47.870 --> 00:41:52.060
it's going to allow us to leverage SQL
server reporting services capabilities.

924
00:41:52.060 --> 00:41:55.220
And we have over 400 built in
reports that we can go and use.

925
00:41:55.220 --> 00:41:57.210
And there are reports on all collections.

926
00:41:57.210 --> 00:42:01.290
All packages and program deployments,
all resources in a collection.

927
00:42:01.290 --> 00:42:03.530
Lots of different ways to
look at this information.

928
00:42:03.530 --> 00:42:05.380
So we'll be able to take
a look at all that and

929
00:42:05.380 --> 00:42:07.970
be able to diagnose things
that maybe going on as well.

930
00:42:07.970 --> 00:42:09.990
>> Another great episode Adam,
love those demos.

931
00:42:09.990 --> 00:42:11.520
We got to look at collections,

932
00:42:11.520 --> 00:42:15.380
at ways we can take those resources that
we've discovered, collect them up, right.

933
00:42:15.380 --> 00:42:16.800
Manage them as a unit.

934
00:42:16.800 --> 00:42:21.180
Start simplifying that administration
within SCCM, as well as a look at roles.

935
00:42:21.180 --> 00:42:24.210
The default roles, the 15 default
roles that are built in there

936
00:42:24.210 --> 00:42:27.725
that we can use to control permissions or
access to SCCM and

937
00:42:27.725 --> 00:42:29.985
the console and
all the goodies inside there.

938
00:42:29.985 --> 00:42:31.375
And the ability to create our own rules.

939
00:42:31.375 --> 00:42:34.635
So, if we wanna customize what
somebody can do when we get in there,

940
00:42:34.635 --> 00:42:36.135
we've got that capability as well.

941
00:42:36.135 --> 00:42:37.405
So, thanks for that Adam.

942
00:42:37.405 --> 00:42:38.875
Hope everybody enjoyed that episode.

943
00:42:38.875 --> 00:42:42.030
Remember, if you wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live,

944
00:42:42.030 --> 00:42:45.490
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

945
00:42:45.490 --> 00:42:47.390
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

946
00:42:47.390 --> 00:42:48.465
>> I'm an application author.

947
00:42:48.465 --> 00:42:50.190
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

948
00:42:50.190 --> 00:42:50.970
>> Take care everybody.

949
00:42:50.970 --> 00:42:55.753
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss ways to deploy the SCCM 2012 R2 client agent. They look at deploying the client agent using group policy. They also look at doing a manual install of the client agent, and push the client agent from the SCCM console.
episodes.title: Deploy the Client Agent
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.299 --> 00:00:15.278
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV,

3
00:00:15.278 --> 00:00:17.141
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.141 --> 00:00:21.080
Today we're doing our System Center
Configuration Manager 2012 R2,

5
00:00:21.080 --> 00:00:24.570
and specifically in this episode
we're gonna be looking at

6
00:00:24.570 --> 00:00:26.280
deploying the client agent, right.

7
00:00:26.280 --> 00:00:28.850
We've seen how to create our collection,

8
00:00:28.850 --> 00:00:32.780
start gathering up our different resources
that we wanna be able to manage, but

9
00:00:32.780 --> 00:00:35.680
somehow we've gotta be able
to talk to those resources.

10
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:38.110
And the agent is where that's
going to come into play.

11
00:00:38.110 --> 00:00:40.210
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

12
00:00:40.210 --> 00:00:40.790
How are you doing Adam?

13
00:00:40.790 --> 00:00:44.780
>> I'm good I'm good we're going
to talk about client agents.

14
00:00:44.780 --> 00:00:47.680
And specifically, as Mike was just
talking about, how to deploy them.

15
00:00:47.680 --> 00:00:51.170
Now deploying sounds fairly
straightforward, and indeed it is.

16
00:00:51.170 --> 00:00:54.650
But we have to understand that deployment
could take one of several paths.

17
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:56.960
And so
what we wanna do is at a high level,

18
00:00:56.960 --> 00:01:00.310
first understand the generic concepts
of what the client agent represent.

19
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:04.390
And then talk through, actually show and
tell as we will in the demo environment,

20
00:01:04.390 --> 00:01:07.770
through a couple of different
scenarios for client agent deployment.

21
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:11.620
The general concept of the client agent is
this little piece of software that gets

22
00:01:11.620 --> 00:01:16.000
installed on the managed end point that
allows us to effectively maintain control,

23
00:01:16.000 --> 00:01:20.470
as Mike was indicating, to do inventory,
to do policy updates, to deploy

24
00:01:20.470 --> 00:01:24.390
software through either an application or
a package, whatever it may be.

25
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:26.440
We have to install this in some way.

26
00:01:26.440 --> 00:01:30.320
In the Windows world we can Group Policy
based deployment just like we would with

27
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:32.590
a MSI file to be able to
drive that deployment.

28
00:01:32.590 --> 00:01:37.570
We can go ahead and we can deploy the
client agent manually by pulling down and

29
00:01:37.570 --> 00:01:40.930
executing the CCMsetup.exe solution.

30
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:43.891
We can go ahead and we can do a log
on script, we can go ahead and

31
00:01:43.891 --> 00:01:46.915
deploy it as part of and image for
imaging operating system and

32
00:01:46.915 --> 00:01:50.268
put the agent in the system and
just have it some up in auto discover.

33
00:01:50.268 --> 00:01:52.790
So there's lots of different ways for
us to do this.

34
00:01:52.790 --> 00:01:55.990
The challenge for us is just figuring
out what the most efficient way will be

35
00:01:55.990 --> 00:01:58.610
given the parameters of our network and
how we choose to operate.

36
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:01.540
While we're not gonna demo
every deployment model for you,

37
00:02:01.540 --> 00:02:04.250
we will at least highlight the dos and
don'ts and

38
00:02:04.250 --> 00:02:06.820
the things you should be aware
of with regards to them.

39
00:02:06.820 --> 00:02:08.710
So what I wanna do is jump in and
show you how to do this.

40
00:02:08.710 --> 00:02:12.160
We're going to go ahead and go to my
machine, and we're gonna take a look at

41
00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:15.300
the client deployment, or
at least the process associated with it.

42
00:02:15.300 --> 00:02:18.890
Now normally we start out in SCCM and
we're in the console.

43
00:02:18.890 --> 00:02:22.358
In this case what we're gonna do is start
out in the domain controller cuz we're

44
00:02:22.358 --> 00:02:25.020
gonna demo how to do a Group Policy
based deployment for you.

45
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:28.020
Or at least I'm gonna walk you
through the major parts of that.

46
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:31.515
Now this is something that most people
actually really don't bother to take

47
00:02:31.515 --> 00:02:34.370
the time to do cuz the reality is
it takes a lot of time to set up.

48
00:02:34.370 --> 00:02:36.380
You have to create a custom Group Policy.

49
00:02:36.380 --> 00:02:39.720
You have to add in the SSCM templates from

50
00:02:39.720 --> 00:02:43.580
the SSCM install directory in order to
provide support for the deployment,

51
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:47.590
and then you have to configure that,
and then set that up and manage it.

52
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:50.600
While it's doable, it's a lot of work.

53
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:53.160
But a lot of times people ask about this,
either when I'm teaching or

54
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:54.630
when I'm on site and I'm doing work.

55
00:02:54.630 --> 00:02:57.220
They say, hey you know I've heard I
can do this but it's kind of hard and

56
00:02:57.220 --> 00:02:59.550
confusing to figure out what
to do based on reading it.

57
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:00.650
Could you walk me through it?

58
00:03:00.650 --> 00:03:03.860
Well, no I don't happen to have it all
set up and just waiting around for

59
00:03:03.860 --> 00:03:04.360
you to do it.

60
00:03:04.360 --> 00:03:07.930
So I can tell you what's gonna happen but
it's a little tough to actually show it to

61
00:03:07.930 --> 00:03:11.360
you unless you turn me loose inside
your directory and let me do it.

62
00:03:11.360 --> 00:03:14.380
At that point we decide it's
probably not a good idea and

63
00:03:14.380 --> 00:03:16.520
we decide we'll spend our
time doing something else.

64
00:03:16.520 --> 00:03:19.320
But, I thought it would be valuable
to show you how to do it so

65
00:03:19.320 --> 00:03:20.590
I am gonna walk you
through how to do this.

66
00:03:20.590 --> 00:03:23.000
We will also take a look at
how to do a manual deployment,

67
00:03:23.000 --> 00:03:27.310
how to pull the CCMsetup.exe package and
execute that to install.

68
00:03:27.310 --> 00:03:30.770
We could also push the agent out as I've
already mentioned through, in some of our

69
00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:34.280
other demonstrations, through the console
once we have a collection and we have it

70
00:03:34.280 --> 00:03:38.530
populated if we find machines we can right
click and do an install client from there.

71
00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:42.070
And we can do what's called a push install
which is another method for installation.

72
00:03:42.070 --> 00:03:44.200
And a lot of times that's really
the preferred method actually,

73
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:48.790
is just do a push install or to image your
operating systems as we will talk about in

74
00:03:48.790 --> 00:03:52.530
a future episode with OSD, the operating
system deployment feature and

75
00:03:52.530 --> 00:03:54.720
to actually include
the agent inside the image.

76
00:03:54.720 --> 00:03:57.790
And then when you throw the image
the machine comes up, it auto-configures,

77
00:03:57.790 --> 00:04:01.350
it is able to leverage the batteries that
are already set up, so it auto-discovers.

78
00:04:01.350 --> 00:04:04.600
And then the client associates and
is found, and ultimately managed.

79
00:04:04.600 --> 00:04:06.468
So there's a lot of
different ways to do this.

80
00:04:06.468 --> 00:04:10.330
Group Policy based deployment may not
be at the top of your list, but it is

81
00:04:10.330 --> 00:04:13.720
something interesting and so we will take
some time to go through and take a look.

82
00:04:13.720 --> 00:04:14.910
So check this one out, I got this.

83
00:04:14.910 --> 00:04:17.495
I figured out what I'm gonna do,
this is gonna be my new one.

84
00:04:17.495 --> 00:04:19.590
Titus are you ready,
this is what I'm gonna do, ready?

85
00:04:19.590 --> 00:04:22.290
This is the signal to go.

86
00:04:22.290 --> 00:04:23.540
Oh look at, that's awesome.

87
00:04:23.540 --> 00:04:25.175
All right,
that's gonna be the new one right there.

88
00:04:25.175 --> 00:04:26.062
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

89
00:04:26.062 --> 00:04:27.712
what we're gonna do is the following.

90
00:04:27.712 --> 00:04:29.550
We're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna jump in here.

91
00:04:29.550 --> 00:04:33.040
So let me just show you where we are.

92
00:04:33.040 --> 00:04:33.830
I am on the domain control.

93
00:04:33.830 --> 00:04:36.579
Or you can see that with
the highlighted dark

94
00:04:36.579 --> 00:04:40.004
blue selector in my virtual
machine area PLABDC01.

95
00:04:40.004 --> 00:04:42.100
So I'm on the domain controller right now.

96
00:04:42.100 --> 00:04:45.200
And in the domain controller I'm in
the Group Policy Management Editor.

97
00:04:45.200 --> 00:04:46.444
You can see that up top there.

98
00:04:46.444 --> 00:04:48.650
I know the little blue square's
kinda sitting in the middle of that.

99
00:04:48.650 --> 00:04:53.050
I apologize, that's the control tools for
the virtual environment that we're using.

100
00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:56.060
Can't really move those so
that's just gonna kinda have to be there.

101
00:04:56.060 --> 00:04:57.173
But what I've done is I've gone ahead and

102
00:04:57.173 --> 00:05:02.230
I've created kind of a custom
Group Policy called SCCM Client Install.

103
00:05:02.230 --> 00:05:05.500
You can see the name up at the very
top on the left of the hierarchy.

104
00:05:05.500 --> 00:05:07.740
And I've just gone ahead and
done that in the editor,

105
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:11.490
right clicked, figured out where I wanted
to create a new policy, give it a name.

106
00:05:11.490 --> 00:05:14.110
I just did all that ahead of time
cuz I figured probably be okay for

107
00:05:14.110 --> 00:05:16.850
us to do that part and
just tell you what we did there.

108
00:05:16.850 --> 00:05:20.750
Then I've opened up the policy editor,
the computer configuration side,

109
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:21.630
as you can see.

110
00:05:21.630 --> 00:05:24.810
I've drilled down inside policies,
down to administrative templates.

111
00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:25.560
And I'm gonna go ahead and

112
00:05:25.560 --> 00:05:28.450
I'm gonna right click on that
administrative template folder here

113
00:05:28.450 --> 00:05:32.160
in a minute because I have to add in some
of those templates that I was managing.

114
00:05:32.160 --> 00:05:34.580
We have to, I was mentioning,
that we have to bring in to manage.

115
00:05:34.580 --> 00:05:38.000
We have this process from
the SCCM installation media.

116
00:05:38.000 --> 00:05:39.350
So we're going to take
a look at how to do that.

117
00:05:40.750 --> 00:05:42.460
So what I'm gonna do is
I'm gonna go over here.

118
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:46.180
I am going to right click on
the Administrative Templates area.

119
00:05:46.180 --> 00:05:49.520
We do have a little menu that shows
up there, Add/Remove Templates.

120
00:05:49.520 --> 00:05:51.315
You may or may not have seen
this depending on how often

121
00:05:51.315 --> 00:05:52.770
you're in playing around
with Group Policy.

122
00:05:52.770 --> 00:05:54.560
But we're gonna go ahead and do that.

123
00:05:54.560 --> 00:05:56.350
So I am gonna go ahead and
do Add/Remove Templates.

124
00:05:56.350 --> 00:05:57.810
So let me just click on that.

125
00:05:57.810 --> 00:06:02.060
We're gonna get our little
Add/Remove Template dialogue box here.

126
00:06:02.060 --> 00:06:04.494
I'm gonna go ahead and
I'm gonna click Add and

127
00:06:04.494 --> 00:06:07.142
we're going to get our
policy template browser.

128
00:06:07.142 --> 00:06:09.420
We're gonna be able to go out
effectively and look for it.

129
00:06:09.420 --> 00:06:12.050
Now what we're gonna have to do
is obviously know ahead of time

130
00:06:12.050 --> 00:06:13.430
where these templates will be, right.

131
00:06:13.430 --> 00:06:16.140
So we have to know where to find them,
we have to know that we have to get them

132
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:18.670
because they're not just
gonna magically appear.

133
00:06:18.670 --> 00:06:20.710
They are part of the SCCM install.

134
00:06:20.710 --> 00:06:21.306
>> Okay, that was the question.

135
00:06:21.306 --> 00:06:22.120
>> We have to know where to find them.

136
00:06:22.120 --> 00:06:24.280
>> Was this part of the install or
do we have to download it from Microsoft?

137
00:06:24.280 --> 00:06:26.587
>> We could get it from Microsoft as well,
but they are part of the install.

138
00:06:26.587 --> 00:06:29.025
So when the install is done
they actually will show up,

139
00:06:29.025 --> 00:06:31.065
not in the place we would
logically think of.

140
00:06:31.065 --> 00:06:32.610
We gotta go find them but
they are gonna be there.

141
00:06:32.610 --> 00:06:34.780
So, I'm gonna tell you
where to go get them from.

142
00:06:34.780 --> 00:06:36.650
So, we're gonna go ahead and
do the following.

143
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:40.712
We're gonna go into the C Drive,
we're gonna go to our share there.

144
00:06:40.712 --> 00:06:44.836
I'm just checking my path statements so
bear with while I mumble to myself.

145
00:06:44.836 --> 00:06:46.160
So that we're gonna go do that.

146
00:06:46.160 --> 00:06:49.060
Now the place that you're gonna wanna
go find them, if you have to go out and

147
00:06:49.060 --> 00:06:52.600
get them, for real,
from the install media is gonna be.

148
00:06:52.600 --> 00:06:55.710
And we'll go ahead,
we'll reproduce this path statement.

149
00:06:55.710 --> 00:06:57.635
During the demo Mike will type it out.

150
00:06:57.635 --> 00:06:58.670
>> Mm-hm.

151
00:06:58.670 --> 00:07:01.520
>> Mike will type it out and put it up so
that way we can show it to you after we're

152
00:07:01.520 --> 00:07:04.300
done, so don't worry about
writing it all down right now.

153
00:07:04.300 --> 00:07:09.285
But it's gonna be SCCM Source Media, it's
gonna be SCCM Source Media > SMS Setup >

154
00:07:09.285 --> 00:07:11.970
Tools > Config Manager > ADM2 Templates.

155
00:07:11.970 --> 00:07:14.130
I'll give you the path, I'll tell you
what it is, don't worry about it.

156
00:07:14.130 --> 00:07:16.460

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss device requirements for installing the SCCM 2012 R2 client agent. They also talk about supporting internet based clients. Then they take a look at configuring custom SCCM 2012 R2 client agent settings.
episodes.title: Manage the Client Agent
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.087 --> 00:00:15.629
Hello, and welcome to another
fantastic episode here at IT Pro TV,

3
00:00:15.629 --> 00:00:17.256
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:17.256 --> 00:00:21.100
Today we're doing our SCCM 2012 R2.

And specifically in this episode,

All right, so anyway.

Please, please don't pay any attention to

>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're here to talk about

client requirements.

25

And as Mike was saying, you know we've
talked a lot about deployment methods,

we talked about how to set up all

27
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:10.050
plan all that out, get that all set up.

28
00:01:10.050 --> 00:01:12.960
We just went through how to do
group policy based deployment,

talked about potentially how to do log on

script based deployments, and

now what we are going to focus on and

33
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:30.110
So the agent starts doing what it

34
00:01:30.110 --> 00:01:34.750
which is more than just show up on the

35
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:38.320
We actually want it to do some work for

36

and report back on all those things.

37
00:01:42.520 --> 00:01:45.920
So we're gonna take some time to go in and
take a look at those settings in detail,

38

but before we go and

And most importantly the parameters and

And then we'll go in and

We'll take a look at it

46
00:02:04.137 --> 00:02:06.947
We talk about how policy gets pushed down

47
00:02:06.947 --> 00:02:09.777

to the client and back again.

48
00:02:09.777 --> 00:02:12.557
For updates, Mike's got a nice

00:02:12.557 --> 00:02:13.337
Show us how to do that.

50
00:02:13.337 --> 00:02:15.787
And we'll wrap up by talking about that.

If we could go and take a look at some

00:02:19.167 --> 00:02:22.257

us to drive this conversation.

53
00:02:22.257 --> 00:02:26.620
So device requirements are gonna help
us to figure out what Windows based,

54
00:02:26.620 --> 00:02:30.390
Windows based client agents are going
to look like, be managed by, and

55
00:02:30.390 --> 00:02:34.130
as result of that have some you know
just default configuration settings and

56
00:02:34.130 --> 00:02:35.980
concerns that we want to be aware of.

57
00:02:35.980 --> 00:02:38.040
We've got that information
up on the screen.

58
00:02:38.040 --> 00:02:42.080
This is going to be what a Windows
based endpoint is going to need to make

59
00:02:42.080 --> 00:02:46.140
in terms of the minimum requirements
and/or meet in terms of prereqs for

60
00:02:46.140 --> 00:02:47.090
us to be able to install the.

61
00:02:47.090 --> 00:02:51.710
You'll notice we can run anything

62
00:02:51.710 --> 00:02:54.350
Windows XP x64 SP2.

63
00:02:54.350 --> 00:02:57.650
So XP SP3 would be on the 32 bit side.

64
00:02:57.650 --> 00:03:01.672
XP x64 SP2 at a minimum
on the client side.

65
00:03:01.672 --> 00:03:05.660
Windows server 2003 SP2 and
newer on the server side.

66
00:03:05.660 --> 00:03:08.336
It's good that we have all those operating
systems that we no longer support

67
00:03:08.336 --> 00:03:09.004
>> [LAUGH]

68
00:03:09.004 --> 00:03:10.839
>> Still right there at the top of

69
00:03:10.839 --> 00:03:11.504
the list.

70
00:03:11.504 --> 00:03:14.924
Now obviously you know the reality
while you still may have some XP,

71
00:03:14.924 --> 00:03:17.324
may still have some server 2003 deployed,

72
00:03:17.324 --> 00:03:21.420
those operating systems are no longer
considered to be supported my Microsoft.

73
00:03:21.420 --> 00:03:26.020
Server 2003 was dropped earlier
in 2015 around summertime, and

74
00:03:26.020 --> 00:03:28.920
XP a little bit prior to that.

75
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:33.476
Actually by the way Microsoft's getting
ready to drop support formally for IE 8,

76
00:03:33.476 --> 00:03:34.650
IE 9, and IE 10.

77
00:03:34.650 --> 00:03:36.910
It's coming up actually in the very
beginning of January 2016.

78
00:03:36.910 --> 00:03:40.735
Within the fist two weeks I believe,
if I'm not mistaken.

79
00:03:40.735 --> 00:03:42.835
Actually, what would it be.

80
00:03:42.835 --> 00:03:43.575
What is today?

81
00:03:43.575 --> 00:03:46.128
[CROSSTALK] Today is Tuesday,
today is Wednesday, so

82
00:03:46.128 --> 00:03:50.003
it would be I think on the 12th if I'm
not mistaken, of January, of 2016.

83
00:03:50.003 --> 00:03:51.980
They have dropped by
the time you hear this and

84
00:03:51.980 --> 00:03:55.750
see this most likely you're not watching
it live, then we'll have done it already.

85
00:03:55.750 --> 00:03:58.702
But they are actually dropping support for
IE 8, 9 and

86
00:03:58.702 --> 00:04:02.160
10 because they want to push
everybody into, God help us all,

87
00:04:02.160 --> 00:04:06.800
the Edge browser and IE 11, because
we know both of those work so well.

88
00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:09.016
With the lab environment
that we are using.

89
00:04:09.016 --> 00:04:12.040
So as a result of that,
good luck is all I have to say.

90
00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:15.270
They are moving to push everybody
into those late-stage browsers.

91
00:04:15.270 --> 00:04:17.860
And they already have dropped support for
2003.

92
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:21.140
But when server 16 comes
out later in 2016,

93
00:04:21.140 --> 00:04:24.765
server 2008 will be on the chopping
block shortly thereafter as well.

94
00:04:24.765 --> 00:04:28.672
So we do see a cycle and
a turnover in these OS's in real time.

95
00:04:28.672 --> 00:04:32.108
We are still reaching backward and
supporting them in theory right now on

96
00:04:32.108 --> 00:04:36.221
the platform, but the reality is if you're
running these things in production you may

97
00:04:36.221 --> 00:04:39.879
still clearly have a reason to manage
them, but you should have an exit plan,

98
00:04:39.879 --> 00:04:43.881
and really a remediation to move off those
operating systems and really roll forward

99
00:04:43.881 --> 00:04:47.146
into something, at a bare minimum like,

1003
00:47:44.310 --> 00:47:46.620
So I'm gonna click on that,
it's gonna open up a little wizard for us,

1004
00:47:46.620 --> 00:47:48.170
it will take us just a moment to do that.

1005
00:47:49.920 --> 00:47:55.770
So what we'll have here is, and
I'll just call this test one,

1006
00:47:55.770 --> 00:48:00.270
the ability to be able to generate that,
and then you'll see you have a checklist

1007
00:48:00.270 --> 00:48:02.640
of all the different setting
options I just showed you.

1008
00:48:02.640 --> 00:48:04.299
We're going to check off the ones we want.

1009
00:48:04.299 --> 00:48:08.058
They're going to be put onto the left-hand
selector window right here under general,

1010
00:48:08.058 --> 00:48:11.254
and then I'm going to be able to start
configuring them as I choose them, so

1011
00:48:11.254 --> 00:48:13.425
let's just take a look at
what that may look like.

1012
00:48:13.425 --> 00:48:18.520
Let's say that I want BITs and
let's say that I want Hardware Inventory.

1013
00:48:18.520 --> 00:48:20.196
So I've selected those two.

1014
00:48:20.196 --> 00:48:21.940
You'll see they've been moved over there.

1015
00:48:21.940 --> 00:48:26.210
And what I can now do is
go to Hardware Inventory.

1016
00:48:26.210 --> 00:48:30.560
And I can go in and I can,

1017
00:48:31.860 --> 00:48:36.565
because Jonathon asked, I can go in and-
>> Check them all.

1018
00:48:36.565 --> 00:48:38.210
>> Check them all,
except I'm not gonna do that,

1019
00:48:38.210 --> 00:48:40.790
because it's a pain in the ass to
go through and check each one.

1020
00:48:40.790 --> 00:48:43.870
>> We need some battery status.
>> They don't have a set all for

1021
00:48:43.870 --> 00:48:46.685
a reason because it is really
not a good idea, all right?

1022
00:48:46.685 --> 00:48:48.848
[LAUGH] But you can,
you know they have like in Windows update,

1023
00:48:48.848 --> 00:48:50.692
where you have the check up,
check box, check all?

1024
00:48:50.692 --> 00:48:53.000
Yeah, we don't have that for
a reason, all right.

1025
00:48:53.000 --> 00:48:55.250
But I am gonna choose most of those, so

1026
00:48:55.250 --> 00:48:59.270
I'm just gonna go ahead and
check off like, let's say those.

1027
00:48:59.270 --> 00:49:01.880
I'm gonna click OK and
then I've done that, so

1028
00:49:01.880 --> 00:49:05.325
then when I'm done, what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna click OK.

1029
00:49:06.460 --> 00:49:09.520
And now, what you'll see

1030
00:49:09.520 --> 00:49:13.000
is that we actually now have not just the
Default Client Settings, but I also have

1031
00:49:13.000 --> 00:49:16.660
a new set of Client Settings called Test
1 that are available there, all right?

1032
00:49:16.660 --> 00:49:17.910
>> Nice.
>> So now I have that, and

1033
00:49:17.910 --> 00:49:23.090
now I can use that, and I can actually
use that to then drive a custom set

1034
00:49:23.090 --> 00:49:27.050
of settings down to certain collections,
and use it to be further focused

1035
00:49:27.050 --> 00:49:31.210
on how I'm gonna effectively gather that
information and use it to my advantage.

1036
00:49:31.210 --> 00:49:34.140
Now in terms of gathering that
information, we wanna take a quick look,

1037
00:49:34.140 --> 00:49:37.780
and I know you have a nice little graphic
that we've put together, that we want to

1038
00:49:37.780 --> 00:49:41.840
talk about for client policy retrieval and
how once we push all this stuff up and set

1039
00:49:41.840 --> 00:49:45.820
it up, how we're actually then gonna be
able to see the client actually updating.

1040
00:49:45.820 --> 00:49:48.560
And so what we have is we now
have the agent settings set up.

1041
00:49:48.560 --> 00:49:49.140
We've done that.

1042
00:49:49.140 --> 00:49:50.280
Configured them.

1043
00:49:50.280 --> 00:49:53.270
We've even showed you how to create
a custom set of agent settings if we want.

1044
00:49:53.270 --> 00:49:55.442
But they're still sitting on
the server on the console.

1045
00:49:55.442 --> 00:49:58.800
We gotta get them down to the client,
not just a client but to all clients.

1046
00:49:58.800 --> 00:50:00.370
We've gotta push them out there.

1047
00:50:00.370 --> 00:50:04.300
So once we've done that, we now have to do
what's called a policy retrieval cycle.

1048
00:50:04.300 --> 00:50:08.610
So the agent checks in by default
every 60 minutes to see whether or

1049
00:50:08.610 --> 00:50:11.270
not with the management point
there's been an update.

1050
00:50:11.270 --> 00:50:14.400
So at least once an hour we're gonna
see if there's been a policy change.

1051
00:50:14.400 --> 00:50:17.950
If there has,
we pull down the pending policy file and

1052
00:50:17.950 --> 00:50:19.700
we apply it to the endpoint.

1053
00:50:19.700 --> 00:50:24.324
Now it's the server's responsibility,
the site server.

1054
00:50:24.324 --> 00:50:28.250
It's the site server's responsibility to
tee up these changes when we make them and

1055
00:50:28.250 --> 00:50:31.846
put them into a pending queue and alert
the management point, which is simply

1056
00:50:31.846 --> 00:50:35.610
a site server role that typically is
sitting on the primary site server.

1057
00:50:35.610 --> 00:50:37.970
But alert any management points
that there's been a change,

1058
00:50:37.970 --> 00:50:38.950
there's been an update.

1059
00:50:38.950 --> 00:50:43.190
So there's communication that takes place
between the primary site server and

1060
00:50:43.190 --> 00:50:46.030
the management points, plural,
if there's more than one.

1061
00:50:46.030 --> 00:50:49.795
If the management point is on
the primary site server, the function.

1062
00:50:49.795 --> 00:50:51.190
The management point function,

1063
00:50:51.190 --> 00:50:53.900
is made aware of the fact
that there's a policy update.

1064
00:50:53.900 --> 00:50:58.060
The management point is then gonna tee
that up and so in step one on the left

1065
00:50:58.060 --> 00:51:02.240
there where the client checks in and
says hey, Mr. management pointer Mrs.

1066
00:51:02.240 --> 00:51:05.730
management point, do I have any
updates that I have to be aware of?

1067
00:51:05.730 --> 00:51:09.190
Management point goes back to
configuration management database server,

1068
00:51:09.190 --> 00:51:10.670
you'll see that in step two.

1069
00:51:10.670 --> 00:51:14.190
Checks the database server and
downloads the policies,

1070
00:51:14.190 --> 00:51:19.670
right, that have been updated, downloads
the updated policy file, the information.

1071
00:51:19.670 --> 00:51:22.780
Returns that back to the management point,
so we have it teed up.

1072
00:51:22.780 --> 00:51:26.100
And then ultimately pushes that
out in step four to the client.

1073
00:51:26.100 --> 00:51:28.340
So at least once an hour
the client does this by default,

1074
00:51:28.340 --> 00:51:29.910
because we have a 60 minute interval.

1075
00:51:29.910 --> 00:51:33.520
Now, we can change that, or we can say
hey, let's check in every 5 minutes,

1076
00:51:33.520 --> 00:51:35.430
or every 15 minutes, or whatever.

1077
00:51:35.430 --> 00:51:39.190
But at least once an hour, clients check
in to see if there's a policy update.

1078
00:51:39.190 --> 00:51:44.270
Now if we wait that cycle, if we wait an
hour, we can make a change two minutes in,

1079
00:51:44.270 --> 00:51:47.390
59 minutes later, roughly,
that change will show up, maybe even

1080
00:51:47.390 --> 00:51:50.680
a little bit more than that, but
it's gonna take a full hour at a minimum.

1081
00:51:50.680 --> 00:51:53.770
If we don't wanna wait, if we're
impatient, we can go to the end point.

1082
00:51:53.770 --> 00:51:56.720
We can go to the SCCM client
in the control panel.

1083
00:51:56.720 --> 00:51:58.930
We can highlight policy retrieval.

1084
00:51:58.930 --> 00:52:02.780
Machine policy retrieval, user policy
retrieval and kick off run now and

1085
00:52:02.780 --> 00:52:06.810
manually intervene and we can launch that
whenever we want as often as we want,

1086
00:52:06.810 --> 00:52:09.120
right, so
we can do that if we need to as well.

1087
00:52:09.120 --> 00:52:11.286
>> As always, Adam, another great episode,

1088
00:52:11.286 --> 00:52:14.388
we got to take a look at managing
those client agent settings and

1089
00:52:14.388 --> 00:52:18.389
there were a lot of them, and some really
cool ones that were pretty surprising.

1090
00:52:18.389 --> 00:52:22.080
We saw support for devices that
we might not normally think of.

1091
00:52:22.080 --> 00:52:23.607
We see Microsoft opening up and

1092
00:52:23.607 --> 00:52:27.072
saying, hey, we can put these agents
on Apple device, iOS devices,

1093
00:52:27.072 --> 00:52:31.127
Android devices, Linux devices, and
then going through all of those settings,

1094
00:52:31.127 --> 00:52:35.490
fantastic, I feel like I could work my
way around there pretty comfortably now.

1095
00:52:35.490 --> 00:52:37.939
Hope you guys can too,
hope you enjoyed watching this episode.

1096
00:52:37.939 --> 00:52:41.585
Remember, if you wannna sit in
one of Adam's classes live,

1097
00:52:41.585 --> 00:52:44.455
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

1098
00:52:44.455 --> 00:52:46.198
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

1099
00:52:46.198 --> 00:52:47.621
>> I'm confused.

1100
00:52:47.621 --> 00:52:49.084
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

1101
00:52:49.084 --> 00:52:49.735
>> Take care.

1102
00:52:49.735 --> 00:52:55.440
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike look at setting up inventory collections in SCCM 2012 R2. They create hardware inventories and software inventories. They look at doing software metering. Then they talk about the reporting capabilities of SCCM 2012 R2.
episodes.title: Inventory Collection
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.401
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.401 --> 00:00:09.315
Hello, and welcome to another

3
00:00:09.315 --> 00:00:15.181
fantastic episode here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.181 --> 00:00:17.600
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

5
00:00:17.600 --> 00:00:20.610
Today we're doing our system
center configurations manager.

6
00:00:20.610 --> 00:00:21.490
2012 R2 content.

7
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:25.008
And in this episode, we're going
to focus in on some inventories.

8
00:00:25.008 --> 00:00:29.520
We're going to take a look at hardware
inventories and software inventories.

9
00:00:29.520 --> 00:00:32.600
And here to help us with that is
the one and only, Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:32.600 --> 00:00:33.600
How's it going, Adam?

11
00:00:33.600 --> 00:00:37.390
>> I have a checklist of things that
is going to indicate it's going well.

12
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:38.983
>> Good.
>> When we think about inventories,

13
00:00:38.983 --> 00:00:39.841
as Mike was saying,

14
00:00:39.841 --> 00:00:43.180
we've actually talked about these in
our prior episode We went through this.

15
00:00:43.180 --> 00:00:46.700
We talked about setting up the client
agent and default settings.

16
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:47.690
We drilled down a little bit.

17
00:00:47.690 --> 00:00:50.793
I'll share with you some of the
interesting little tidbits of information

18
00:00:50.793 --> 00:00:52.714
about both hardware and
software inventory,

19
00:00:52.714 --> 00:00:55.980
the fact that we can go through and be
very granular on the hardware inventory.

20
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:56.770
We'll take a look at that.

21
00:00:56.770 --> 00:00:58.830
We felt that was pretty exciting.

22
00:00:58.830 --> 00:01:00.260
We talked about software inventory.

23
00:01:00.260 --> 00:01:03.500
The fact that we can collect
files from individual machines.

24
00:01:03.500 --> 00:01:07.760
And so we're gonna delve in and
go a little bit deeper there in the sense,

25
00:01:07.760 --> 00:01:10.750
I'm gonna actually show you the agent,
I'm gonna show you the settings.

26
00:01:10.750 --> 00:01:12.480
We haven't really previewed
the agent up until now.

27
00:01:12.480 --> 00:01:14.920
We've been talking about it, but
we actually have it installed.

28
00:01:14.920 --> 00:01:16.690
We'll go and we'll take a look at what
it looks like in the control panel.

29
00:01:16.690 --> 00:01:20.600
We'll pull up the agent and show you what
the settings are once they are pushed

30
00:01:20.600 --> 00:01:22.880
the management point and configured.

31
00:01:22.880 --> 00:01:25.300
We'll go in and
we'll make a change to the hardware.

32
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:26.630
Agent settings.

33
00:01:26.630 --> 00:01:28.790
So, we'll see how to customize
what's called a mav file,

34
00:01:28.790 --> 00:01:33.040
the sms_desktopmavfile,
to update and modify and

35
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:35.410
configure the inventory to be
done a slightly different way.

36
00:01:35.410 --> 00:01:39.580
We'll take a look at wmi classes and
maybe add in an inventory class just for

37
00:01:39.580 --> 00:01:40.590
good measure.

38
00:01:40.590 --> 00:01:43.190
And then, we'll go through,
we'll run an inventory cycle.

39
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:45.340
We'll do a hardware and
a software inventory.

40
00:01:45.340 --> 00:01:47.360
We'll then look at the resources for it.

41
00:01:47.360 --> 00:01:50.240
At least we'll talk about what it is,
see what the outcome of that looks like.

42
00:01:50.240 --> 00:01:51.777
So we'll do a full little
runaround that way.

43
00:01:51.777 --> 00:01:56.014
Before we get started with that, I know
that we have put together just a couple of

44
00:01:56.014 --> 00:02:00.504
little list items for you, as we often do,
set the tone, give you a little appetizer

45
00:02:00.504 --> 00:02:04.553
for your knowledge palate, if you will,
and get you excited about the whole

46
00:02:04.553 --> 00:02:08.650
concept of inventory because if we
don't it is rather dry and boring.

47
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:11.230
So we're going to do that for
you to get you thinking about it and

48
00:02:11.230 --> 00:02:12.580
get you up and running.

49
00:02:12.580 --> 00:02:15.330
So what I want to do is to just really
throw out some items that are going to

50
00:02:15.330 --> 00:02:19.680
be helpful for you to remember, to think
about kind of get you organized around

51
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:23.650
as we start thinking about getting into
and ultimately doing our hands-on demo.

52
00:02:23.650 --> 00:02:25.890
So what do we use hardware and
software inventories for?

53
00:02:25.890 --> 00:02:27.420
We've talked about this already.

54
00:02:27.420 --> 00:02:30.720
The idea is obviously we wanna make sure
that we can think through gathering up

55
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:33.330
this information, and when we get it,
what do we do with it?

56
00:02:33.330 --> 00:02:35.335
We may wanna report on it.

57
00:02:35.335 --> 00:02:38.094
May wanna be able to look at
compliance activities and

58
00:02:38.094 --> 00:02:41.420
specify whether a certain machine
is configured a certain way.

59
00:02:41.420 --> 00:02:46.880
So we think about what's called GRC,
governance risk and compliance activities.

60
00:02:46.880 --> 00:02:52.380
Within the organization, and inventory can
help us to drive through and manage this.

61
00:02:52.380 --> 00:02:54.550
We may think about getting ready for
an audit.

62
00:02:54.550 --> 00:02:58.168
Somebody may be coming in, and they want
to see how certain machines are set up,

63
00:02:58.168 --> 00:03:00.730
how they're configured,
how they're managed.

64
00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:02.600
We can validate that by
showing them the inventory.

65
00:03:02.600 --> 00:03:04.535
So troubleshooting client problems,

66
00:03:04.535 --> 00:03:08.521
maintaining corporate standards based
on policy, collection of files through

67
00:03:08.521 --> 00:03:12.730
software inventory to validate that
a certain system's set up a certain way.

68
00:03:12.730 --> 00:03:17.410
And all these things can be done through
inventory, so, some of the uses of or

69
00:03:17.410 --> 00:03:20.890
the management uses of hardware and
software inventory very important.

70
00:03:20.890 --> 00:03:23.040
How is software inventory
going to be collected?

71
00:03:23.040 --> 00:03:25.890
What is the software inventory process?

72
00:03:25.890 --> 00:03:28.740
When we think about it we
collect data directly from

73
00:03:28.740 --> 00:03:31.610
files by reading the file header and
then gathering it up.

74
00:03:31.610 --> 00:03:36.170
So if we say hey we want everything that's
got a .txt extension, we're gonna look for

75
00:03:36.170 --> 00:03:38.980
all that, look at the metadata
to validate the file type,

76
00:03:38.980 --> 00:03:41.500
gather that information up and
then collect it.

77
00:03:41.500 --> 00:03:43.930
So we're gonna go through and
be able to pull that in.

78
00:03:43.930 --> 00:03:46.292
We are gonna use, and
I did talk about the Resource Explorer,

79
00:03:46.292 --> 00:03:47.850
I mentioned it down there at the bottom.

80
00:03:47.850 --> 00:03:48.970
We're gonna use that or

81
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:52.510
at least take a look at that tool
once we're done with the inventory.

82
00:03:52.510 --> 00:03:55.954
And we're gonna then be able to see
what software is running on a system,

83
00:03:55.954 --> 00:03:57.761
and/or what hardware inventory is,

84
00:03:57.761 --> 00:04:00.880
and actually drill down and
see what the settings are in a system.

85
00:04:00.880 --> 00:04:04.396
Not in real time, because it is flat
based on the captured inventory and

86
00:04:04.396 --> 00:04:06.180
the last time it was captured.

87
00:04:06.180 --> 00:04:07.747
So it's not dynamic, it is static, but

88
00:04:07.747 --> 00:04:10.850
it's gonna show us very detailed granular
information based on what is there.

89
00:04:10.850 --> 00:04:12.850
So it's gonna be kinda cool.

90
00:04:12.850 --> 00:04:14.660
So think about that.

91
00:04:14.660 --> 00:04:15.389
Now some do's and

92
00:04:15.389 --> 00:04:18.460
don't's from a security perspective
with regards to client inventory.

93
00:04:18.460 --> 00:04:22.598
We should enable inventory encryption,
we should in other words make sure that

94
00:04:22.598 --> 00:04:25.700
the inventory data is sent and
received in encrypted form.

95
00:04:25.700 --> 00:04:28.490
That way nobody can snoop that data and
potentially take it off the wire.

96
00:04:28.490 --> 00:04:31.840
We might want to disable
MIF file collections.

97
00:04:31.840 --> 00:04:34.760
The MIF concept we talked a little bit
about this when we did this, is going to

98
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:40.020
allow us to extend the inventory and as a
result of that get additional information.

99
00:04:40.020 --> 00:04:43.980
We may not want to do that because we may
not want to expose proprietary information

100
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:47.030
and the specifics of
configuration that we are using.

101
00:04:47.030 --> 00:04:48.710
So we may not actually want to do that.

102
00:04:48.710 --> 00:04:52.780
That will be up to us because those MIF
files can then actually be snooped by

103
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:55.870
somebody, or gathered off the system and
used to figure out how systems

104
00:04:55.870 --> 00:04:59.330
are inventoried, or excuse me, how they
are configured based on the inventory.

105
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:02.500
And that can lead to security
complications, so just be aware of that.

106
00:05:02.500 --> 00:05:06.920
If we are using File Collection and we
are getting copies of critical files and

107
00:05:06.920 --> 00:05:08.520
we are storing them on the server.

108
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:12.380
Again, we have an issue they're storing
sense of proprietary information.

109
00:05:12.380 --> 00:05:16.140
Somebody maybe have gather that and
use it against us think about that.

110
00:05:16.140 --> 00:05:20.201
And we also want to set specific deletion
intervals for older inventory data and

111
00:05:20.201 --> 00:05:23.945
collected files we were generically
called retention period, right.

112
00:05:23.945 --> 00:05:26.450
Because we don't want to leave
this stuff playing around forever,

113
00:05:26.450 --> 00:05:28.410
we could run into some issues.

114
00:05:28.410 --> 00:05:29.690
And some concerns right?

115
00:05:29.690 --> 00:05:33.251
So just wanna be aware of that thing about
that, Mike's getting a little excited and

116
00:05:33.251 --> 00:05:36.163
scrolling down there while I'm
talking before I'm actually able to

117
00:05:36.163 --> 00:05:37.320
finish my point.

118
00:05:37.320 --> 00:05:39.910
We're gonna come back to that stuff
Mike was just about to preview for

119
00:05:39.910 --> 00:05:43.850
