789
00:38:15.560 --> 00:38:17.180
more end points that we're monitoring.

790
00:38:17.180 --> 00:38:20.310
Now this is another one of the client
agent settings, we had a setting for

791
00:38:20.310 --> 00:38:22.230
software metering to enable it.

792
00:38:22.230 --> 00:38:25.660
I told you that although we monitor and
do a refresh every 7 days,

793
00:38:25.660 --> 00:38:28.260
we have to get 30 days worth
of data to run the reports.

794
00:38:28.260 --> 00:38:29.540
So that's just something to consider,

795
00:38:29.540 --> 00:38:31.550
but what we did was put
together a little picture for

796
00:38:31.550 --> 00:38:34.970
you that helps us to understand how
software metering actually works.

797
00:38:34.970 --> 00:38:36.220
So let's just quickly take a look,

798
00:38:36.220 --> 00:38:38.470
cuz I just want to make sure
you understand this as well.

799
00:38:38.470 --> 00:38:40.990
Mike was kind enough to do a little
numbering for us to help us keep

800
00:38:40.990 --> 00:38:44.790
track of things and made the steps
down below there match the numbers, so

801
00:38:44.790 --> 00:38:46.940
that way we can kinda keep
track of what's happening.

802
00:38:46.940 --> 00:38:50.350
So you'll see in Step 1, and as we always
do, let's just break down the diagram,

803
00:38:50.350 --> 00:38:51.900
make sure everybody knows
what we're looking at.

804
00:38:51.900 --> 00:38:55.080
On the left hand side, we have an
endpoint, a client that's being managed.

805
00:38:56.270 --> 00:38:57.540
We have some monitor programs,

806
00:38:57.540 --> 00:39:00.260
this little rectangular boxes with
the arrows coming out of them.

807
00:39:00.260 --> 00:39:03.240
Represent Monitored Programs
as he's labeled up above.

808
00:39:03.240 --> 00:39:08.360
And so those are things like Microsoft
Word or Notepad or Pinball or whatever.

809
00:39:08.360 --> 00:39:09.357
I do miss Pinball by the way.

810
00:39:09.357 --> 00:39:09.902
>> [LAUGH] That was a good one.

811
00:39:09.902 --> 00:39:10.599
>> That was an awesome game.

812
00:39:10.599 --> 00:39:13.450
Pinball or something like
that that we may be running.

813
00:39:13.450 --> 00:39:16.220
So those of you that are into
slacking off at work and

814
00:39:16.220 --> 00:39:19.870
running programs you're not supposed to,
be forewarned and beware we can tell what

815
00:39:19.870 --> 00:39:23.830
you're doing cuz with software metering we
can look at all the executables that run.

816
00:39:23.830 --> 00:39:25.315
So big brother is watching you.

817
00:39:25.315 --> 00:39:26.898
>> Amen.
>> And we've known that for some time but

818
00:39:26.898 --> 00:39:28.080
now we can actually prove it.

819
00:39:28.080 --> 00:39:29.730
So we have monitor programs.

820
00:39:29.730 --> 00:39:30.960
So those are gonna run.

821
00:39:30.960 --> 00:39:32.870
Then the software metering
agent is running and

822
00:39:32.870 --> 00:39:35.190
capturing ever time an executable is used.

823
00:39:35.190 --> 00:39:38.753
When that executable is fired off,
we make a note in our little notepad and

824
00:39:38.753 --> 00:39:42.087
then we actually upload that data
into the management point when we do

825
00:39:42.087 --> 00:39:43.360
a policy refresh.

826
00:39:43.360 --> 00:39:47.640
Or rather a policy cycle, so every seven
days for software metering we take all

827
00:39:47.640 --> 00:39:52.110
that data of the client, upload it into
the site server and the management point.

828
00:39:52.110 --> 00:39:54.900
That then ultimately forwards
the data from the manage

829
00:39:56.010 --> 00:39:59.500
point over to the site server, over to
the site server database in step 4.

830
00:39:59.500 --> 00:40:04.270
Records that, and then we can use
recording to go in and to actually then

831
00:40:04.270 --> 00:40:07.540
take a look at that, or at least in
theory if we have reporting set up.

832
00:40:07.540 --> 00:40:09.600
We can certainly go in and
we can take a look at that.

833
00:40:09.600 --> 00:40:14.990
And so the idea is that we can go in and
we actually then use one or more reports.

834
00:40:14.990 --> 00:40:17.530
And there's over 400
reports we can access.

835
00:40:17.530 --> 00:40:20.730
There's a whole bunch, not specific
just to software metering and usage, but

836
00:40:20.730 --> 00:40:24.330
there's a bunch specific to that,
we can access those reports and

837
00:40:24.330 --> 00:40:27.740
we're gonna set up software,
excuse me, not software, metering.

838
00:40:27.740 --> 00:40:31.050
We're gonna set up reporting
in an upcoming episode and

839
00:40:31.050 --> 00:40:32.120
we'll show you how to do that.

840
00:40:32.120 --> 00:40:35.300
And once those reports are in, you can
see all the categories of reports and

841
00:40:35.300 --> 00:40:36.040
see what they are.

842
00:40:36.040 --> 00:40:39.260
We would then be able to pull a report or
several that show us what kind of

843
00:40:39.260 --> 00:40:41.590
executables are running,
how often, on what machines.

844
00:40:41.590 --> 00:40:45.640
It's also good for licensing true up and
licensing evaluation.

845
00:40:45.640 --> 00:40:49.070
because one of the things we
can do is debunk that myth

846
00:40:49.070 --> 00:40:52.330
that we often hear about where people say,
oh I need this software or that software.

847
00:40:52.330 --> 00:40:55.320
A lot of people will say, no,
I have to have a copy of Access or

848
00:40:55.320 --> 00:40:57.660
I have to have a copy of Project or Visio.

849
00:40:57.660 --> 00:41:01.730
I love having these conversations with
customers, because at $250.00 a copy

850
00:41:01.730 --> 00:41:04.060
you can have as many as you want
as long as you write a check.

851
00:41:04.060 --> 00:41:08.350
But the reality is that most people
that request that software never use it,

852
00:41:08.350 --> 00:41:10.380
it's the monkey see, monkey do phenomenon.

853
00:41:10.380 --> 00:41:11.925
I'm being kind when I say that by the way.

854
00:41:11.925 --> 00:41:15.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because I mean that in the most

855
00:41:15.370 --> 00:41:17.370
kind way I possibly can,
not that you're a monkey but

856
00:41:17.370 --> 00:41:19.460
that you're parroting people around you.

857
00:41:19.460 --> 00:41:22.532
But the idea is that a lot of
people will say, well so so and so

858
00:41:22.532 --> 00:41:24.262
has that software so I want it to.

859
00:41:24.262 --> 00:41:27.047
Well you may want it, but
the reality is, are you really using it?

860
00:41:27.047 --> 00:41:30.749
An you know, up until recently, it's been
hard for us to equivocally say, well yeah,

861
00:41:30.749 --> 00:41:32.130
you're using it a lot.

862
00:41:32.130 --> 00:41:35.160
But now that we do software metering
we could look at executable launch,

863
00:41:35.160 --> 00:41:39.410
we actually can say, wow, you really are
using that software, like ten times a day.

864
00:41:39.410 --> 00:41:41.710
Now you may be smart enough to realize
all you have to do is go in there and

865
00:41:41.710 --> 00:41:42.785
click, open it up.

866
00:41:42.785 --> 00:41:44.770
[LAUGH] And then we say,
oh yeah, you used it and

867
00:41:44.770 --> 00:41:47.180
justify that even though you never use it.

868
00:41:47.180 --> 00:41:50.550
But the report will show that you launched
the product a certain number of times.

869
00:41:50.550 --> 00:41:54.270
So we don't actually look at usage from
a time perspective, just to be clear,

870
00:41:54.270 --> 00:41:57.900
we're simply looking at it and reporting
on it based on executable launches.

871
00:41:57.900 --> 00:42:01.700
So but we can tell if somebody's actually
using that software and if so how often.

872
00:42:01.700 --> 00:42:04.360
So that is just something
else to be aware of.

873
00:42:04.360 --> 00:42:05.960
>> All right.
Again, as usual,

874
00:42:05.960 --> 00:42:07.770
another fantastic episode, Adam.

875
00:42:07.770 --> 00:42:12.370
A great look at doing our hardware and our
software inventories, and a little bit of

876
00:42:12.370 --> 00:42:15.640
software metering there, talked about
reporting, a lot of great stuff.

877
00:42:15.640 --> 00:42:17.530
Hope you guys enjoyed that one.

878
00:42:17.530 --> 00:42:20.010
Remember, if you wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live,

879
00:42:20.010 --> 00:42:23.330
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

880
00:42:23.330 --> 00:42:24.980
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

881
00:42:24.980 --> 00:42:26.040
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

882
00:42:26.040 --> 00:42:27.182
>> And we'll see you next time.

883
00:42:27.182 --> 00:42:28.308
>> Take care, everybody.

884
00:42:28.308 --> 00:42:33.800
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss writing queries and generating reports. They talk about the Windows Query Language and the information that can be queried. Then they look at reporting services and how to generate reports.
episodes.title: Queries and Reports
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.868 --> 00:00:15.541
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV,

3
00:00:15.541 --> 00:00:17.241
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.241 --> 00:00:20.990
Today we are doing our SCCM 2012R2.

5
00:00:20.990 --> 00:00:25.290
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna focus on queries and reports, right?

6
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:28.523
We've talked a little bit about
those in previous episodes,

7
00:00:28.523 --> 00:00:32.580
now we're gonna delve into the world of
WMI queries and all of that fun stuff.

8
00:00:32.580 --> 00:00:35.820
So we're gonna start learning another
language in this episode, how about that?

9
00:00:35.820 --> 00:00:38.997
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Adam Gordon, how are you doing, Adam?

10
00:00:38.997 --> 00:00:41.728
>> [FOREIGN]
>> [LAUGH]

11
00:00:41.728 --> 00:00:45.388
>> [FOREIGN] Mike.

12
00:00:45.388 --> 00:00:49.030
>> [LAUGH] Wait let me say that again,
[FOREIGN], okay, good.

13
00:00:49.030 --> 00:00:49.900
>> Did I get that right?

14
00:00:49.900 --> 00:00:50.480
>> I think so.

15
00:00:50.480 --> 00:00:52.460
>> I have to represent
some from South Florida.

16
00:00:52.460 --> 00:00:54.260
If I didn't get that right,
I couldn't go back home.

17
00:00:54.260 --> 00:00:58.090
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we are going to learn how to speak

18
00:00:58.090 --> 00:01:00.130
another language,
I actually like how Mike put that.

19
00:01:00.130 --> 00:01:04.860
That is a great way to start thinking
about reporting and more importantly,

20
00:01:04.860 --> 00:01:05.435
about querying.

21
00:01:05.435 --> 00:01:10.300
Cuz the two are related, but querying is
really the idea and ultimately the art and

22
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:13.480
science of being able to use,
in this case,

23
00:01:13.480 --> 00:01:17.195
WQL, the WMI query language
to be able to ask questions.

24
00:01:17.195 --> 00:01:21.530
And queries on the surface actually
sound fairly straightforward.

25
00:01:21.530 --> 00:01:22.720
What time is it, right?

26
00:01:22.720 --> 00:01:24.530
What status is the system?

27
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:25.760
Is the system on?

28
00:01:25.760 --> 00:01:26.730
Is the system off?

29
00:01:26.730 --> 00:01:28.270
Does Mike know what the intro is?

30
00:01:28.270 --> 00:01:29.870
Does he not know what the intro is?

31
00:01:29.870 --> 00:01:32.240
We can ask these questions, we can query.

32
00:01:32.240 --> 00:01:34.010
In many cases, the answer is yes.

33
00:01:34.010 --> 00:01:37.520
In some cases, as in with the intro,
the answer may be no for Mike.

34
00:01:37.520 --> 00:01:41.135
So the reality is when we ask a query,
we are effectively asking or

35
00:01:41.135 --> 00:01:45.510
when we pose a query, we create one and
we use it, we are posing a question.

36
00:01:45.510 --> 00:01:49.860
And when we think about queries from the
perspective of, if I ask a question and

37
00:01:49.860 --> 00:01:52.580
I understand how to frame
the question in such a way

38
00:01:52.580 --> 00:01:57.020
that the answer has to either be yes,
no, true, false, on, off.

39
00:01:57.020 --> 00:02:01.020
Kind of those kinds of queries,
those kinds of questions.

40
00:02:01.020 --> 00:02:02.730
That or what we would call black and
white, right?

41
00:02:02.730 --> 00:02:04.310
There's no room for gray.

42
00:02:04.310 --> 00:02:08.430
There's either an established answer
that is of one or another type.

43
00:02:08.430 --> 00:02:13.330
We can begin to think about how to use
queries in such a way that we can use them

44
00:02:13.330 --> 00:02:14.760
to accomplish several things.

45
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:20.860
We can check status, we can understand the
current state, what the desired state is.

46
00:02:20.860 --> 00:02:25.510
What the potential difference between the
desired state and the current state is.

47
00:02:25.510 --> 00:02:30.510
And we also can look at what is actively
going on and measure those values.

48
00:02:30.510 --> 00:02:33.360
And understand whether they
represent what we expect or

49
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:36.910
what we would hopefully not wanna see but
may have occurring.

50
00:02:36.910 --> 00:02:40.880
So we could be above or below a threshold,
we could ask queries about that.

51
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:44.640
We can be of a certain type or
be doing a certain thing, so

52
00:02:44.640 --> 00:02:47.270
a system can be managed and
maybe unmanaged.

53
00:02:47.270 --> 00:02:51.210
A system may have an agent in
a current state or similar state, but

54
00:02:51.210 --> 00:02:52.800
not one that we're looking for.

55
00:02:52.800 --> 00:02:55.559
So queries can do all sorts of things for
us and

56
00:02:55.559 --> 00:02:57.840
we think about the logic of queries.

57
00:02:57.840 --> 00:03:01.520
What we have to really think about
is how do I wanna frame the question

58
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:04.340
in such a way that the answer
that comes back makes sense for

59
00:03:04.340 --> 00:03:05.460
what I'm looking to accomplish.

60
00:03:05.460 --> 00:03:08.520
There's more than one way to
ask a question, for instance,

61
00:03:08.520 --> 00:03:10.320
I can ask an open-ended question.

62
00:03:10.320 --> 00:03:12.560
Good morning, how are you?

63
00:03:12.560 --> 00:03:15.200
There could be a lot of ways you
may choose to answer that question.

64
00:03:15.200 --> 00:03:17.560
You may say, oh good morning, I'm good.

65
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:18.090
You may say,

66
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:22.420
good morning and then I may get 20
minutes of what's going on in your life.

67
00:03:22.420 --> 00:03:25.131
I've stopped paying attention by the way
right after good morning, typically.

68
00:03:25.131 --> 00:03:28.911
So you're talking, but I'm not
really capturing anything of value.

69
00:03:28.911 --> 00:03:33.160
Not because I don't want to, but because
it's just boring and I really don't care.

70
00:03:33.160 --> 00:03:37.110
So, the reality of the question
being open-ended is

71
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:41.420
I'm probably gonna get back a lot more
information than either I want, I need or

72
00:03:41.420 --> 00:03:43.840
I can process and realistically use.

73
00:03:43.840 --> 00:03:45.810
So if I ask open-ended questions,

74
00:03:45.810 --> 00:03:50.040
probably not gonna get a lot of stuff
that's valuable and easily consumable.

75
00:03:50.040 --> 00:03:54.640
But if I ask targeted,
specific questions geared towards or

76
00:03:54.640 --> 00:03:59.060
focused on a very well-defined and
quantifiable.

77
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:01.710
This is an important thought
process with queries.

78
00:04:01.710 --> 00:04:06.390
Quantification or quantifiability,
I'm making up words as I go here.

79
00:04:06.390 --> 00:04:10.860
Quantification is the idea, the art,
the science in measuring something, right?

80
00:04:10.860 --> 00:04:15.610
And if we ask a query and we focus it
in such a way that it is measurable.

81
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:20.180
It has the ability, the query,
to produce an outcome that we can measure,

82
00:04:20.180 --> 00:04:23.260
that we can understand,
that we can create value with.

83
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:26.550
Then that query is gonna produce something
that's gonna be very important for us.

84
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:30.490
So instead of saying or asking you,
good morning, how are you?

85
00:04:30.490 --> 00:04:34.640
I may say on a scale of one to five,
how happy are you this morning?

86
00:04:34.640 --> 00:04:39.880
One being, I need Prozac, five being I
couldn't be happier if I tried, right?

87
00:04:39.880 --> 00:04:44.708
And then somewhere on that scale, I need
you to quantify, I need you to assess and

88
00:04:44.708 --> 00:04:47.270
measure your state of happiness, right?

89
00:04:47.270 --> 00:04:48.772
Given the smile on Mike's face,

90
00:04:48.772 --> 00:04:52.270
I'm thinking he doesn't need any sort
of medication this morning, right?

91
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:53.040
>> Or I've already had it.

92
00:04:53.040 --> 00:04:56.020
>> Or he may have already taken it,
in which case it's now kicking in and

93
00:04:56.020 --> 00:04:58.550
he's gonna have that smile for
some time to come.

94
00:04:58.550 --> 00:05:02.170
Either way, the point is Mike looks
like he's on the upside of that scale.

95
00:05:02.170 --> 00:05:04.520
He looks like he's somewhere
between four and five and

96
00:05:04.520 --> 00:05:06.060
not on the low end of that scale.

97
00:05:06.060 --> 00:05:09.050
Down in the dumps so to speak or
the doldrums, down towards the ones and

98
00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:10.010
twos, right?

99
00:05:10.010 --> 00:05:14.690
And so we can create a closed-ended
question, kind of a focused question,

100
00:05:14.690 --> 00:05:16.660
a focused query, by planning.

101
00:05:16.660 --> 00:05:19.001
And we keep coming back to that
idea of planning over and over and

102
00:05:19.001 --> 00:05:20.820
over again in our conversations.

103
00:05:20.820 --> 00:05:23.200
The art and
science of querying is really the art and

104
00:05:23.200 --> 00:05:26.990
science of figuring out what
it is you want to know.

105
00:05:26.990 --> 00:05:29.810
And then figuring out
the best way to ask the query

106
00:05:29.810 --> 00:05:33.740
to achieve that end result with
the least amount of work possible, but

107
00:05:33.740 --> 00:05:37.150
the maximum opportunity
to get that information.

108
00:05:37.150 --> 00:05:40.830
And it sounds hard on the surface when
we talk about it in the abstract.

109
00:05:40.830 --> 00:05:43.410
Which is why we're actually just gonna
ditch the rest of this episode and

110
00:05:43.410 --> 00:05:44.030
not do anything else.

111
00:05:44.030 --> 00:05:47.315
Cuz it's impossible to do and
I don't know what else to tell you.

112
00:05:47.315 --> 00:05:50.155
We're gonna scratch this one and
move on to something more exciting.

113
00:05:50.155 --> 00:05:53.535
I'm only kidding, if you're listening,
don't go away, we are not gonna do that,

114
00:05:53.535 --> 00:05:54.525
I'm only kidding.

115
00:05:54.525 --> 00:05:55.975
My point with this is that,

116
00:05:55.975 --> 00:05:59.309
it sounds hard on the surface because
when we talk about queries, right?

117
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:03.310
We're talking in the abstract
until we actually do it.

118
00:06:03.310 --> 00:06:05.043
And when we do the queries,
you're gonna see and

119
00:06:05.043 --> 00:06:07.680
we are gonna show you how to write them,
we're gonna take them apart.

120
00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:09.809
Explain to you how they work,
put them back together again,

121
00:06:09.809 --> 00:06:11.920
make sure you're comfortable
with how to create queries.

122
00:06:11.920 --> 00:06:16.078
When you see it done, you begin to
see that although there is definitely

123
00:06:16.078 --> 00:06:20.789
investment of time and energy you need to
put in to understand, not only WQL, but

124
00:06:20.789 --> 00:06:23.650
the object class model
that Windows is built on.

125
00:06:23.650 --> 00:06:25.730
We're gonna debunk that for
you a little bit here.

126
00:06:25.730 --> 00:06:28.950
Mike put together a nice little graphic
for us, we're gonna take a look at that.

127
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:32.123
And we've got a little website URL we're
gonna show you in a minute that'll give

00:09:18.075 --> 00:09:19.250

00:09:49.330 --> 00:09:50.860

You know, with the advent of virtual

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike look at Endpoint Protection. They demonstrate how to integrate Endpoint Protection into SCCM 2012 R2, to allow for centralized management. They show how we can use endpoint Protection to manage antimalware settings as well as firewall settings.

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike look at some lesser used features and capabilities of SCCM 2012 R2. They start with the remote tool set, which allows for remotely managing a machine via the agent. They also look at using Windows Intune to manage mobile devices.

00:31:13.770 --> 00:31:15.880
using Hyper -V as the hypervisor.

637
00:31:15.880 --> 00:31:19.050
We've got the system center
service level manager,

638
00:31:19.050 --> 00:31:22.200
the SLM product that does our
help desk our ticketing and

639
00:31:22.200 --> 00:31:25.690
our coordination, so
yeah we've got all these different pieces.

640
00:31:25.690 --> 00:31:28.000
All of them are being
integrated number one and

641
00:31:28.000 --> 00:31:30.800
all of them now are going to have
cross-platform support number two.

642
00:31:30.800 --> 00:31:34.820
Which means that if we manage those Linux
and Unix clients the way we just showed

643
00:31:34.820 --> 00:31:37.850
you here we can continuously
monitor them using SCOM.

644
00:31:37.850 --> 00:31:39.290
We could set up ticketing, and

645
00:31:39.290 --> 00:31:41.920
track our incident and
response management throughout SLM.

646
00:31:41.920 --> 00:31:44.910
And we could virtualize
them using a CVM map,

647
00:31:44.910 --> 00:31:48.930
a complete resource management capability
across the entire infrastructure.

648
00:31:48.930 --> 00:31:51.770
So, my parting words of
wisdom would really be,

649
00:31:51.770 --> 00:31:55.880
look to your infrastructure,
look to your cross-platform support, and

650
00:31:55.880 --> 00:31:59.460
understand that this suite of
products is really enterprise-ready.

651
00:31:59.460 --> 00:32:01.350
And can do anything you need it to do.

652
00:32:01.350 --> 00:32:04.520
And all you have to understand how
to do is enable the support and

653
00:32:04.520 --> 00:32:05.860
then take advantage of it.

654
00:32:05.860 --> 00:32:07.210
>> Great information as always.

655
00:32:07.210 --> 00:32:08.500
>> Adam, thank you for being here and

656
00:32:08.500 --> 00:32:11.010
making the complex a little
bit more simplistic but

657
00:32:11.010 --> 00:32:14.960
it does look like we're gonna go ahead and
sign out here for ITProTV.

658
00:32:14.960 --> 00:32:16.530
So I've been your host Wes Bryan.

659
00:32:16.530 --> 00:32:19.490
>> I actually like to think of it
as making the simple complex but

660
00:32:19.490 --> 00:32:22.140
that's just me, that's how I
>> prefer to view life, right?

661
00:32:22.140 --> 00:32:24.580
Gives me more things to talk about and
keeps me busy.

662
00:32:24.580 --> 00:32:27.420
I'm your host, Mr.
Complexity, Adam Gordon.

663
00:32:27.420 --> 00:32:28.440
>> And, we'll see you next time.

664
00:32:28.440 --> 00:32:29.869
>> Take care everybody.

665
00:32:29.869 --> 00:32:38.560
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Adam discuss the process of migrating from a SCCM 2007 infrastructure to SCCM 2012R2. They explore the migration process and the components needed to perform a successful migration. They also will demonstrate how to clean up residual data left behind after the migration has been performed.
episodes.title: SCCM 2007 to 2012R2 Migration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.347 --> 00:00:13.970
Welcome to ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.970 --> 00:00:15.160
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:15.160 --> 00:00:18.690
And in today's episode, we're gonna be
continuing our journey through SCCM.

5
00:00:18.690 --> 00:00:23.150
And joining me in the studio today
is none other than Mr. Adam Gordon.

6
00:00:23.150 --> 00:00:24.135
How are you doing today, Adam?

7
00:00:24.135 --> 00:00:25.230
>> [LAUGH] I'm doing well.

8
00:00:25.230 --> 00:00:26.220
Thank you, Wes.

9
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:26.990
Good to see everybody.

10
00:00:26.990 --> 00:00:28.620
Hopefully everybody's
doing well out there.

11
00:00:28.620 --> 00:00:31.360
And hopefully you have a comfortable
chair that you're sitting in.

12
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:33.742
This is gonna be a bit
of a long discussion.

13
00:00:33.742 --> 00:00:38.503
We're gonna walk you through what
the migration path looks like from SCCM

14
00:00:38.503 --> 00:00:40.433
2007 into 2012 R2.

15
00:00:40.433 --> 00:00:44.370
We're gonna spend some time and Wes and
I are gonna chat a little bit first.

16
00:00:44.370 --> 00:00:47.779
He's been kind enough to go out and
find all sorts of great documentation for

17
00:00:47.779 --> 00:00:51.451
you and we're gonna show you as well, how
to do this, the right way to get it done,

18
00:00:51.451 --> 00:00:52.538
things you wanna know.

19
00:00:52.538 --> 00:00:56.152
And then once we've done that and we've
taken a look at some pretty pictures,

20
00:00:56.152 --> 00:00:59.599
type out some do's and don'ts,
we're gonna go in as we usually try to do,

21
00:00:59.599 --> 00:01:03.078
especially with something like this,
spin up a demo environment for you.

22
00:01:03.078 --> 00:01:06.703
And we're gonna spend a nice amount
of time walking through slowly but

23
00:01:06.703 --> 00:01:10.392
surely, talking about everything we
need to accomplish to ensure that

24
00:01:10.392 --> 00:01:14.410
we get successfully out of 2007
into our 2012 R2 environment.

25
00:01:14.410 --> 00:01:16.050
And how we're gonna make that work.

26
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:17.150
So that way, as we're done, and

27
00:01:17.150 --> 00:01:20.960
we finish that migration path, we've got
all our infrastructure accounted for.

28
00:01:20.960 --> 00:01:24.510
Our clients are migrated over,
our distribution points are available.

29
00:01:24.510 --> 00:01:28.030
We've cleaned up all the backend
data after migration.

30
00:01:28.030 --> 00:01:31.868
Disconnected, that connector that
pulls the data in from 2007.

31
00:01:31.868 --> 00:01:34.839
One of the most important things
we can do, ultimately, and

32
00:01:34.839 --> 00:01:36.380
then we'll be set to go.

33
00:01:36.380 --> 00:01:39.730
So let's kick this off by starting
to talk about what a migration path

34
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:40.930
actually looks like.

35
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:43.510
And to that end, I believe we
have a nice little picture for

36
00:01:43.510 --> 00:01:46.890
our friendly neighborhood folk
out there in ITProTV land.

37
00:01:46.890 --> 00:01:50.371
So what we're gonna be able to see is,
and actually I think we need to go,

38
00:01:50.371 --> 00:01:52.556
get me out of that picture and
go full screen.

39
00:01:52.556 --> 00:01:53.425
There we go.

40
00:01:53.425 --> 00:01:57.280
Cuz you don't wanna look at me, you wanna
look at the diagram that we have for you.

41
00:01:57.280 --> 00:01:59.424
What we're gonna do is we're gonna talk
about talk about the migration process.

42
00:01:59.424 --> 00:02:01.863
Now on the left, as you can see labelled,

43
00:02:01.863 --> 00:02:06.490
just to make sure we're all on the same
page, we have our source hierarchy.

44
00:02:06.490 --> 00:02:08.778
That's our config manager
2007 infrastructure.

45
00:02:08.778 --> 00:02:12.140
We're not gonna worry about those
colored lines for just a minute,

46
00:02:12.140 --> 00:02:15.750
we'll talk about those and
how they happen and why in just a second.

47
00:02:15.750 --> 00:02:19.350
On the right are new hierarchy
is essentially our targets.

48
00:02:19.350 --> 00:02:21.020
Now it does say config manager 2012.

49
00:02:21.020 --> 00:02:25.991
It could be 2012, 2012 SP1, 2012 R2.

50
00:02:25.991 --> 00:02:31.342
We just left it generic because
the migration path from any 2007 instance

51
00:02:31.342 --> 00:02:37.614
into the 12 X platform, 12, 12 SP1,12
bar 2, is gonna look and feel the same.

52
00:02:37.614 --> 00:02:39.797
So as a result we're not
too worried about that,

53
00:02:39.797 --> 00:02:42.580
we just wanna know it's moving
to the 12 platform, right?

54
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:43.850
So we're going to see that.

55
00:02:43.850 --> 00:02:48.682
Now, let's also talk about some of the
infrastructure that we see there, and just

56
00:02:48.682 --> 00:02:53.307
make sure that we understand the names,
and understand how we refer to things,

57
00:02:53.307 --> 00:02:57.060
because in 2007 we would call
a primary site a central site.

58
00:02:57.060 --> 00:02:58.640
And maybe we could zoom in real quick.

59
00:02:58.640 --> 00:03:00.680
Upper left hand corner there, Wes.

60
00:03:00.680 --> 00:03:01.570
Outstanding, right there.

61
00:03:01.570 --> 00:03:04.610
Yeah.
And so we'll see that the central site,

62
00:03:04.610 --> 00:03:09.130
which is the top of the hierarchy in 2007,
is referred to as our primary site.

63
00:03:09.130 --> 00:03:11.910
Now if we just simply
move right directly over.

64
00:03:11.910 --> 00:03:12.900
Right, horizontally there.

65
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:13.930
Perfect, to the right.

66
00:03:13.930 --> 00:03:18.280
We'll see the central admin site in 2012,
what we call the CAS.

67
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:20.990
Not to be confused with
the CAS we have for

68
00:03:20.990 --> 00:03:25.020
the client access points in
the exchange infrastructure,

69
00:03:25.020 --> 00:03:27.980
actually we have a CAS there as well,
we're not gonna worry about that.

70
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:31.340
But the idea is the same,
we have our central admin site there and

71
00:03:31.340 --> 00:03:35.230
then notice primary sites are below
the central admin site In 2012.

72
00:03:35.230 --> 00:03:41.780
Now we've talked a lot in our overview
episode in our architecture episodes.

73
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:46.150
We have two of them that we put together
for you on this particular solution.

74
00:03:46.150 --> 00:03:50.440
That the primary site is going to
be usually the top of the hierarchy

75
00:03:50.440 --> 00:03:52.340
in a small environment.

76
00:03:52.340 --> 00:03:56.820
But if we do in 2012 setup
a scaled enterprise environment,

77
00:03:56.820 --> 00:03:59.070
we put the central admin site in place,

78
00:03:59.070 --> 00:04:03.080
to have essentially aggregation
of all the primary sites, plural,

79
00:04:03.080 --> 00:04:07.170
information and their associated secondary
sites that we happen to have any.

80
00:04:07.170 --> 00:04:09.990
We'll see one at the lower
right hand corner down there,

81
00:04:09.990 --> 00:04:12.650
across from the distribution point,
to see a secondary site.

82
00:04:12.650 --> 00:04:16.270
We will have all of that rolled up
to the CAS, that's gonna be for

83
00:04:16.270 --> 00:04:21.340
reporting purposes primarily, it's really
just a Way in which we can aggregate and

84
00:04:21.340 --> 00:04:23.750
manage centrally and see all the data.

85
00:04:23.750 --> 00:04:25.240
And that's what we're looking at there.

86
00:04:25.240 --> 00:04:27.220
And that's what we just
want to understand.

87
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:32.865
As we scroll back over towards the left
we will see we do have our central site,

88
00:04:32.865 --> 00:04:33.935
primary sites.

89
00:04:33.935 --> 00:04:36.865
We then do have our
primary sites down below,

90
00:04:36.865 --> 00:04:40.905
roughly following the same kind
of architecture, as you can see.

91
00:04:40.905 --> 00:04:45.070
And we may then have one or more
secondary sites on the left hand side.

92
00:04:45.070 --> 00:04:47.490
At the bottom as well, you'll see that.

93
00:04:47.490 --> 00:04:51.270
And so we see central site linking
over to central admin site.

94
00:04:51.270 --> 00:04:52.490
Concept is the same.

95
00:04:52.490 --> 00:04:54.360
Naming is just a little bit different.

96
00:04:54.360 --> 00:04:56.490
We have our primary site or sites.

97
00:04:56.490 --> 00:04:58.230
We'll see those linking over as well.

98
00:04:58.230 --> 00:05:01.330
And our secondary sites,
we have more than one.

99
00:05:01.330 --> 00:05:04.690
So let's talk about some of those
colored arrows for just a minute and

100
00:05:04.690 --> 00:05:06.890
what they will represent.

101
00:05:06.890 --> 00:05:10.170
The first step we take at
the upper middle there, first one,

102
00:05:10.170 --> 00:05:14.900
the red arrow, says configure
source hierarchy, we're going to

103
00:05:14.900 --> 00:05:19.625
map the source hierarchy from the central
site primary on the left, over

104
00:05:19.625 --> 00:05:24.295
to our central admin site on the right,
or our main primary site on the right.

105
00:05:24.295 --> 00:05:28.105
Which is gonna be how we're gonna create
the connection using the migration wizard

106
00:05:28.105 --> 00:05:29.985
to start pulling information in and

107
00:05:29.985 --> 00:05:33.817
understand what it is we're gonna
see from the hierarchy perspective.

108
00:05:33.817 --> 00:05:37.817
We're then gonna, in step two, go through
and configure the additional source sites.

109
00:05:37.817 --> 00:05:41.267
So if we have additional primary sites,
we're gonna be pulling those in,

110
00:05:41.267 --> 00:05:44.697
we can see the main primary site
there is linked over as well.

111
00:05:44.697 --> 00:05:46.917
So we're gonna have those
steps accounted for and

112
00:05:46.917 --> 00:05:50.490
then in yellow, or our two yellow arrows.

113
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:54.250
We're gonna be migrating collections and
objects out of the primary site or

114
00:05:54.250 --> 00:05:56.420
sites that are gonna contain them.

115
00:05:56.420 --> 00:06:00.280
So we will be pulling over
our various collections,

116
00:06:00.280 --> 00:06:03.080
our machines that are being managed.

117
00:06:03.080 --> 00:06:05.800
Application packages that we may have.

118
00:06:05.800 --> 00:06:08.280
We'll talk about that and
see how that goes.

119
00:06:08.280 --> 00:06:11.500
And then we'll be migrating
our clients over in green.

120
00:06:11.500 --> 00:06:13.510
So we'll be moving our clients over,

121
00:06:13.510 --> 00:06:15.370
meaning associating
them with the new site.

122
00:06:15.370 --> 00:06:17.900
New site codes have to be put in.

123
00:06:17.900 --> 00:06:21.100
We have to move them over into
probably new boundaries as well.

124
00:06:21.100 --> 00:06:22.860
So we'll talk about all that.

125
00:06:22.860 --> 00:06:24.470
And then down there in blue, or

126
00:06:24.470 --> 00:06:28.470
whatever color you would call that,
converting distribution points, pulling

127
00:06:28.470 --> 00:06:32.950
those distribution points over from our
secondary sites where ever they may be,

128
00:06:32.950 --> 00:06:37.500
into our distribution points
on the 2012 R2 infrastructure.

129
00:06:37.500 --> 00:06:41.120
Because we have to bring our packages
over, update our distribution,

130
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:44.190
make sure we redistribute the packages,
have those available.

131
00:06:44.190 --> 00:06:46.400
So we're gonna be going
through these steps.

132
00:06:46.400 --> 00:06:49.985
And it's critical to understand
the migration is going to be performed

133
00:06:49.985 --> 00:06:51.080
side-by-side.

134
00:06:51.080 --> 00:06:53.560
In other words,
we have this infrastructure up and

135
00:06:53.560 --> 00:06:55.320
running in parallel, right?

136
00:06:55.320 --> 00:06:59.615
And we have to have both sets of
infrastructure available, so we have to

137
00:06:59.615 --> 00:07:04.485
built out the 12 R2 environment,
we have to access to the 2007 platform,

138
00:07:04.485 --> 00:07:08.734
and we have to then be able to create
connections from one to the other.

139
00:07:08.734 --> 00:07:12.062
Things that we can migrate,
types of objects that we'll come across,

140
00:07:12.062 --> 00:07:14.564
these various colored lines
as we're doing things.

141
00:07:14.564 --> 00:07:17.610
So in particular thinking about
what's in the yellow area there.

142
00:07:17.610 --> 00:07:19.840
What we may see so to speak.

143
00:07:19.840 --> 00:07:22.220
We will migrate collections
as you can see.

144
00:07:22.220 --> 00:07:25.820
Advertisements we'll come across,
if we have any.

145
00:07:25.820 --> 00:07:29.100
Remember advertisements are used
to essentially tell a client

146
00:07:29.100 --> 00:07:31.791
in a group somewhere hey there's
software out there, right.

147
00:07:31.791 --> 00:07:34.500
Wanna pull that software in and
you may wanna use it.

148
00:07:34.500 --> 00:07:36.785
So it's almost like taking
an ad out on the paper,

149
00:07:36.785 --> 00:07:38.970
thatt's probably why we call
it advertisements, right?

150
00:07:38.970 --> 00:07:42.972
And we're gonna have those, we can pull
those across, boundaries as I mentioned,

151
00:07:42.972 --> 00:07:45.560
may be pulled across they
also It may be reset.

152
00:07:45.560 --> 00:07:47.050
We may use new boundaries.

153
00:07:47.050 --> 00:07:51.226
Software distribution packages will
come across to the distribution points.

154
00:07:51.226 --> 00:07:55.375
Virtual application packages, if we're
doing AbV will come across as well.

155
00:07:55.375 --> 00:07:57.057
We'll talk about how we deal with those.

156
00:07:57.057 --> 00:07:59.471
Asset intelligence customizations.

157
00:07:59.471 --> 00:08:03.924
If we've done any of that customization
work, we can pull that catalog across.

158
00:08:03.924 --> 00:08:06.807
Software metering rules can be migrated.

159
00:08:06.807 --> 00:08:12.269
In the operating system deployment area,
we'll be able to pull over boot images,

160
00:08:12.269 --> 00:08:17.040
driver packages, drivers, images,
packages, and task sequences.

161
00:08:17.040 --> 00:08:19.417
All the things that are near and
dear to our hearts.

162
00:08:19.417 --> 00:08:23.595
And for instance with MDOP, I know that
you Wes have an interest with that and

163
00:08:23.595 --> 00:08:24.652
spend time there.

164
00:08:24.652 --> 00:08:26.573
We'd be able to pull in,
all of the imaging,

165
00:08:26.573 --> 00:08:28.554
all of the task sequencing
that we're doing.

166
00:08:28.554 --> 00:08:32.144
We're able to build on that commitment
we've already made to the infrastructure

167
00:08:32.144 --> 00:08:34.340
and the configuration,
so we don't lose it all.

168
00:08:34.340 --> 00:08:38.296
Cuz as you know having done it right, it's
a lot of time invested in the platform

169
00:08:38.296 --> 00:08:42.387
to rebuild those images and those task
sequences in particular to do automation.

170
00:08:42.387 --> 00:08:46.329
Desired configuration management, we'll
be able to pull over the configuration

171
00:08:46.329 --> 00:08:48.310
baselines and the configuration items.

172
00:08:48.310 --> 00:08:49.799
Those will all come across.

173
00:08:49.799 --> 00:08:53.343
We'll also see under software updates,
the WSUS functionality.

174
00:08:53.343 --> 00:08:57.289
As we configure and build in patch
management will be able to bring our

175
00:08:57.289 --> 00:09:02.403
deployments, our deployment packages,
our templates, our software updates lists.

176
00:09:02.403 --> 00:09:06.516
All of these things will be migrating or
potentially targets for migration, but

177
00:09:06.516 --> 00:09:09.792
there are also things that
are excluded that we cannot migrate.

178
00:09:09.792 --> 00:09:11.400
We wanna know about these, as well.

179
00:09:11.400 --> 00:09:15.133
Queries cannot be migrated over, which
is one of the big bummers, so to speak,

180
00:09:15.133 --> 00:09:16.595
because we can't bring that.

181
00:09:16.595 --> 00:09:17.705
Can we go back to the picture?

182
00:09:17.705 --> 00:09:20.262
I wanna be able to reference this and
talk about why.

183
00:09:20.262 --> 00:09:22.168
When we cannot bring over queries,

184
00:09:22.168 --> 00:09:26.115
the reason we're not able to do this
is that the databases are different.

185
00:09:26.115 --> 00:09:30.786
And if you think about the logic of this,
those blue kinda cylindrical objects

186
00:09:30.786 --> 00:09:35.126
sitting to the right of all of the server
icons, any one of those things.

187
00:09:35.126 --> 00:09:38.049
They almost look like little erasers or
something like that.

188
00:09:38.049 --> 00:09:42.812
Those are meant to represent our databases
in the diagram and those databases as you

189
00:09:42.812 --> 00:09:47.438
can see are gonna be linked to the site
architecture by deployment platform, and

190
00:09:47.438 --> 00:09:51.742
they contain different information,
and they are different instances.

191
00:09:51.742 --> 00:09:57.070
Those queries in 2007 are run against
the databases in the 2007 side.

192
00:09:57.070 --> 00:10:00.184
That information is not gonna
be represented accurately and

193
00:10:00.184 --> 00:10:03.908
fully on the 2012 R2 side,
because we're changing, modifying,

194
00:10:03.908 --> 00:10:07.157
migrating some thing's do come over,
some thing's don't.

195
00:10:07.157 --> 00:10:08.892
The queries have to be rewritten.

196
00:10:08.892 --> 00:10:13.188
This is one of the big gotchas, because
especially if we've done a lot of custom

197
00:10:13.188 --> 00:10:16.781
query work to bring over and
